Its presence enables breathing and sustains vitality, hence one does not die.
The breath’s qi enters from outside, first reaching the lungs. The *Huangting Jing* names the lungs *"White Origin"* and also *"Formed by Emptiness,"* for the lungs are empty, formed by the accumulation of qi. Thus, within the body, the lungs open and close with each inhalation and exhalation; the qi’s entry and exit cause the lungs to open and close. The lungs’ opening and closing follow the qi’s movement in and out.

chunks.original_text: 盖言为心声，舌为心苗，是非之生，大半出于口舌。 兼之眩也迷也，六根门头，漏失神气。 日顺其欲，漏乃日多，而人渐衰老而病死，此顺行造化也。 故循顺而不改，有生有死； 逆而返之，则长生而仙矣。 识神之为物，愈用而愈灵。 后天之智慧，皆识神所出也，愈灵而愈堕落。 作奸犯科，奸盗诈伪，皆此识神主之。 元神则不然，不识不知，顺帝之则，循造化之自然而通灵。 《阴符经》举一“盗”字，言盗天地之元气，皆元神之事也。 《西游记》孙悟空以石猴下世，石者实也，虚中生实也。 而盗兵器、盗金箍捧、盗桃、盗酒、盗丹，无一而不盗。 其在傲来国盗兵器，尚为寻常之兵器，凡金也，即后天也。 至水晶宫盗金箍捧，则为真铅，水中金矣，先天炁矣。 盗桃即木也，盗酒即酉水也，本在东家子，西邻寄体生，金木交并也； 盗丹即阴阳和合也，故愈盗而神通愈大。 如人自下生，至“五千四百生黄道”之日，盖无日而不盗，皆于不识不知之中行之，以完成纯阳童体。 乾为纯阳为天，故曰“齐天”也。 《阴符经》曰：“三盗既宜，三才既安。 ”天地日月亦盗也，盗太极之炁，以为造化之气，其理正同。 先天炁自外来，为我之主人； 后天气亦自外来，亦为我身主人。 有外必有内，内即神也，外即气也，元神与乾元祖性同体，后变识神，亦为我主人。 凡一切动作行为，皆神主之，而无气则不能感通而役使有形之体。 故神之为主人，无形之主人，心之主人也； 气之为主人，有形之主人，身之主人也； 神可为法身之主人，而和合元气，以成阳神。 此元气并能将识神返为元神，以成胎仙。 《黄庭经》谓“琴心三叠”，即调和神气也。 盖呼吸之气非命蒂，而命蒂在其中； 思虑之神非性根，而性根在其内。 即后天以复先天，空洞无物，不随识神用事，性住气回即得其道矣。 夫人内神而外气，神为主而气为宾。 气动神动，息转念生，一呼一吸，而色声香味触法因之而生。 神因气以外驰，日日顺之，神散精竭而气绝，以有衰老病死，此凡道也。 虽能生子生女，而本体无有不坏者也。 若仙道则反之，内空以招外有，外空以生内有。 彼本虚也，以我实之则为有； 彼本宾也，以我迎之则为主。 颠倒主宾，同归虚空之太极，以重造性命，故丹经屡曰“再造乾坤”、《悟真》曰“用将须分左右军，饶他为主我为宾”也。 所谓“左右”者，即以我之虚空，通太虚之虚空。 虚之极，静之笃，而后与太虚化合，无人无我，无物无法，浑然如鸿蒙未判之先，而窈冥恍惚之中，生出与先天乾元祖性同类之一点真阳。 正如彼宾外来，到我面前，丹经所谓“铅至药生，真阳自虚无中来”、“九三男子来投宿”、“其中有象、其中有精、其精甚真”者，皆是也。 当此之时，我若不惊、不怖、不畏，安我虚无，守我静笃，不识不知，顺其自然，则一转瞬之间，而我陷于坎中之乾金，即埋藏大渊，深不可测，晦而难见之生身受炁之乾元祖性，因同类相感之理，忽然涌出，正如磁石吸铁，而与外来之真阳，合而为一。 丹经所谓“汞迎得药”、“采药归炉”、“嫁与金公作老郎”、“二八佳人去安床”、“牵来白虎归家养”、“其中有信”者，皆是也。
chunks.translated_text:
For speech is the voice of the heart, and the tongue its sprout—thus, the arising of right and wrong largely stems from the mouth and tongue. Moreover, dazzlement and confusion at the gates of the six senses leak and dissipate spirit and qi. Daily indulgence in desire causes these leaks to grow ever greater, and so one gradually weakens, ages, sickens, and dies—this is the natural course of creation. Thus, to follow this course without change is to be born and to die; to reverse it and return is to attain longevity and become an immortal.

The *shen* of consciousness grows more acute the more it is used. All post-natal wisdom arises from this *shen* of consciousness, yet the sharper it becomes, the deeper one falls. Deceit, crime, fraud, and falsehood—all are governed by this *shen* of consciousness. The original spirit (*yuan shen*), however, is otherwise: unknowing and unperceiving, it follows the decree of the Emperor and moves in accord with the spontaneity of creation, thereby achieving numinous communion. The *Yinfu Jing* speaks of a single word—“stealing”—referring to the theft of the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth, which is the work of the original spirit. In *Journey to the West*, Sun Wukong descends to the world as a stone monkey: the stone is solidity, born of emptiness within. Yet he steals weapons, steals the golden-hooped staff, steals peaches, steals wine, steals elixir—nothing he does not steal. When he steals weapons in the Country of Aolai, these are still ordinary weapons, mere metal—post-natal. But when he steals the golden-hooped staff from the Crystal Palace, it is true lead, metal within water—primordial qi. Stealing peaches is wood; stealing wine is the water of the tenth Earthly Branch; originally belonging to the east, it is born in the west, where metal and wood converge. Stealing the elixir is the harmony of yin and yang. Thus, the more he steals, the greater his spiritual powers grow. Like one born below, by the day of “five thousand four hundred births in the Yellow Path,” there is no day he does not steal—all is done in unknowing and unperceiving, to complete the body of a pure yang youth. Qian is pure yang, is Heaven, hence “Equal to Heaven.”

The *Yinfu Jing* says: *“When the three thefts are fitting, the Three Powers are at peace.”* Even Heaven, Earth, sun, and moon are thieves—they steal the qi of the Great Ultimate to become the qi of creation, the principle of which is the same. Primordial qi comes from without to become the master within me; post-natal qi also comes from without to become the master of my body. Where there is an outer, there must be an inner: the inner is spirit, the outer is qi. The original spirit shares the same substance as the primordial nature of Qian; when it later transforms into the *shen* of consciousness, it too becomes a master within me. All movement and action are governed by spirit, yet without qi, it cannot communicate or command the physical body. Thus, spirit is the master—the formless master, the master of the heart; qi is the master—the embodied master, the master of the body. Spirit can be the master of the Dharma-body, and when harmonized with primordial qi, it forms the yang spirit. This primordial qi can also return the *shen* of consciousness to the original spirit, giving birth to the fetal immortal.

The *Huangting Jing* speaks of “threefold zither-heart,” which is the harmonizing of spirit and qi. For the qi of breathing is not the root of life, yet the root of life resides within it; the spirit of thought is not the root of nature, yet the root of nature lies within. Thus, through the post-natal one returns to the primordial—emptiness without substance, not following the dictates of the *shen* of consciousness. When nature abides and qi returns, the Way is attained.

In humans, spirit is internal and qi external; spirit is the host and qi the guest. When qi moves, spirit moves; when breath turns, thought arises. With each inhalation and exhalation, the six sense objects—form, sound, scent, taste, touch, and dharma—come into being. Spirit, drawn outward by qi, daily follows this course, scattering spirit and depleting essence until qi is cut off. Thus arise aging, sickness, and death—this is the common path. Though one may bear sons and daughters, the original body is never without decay.

The immortal path, however, reverses this: inner emptiness draws outer fullness; outer emptiness gives rise to inner fullness. That which is originally void, when I make it solid, becomes real; that which is originally guest, when I welcome it, becomes host. By inverting host and guest, they return together to the Great Ultimate of emptiness, to recreate nature and life. Hence, the alchemical classics repeatedly speak of “recreating Heaven and Earth,” and the *Wuzhen Pian* says: *“To employ them, one must divide the left and right armies—let them be host while I am guest.”* The “left and right” refer to my own emptiness communicating with the emptiness of the Great Void. When emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness its utmost, one merges with the Great Void—no self, no other, no thing, no dharma—utterly as before the division of the primordial chaos. Within this profound and indistinct state, there arises a speck of true yang, of the same kind as the primordial nature of Qian.

Just as that guest comes from without to stand before me, the alchemical classics speak of *“when lead arrives, the medicine is born,”* *“true yang comes from the midst of emptiness,”* *“the nine-three man comes to lodge,”* *“within it there is an image, within it there is essence, its essence most true.”* At this moment, if I am neither startled nor afraid, neither awed nor alarmed, but rest in my emptiness and guard my stillness, unknowing and unperceiving, following its spontaneity—then in an instant, the Qian metal buried within Kan, hidden in the great abyss, deep and unfathomable, obscured and hard to perceive—the primordial nature of the life-receiving qi of Qian—suddenly surges forth by the principle of like attracting like, like a magnet drawing iron. It unites with the true yang that has come from without. The alchemical classics speak of *“mercury welcoming the medicine,”* *“gathering the medicine and returning to the furnace,”* *“marrying the Golden Lord as an old husband,”* *“the maiden of sixteen going to prepare the bed,”* *“leading the White Tiger home to raise,”* *“within it there is a sign.”* All refer to this.

The *Classic* says: *"The eyes are dazzled by the five colors, the ears confused by the five sounds."* The saying goes: *"The mouth opens and spirit-qi scatters; the tongue moves and disputes arise."* Here, *"mouth"* refers not merely to the organ of eating but to the gateway of the six senses. Only *"the tongue moves and disputes arise"* specifically refers to the mouth of eating.

chunks.original_text: 是迎外来之宾，而使之为我中宫主人也。 吾师东亭先生曰：“仆得诀后，每下功时，即见孙外公当面而来。 我急速应声曰：我愿退位为宾，你是我旧主人，请你到我家中做个新主人公，好同你安炉立鼎，化凡胎也。 ”但先天真阳生时，如电光一灼即过，苟如惊怖着相，或生心动念，或不能保持虚静，则不能采取，一瞬即化后天，不可复用，是谓当面错过。 古今来当面错过者，不知多少人。 人人皆有阳生之时，不知道者，未有不错过，未有不顺化。 盖铅虽到，而汞不迎，其觉不灵，其心不虚也； 修道之士，当面错过者，亦复不少，或认不得孙外公，或见象着心相，见景着身相，或经此一觉，无所措手足，是皆炼己未熟者也，此炼己工夫之所以无限也。 若得此真阳作我主人，则元神渐复，而识神渐泯，如是渐移渐多，而腹实矣。 腹实而心死神活矣，又何忧识神之为害也。 “取坎填离”、“积金实腹”，皆谓此也。 “返我本牲”、“还我元神”，亦谓此也。 坎，外也； 离，内也，一内一外，一神一炁，一虚一实也。 离内虚而外实，神在气中，此神为我所自有； 坎内实而外虚，阴居阳外，此炁所以自外来，外来者实也，真空中妙有也； 内有者虚也，妙有中真空也。 观下图自明： 先天坎、离居东西，后天离、坎变为震、兑，《悟真篇》曰：“震龙汞出自离乡，兑虎金生在坎方。 ”震、兑即离、坎也。 坎离、水火交，即是震兑、金木并也。 龙从火里出，东三南二同体也； 虎向水中生，北一西四同体也，东西即南北，金木即水火，五行即四象，四象即三家，三家即内外，内外即一家。 凡水火之交，金木之并，无不在中宫黄庭，而以真意行之。 黄庭土也，意亦土也，化来化去，归本于土。 土即一也，一即虚也、太极也。 修道者之作用，在内神外气，神即我也。 对人为有我，我为一，而人为二。 世俗自称我，多指鼻而言，此有深意，形身以鼻为主也，所谓“我”者，即指中阴情识。 人受生时，得先天一炁，无识无知。 至十月满足，感动中阴外来，作我主人，然后有知觉。 惟其有觉，乃有我相，即此所谓“我”，我即识神也。 然识神含有孽根，更加习性，实为假我。 所谓“真我”，乃生时所受之先天乾性是也。 此炁在儒家谓之太极中之理气，在天为命，于人为性，作生生之本，无欠无余。 人到死时，含孽根之识神，因堕地狱而受罪报； 至先天乾性，则仍还诸太虚，而不生不灭。 惟此不生不灭者，乃为真我。 修道者，应将识神融入性中，假我化合于真我，始为断绝业根，入于无余涅盘。 夫真我一本具万能，因假我来侵夺其主体，逐之九渊之中，杳不可睹； 而假我返客为主，根尘相因，因而堕落。 倘分别不清，即认此识神为真我，而以识神为主以修道，佛书谓之“认贼作子”。 是应泯此识神，化假为真，经曰：“推情合性。 ”即推假我之识神，合入于真我之谓也。 兹自性情言之，《契》曰“性主处内，情主御外”者，性乃寂然不动之虚体，静而不动； 情则好动，根尘相接，而日驰于外。 情者，七情也，七情之发，皆缘于识，盖必外诱触之而后发，未有外诱不入，而自为喜怒哀乐者也。 故必感于外，而情动于中；
chunks.translated_text:
This is the welcoming of the guest from without, making it the master of my Central Palace. My teacher, Master Dongting, said: "After I received the oral instructions, whenever I practiced, I would see Grandfather Sun come before me. I would quickly respond, saying: ‘I willingly step down as guest, for you are my old master. I beg you to come to my home as the new host, so together we may set up the furnace and cauldron to transform this mortal frame.’"

Yet when the primordial true yang arises, it flashes like lightning and is gone in an instant. If one is startled or attached to appearances, or if the mind stirs with thoughts, or if one cannot maintain emptiness and stillness, then it cannot be gathered. In a moment, it transforms into the postnatal and can no longer be used—this is called "missing it face to face." From ancient times to the present, how many have missed it in this way? Every person has a moment when yang arises, but those who do not recognize it invariably miss it and let it transform naturally.

For though the lead arrives, if the mercury does not welcome it, awareness is not keen, and the heart is not empty. Among those who cultivate the Dao, many miss it face to face—some fail to recognize Grandfather Sun, some become attached to the images in their minds or the visions before their eyes, and some, upon this awakening, are at a loss for what to do. All these are signs that the work of refining the self is not yet ripe; thus, the work of refining the self is endless.

If this true yang is made the master within, then the original spirit gradually returns while the conscious spirit gradually fades. As this shift occurs little by little, the abdomen becomes full. When the abdomen is full, the heart dies and the spirit lives—what worry is there then that the conscious spirit will cause harm? *"Drawing from Kan to fill Li,"* *"accumulating metal to fill the abdomen"*—all refer to this. *"Returning to my original nature,"* *"restoring my original spirit"*—these also refer to this.

Kan is without; Li is within. One is inner, one is outer; one is spirit, one is qi; one is emptiness, one is fullness. Li is empty within and full without, with spirit residing in qi—this spirit is what I inherently possess. Kan is full within and empty without, with yin dwelling outside yang—this qi comes from without, and what comes from without is fullness, the wondrous existence within true emptiness. What is within is emptiness, the true emptiness within wondrous existence.

Observe the diagram below to understand: In the primordial state, Kan and Li reside in the west and east; in the postnatal state, Li and Kan transform into Zhen and Dui. As the *Wuzhen Pian* says: *"The dragon of Zhen mercury emerges from the land of Li; the tiger of Dui metal is born in the region of Kan."* Zhen and Dui are Li and Kan. The union of Kan and Li, water and fire, is the same as the pairing of Zhen and Dui, metal and wood.

The dragon emerges from fire, for east (three) and south (two) share the same body. The tiger is born from water, for north (one) and west (four) share the same body. East and west are thus south and north; metal and wood are water and fire; the Five Phases are the Four Symbols; the Four Symbols are the Three Families; the Three Families are inner and outer; inner and outer are one family. All unions of water and fire, all pairings of metal and wood, occur within the Yellow Court of the Central Palace, guided by true intention.

The Yellow Court is earth; intention is also earth. Transformations come and go, returning to earth. Earth is the One; the One is emptiness, the Supreme Ultimate. The practitioner’s work lies in the inner spirit and outer qi—spirit is the self. In relation to others, the self is one, while others are two. The common worldly reference to "I" often points to the nose, which holds deep meaning, for the physical form is governed by the nose. This "I" refers to the emotions and perceptions of the intermediate state.

When a person is born, they receive the primordial qi of the One, without knowledge or perception. By the tenth month, they are stirred by the external intermediate state, which becomes their master, and only then do they gain awareness. It is through this awareness that the sense of self arises—this is what is meant by "I," and this "I" is the conscious spirit. Yet the conscious spirit contains the roots of karmic obstructions, compounded by habitual tendencies, making it the false self.

The "true self" is the primordial Qian nature received at birth. In Confucian terms, this qi is the principle within the Supreme Ultimate; in heaven, it is fate; in humans, it is nature, the foundation of life, complete and without lack. At death, the conscious spirit, burdened with karmic roots, falls into hell and suffers retribution, while the primordial Qian nature returns to the great void, neither born nor destroyed. Only this unborn and undestroyed nature is the true self.

The cultivator must merge the conscious spirit into nature, transforming the false self into the true self, thereby cutting off the roots of karma and entering the state of *nirvana* without remainder. The true self, in its original state, possesses boundless potential, but the false self usurps its mastery and drives it into the nine abysses, where it becomes utterly obscured. The false self, having become the host in place of the guest, entangles itself with the roots of sensory experience and thus falls into degradation.

If one fails to distinguish clearly, mistaking the conscious spirit for the true self and taking it as the basis for cultivation, Buddhist texts call this "mistaking the thief for one’s child." One must dissolve this conscious spirit, transforming the false into the true. The scriptures say: *"Push emotion to unite with nature,"* meaning to push the conscious spirit of the false self to merge with the true self.

Now, speaking of nature and emotion, the *Canticle* says: *"Nature presides within, emotion governs without."* Nature is the quiescent, unmoving empty body, still and unmoving. Emotion, however, is fond of movement, engaging with the roots of sensory experience and daily racing outward. Emotion refers to the seven emotions, and their arising all stem from consciousness. For they are only stirred after being provoked by external influences—there is no joy, anger, sorrow, or delight that arises without external provocation. Thus, one is always moved by what is without, and emotion stirs within.
chunks.overlap_context: of the life-receiving qi of Qian—suddenly surges forth by the principle of like attracting like, like a magnet drawing iron. It unites with the true yang that has come from without. The alchemical classics speak of *“mercury welcoming the medicine,”* *“gathering the medicine and returning to the furnace,”* *“marrying the Golden Lord as an old husband,”* *“the maiden of sixteen going to prepare the bed,”* *“leading the White Tiger home to raise,”* *“within it there is a sign.”* All refer to this.

chunks.original_text: 情动于中，而形于外。 六识激之，而后七情应之，情因识发，识以情见，情识相缘，而六根之返源无日； 性天之主，且为所蔽，而失其真矣，曹仙姑《咏乾金诗》云“昔年云雾深遮蔽，此日相逢道眼开”是也。 又谓谷神为大极初生一炁，与天同类，与太虚同体，故曰“天命之为性”。 性本不动，故曰“处内”； 情乃常动于外，故曰“御外”。 御者何？ 御六识也。 防御外之六贼，不使侵入，则六识不生； 六识不生，则七情不动； 偶尔有触，亦皆中节，中节则和矣。 和者何？ 和其性也，和内外为一也，即一也，未发之中即性也。 性之中，情之和，即道之“中”与“一”也，一贯之道也。 以情御外，则性自安处于内矣。 情御外识而识泯，则情返先天之元情，假者归真，而复乾金矣。 丹书以元精元情，将假我泯去，推之外出，招来真我，作为金公，亦颠倒之意也。 欲推情合性，必先筑堤防，以御外诱。 外诱不入，则假我自泯，而渐复真我矣。 然欲招真我，非将假我推出灵台，打扫干净不为功，故先须从内下手。 而其作用，仍在于外，经曰“内外双修”是也。 此返还工夫之所由来也。 《契》曰“内以养己，安静虚无。 原本隐明，内照形躯。 闭塞其兑，筑固灵株。 三光陆沉，温养子珠。 视之不见，近而易求”者，言养性之初功，即御外之堤防也。 所谓“内以养己”，即炼己也，养己在我小虚空之中，必先“安静虚无”，以通彼大虚空之中，方能混沌，而招来真我。 真我即乾性也，原本妙明，至虚至实。 所谓“隐”者，以其寂也，迨为假我之识神所掩，而隐藏于密密者，视之不见，索之不得也。 然其灵仍时时内照形躯，何以见之？ 譬如人沉沉熟睡之时，已无知识，识神泯矣，静已极矣，而灵觉因以发见。 倘有人从旁呼唤，即能觉醒，灵觉之觉，非识神之觉也。 又人遇灾变，事前自身有得先兆者，亦性中之灵也。 修道者，若能安静虚无，则能复其灵明。 盖性为之本体，虚无为性所自生，虚极静笃，则心自明而性自见矣，其道首在“闭塞其兑”。 兑，口也，非饮食之口，乃六根之门户也。 蔽塞六根，使之内念不出，外念不入，收视返听，不相接触，即“克己复礼”之道。 所谓视听言动，毋出非礼，自能克己复礼，而天下归仁，仁者，性也。 “灵株”即灵根，先天一炁是也，即仁也，“生生不已之谓仁”，仁者万物之灵根也。 筑之使固，即“允执厥中”也。 譬之筑墙然，经之营之，使就坚固，此筑基之事也。
chunks.translated_text:
Emotion stirs within and manifests without. The six consciousnesses excite it, and only then do the seven emotions respond—emotion arises from consciousness, and consciousness is revealed through emotion. As emotion and consciousness mutually arise, the six roots never return to their source. The lord of heavenly nature is thus obscured, losing its truth. As Immortal Cao Xian Gu’s *Ode to Qian Gold* says: *"In former years, clouds and mist deeply veiled me; today, we meet with the Dao-eye opened."*

Moreover, the Valley Spirit is called the primal qi born of the Great Ultimate, of the same kind as Heaven and the same body as the Great Void, hence the saying: *"That which Heaven commands is called nature."* Nature is fundamentally unmoving, thus *"presiding within"*; emotion, however, is ever-moving without, thus *"governing without."* What does *"governing"* mean? It means governing the six consciousnesses—defending against the six external thieves to prevent their intrusion, so that the six consciousnesses do not arise. If the six consciousnesses do not arise, the seven emotions remain unstirred; even if occasionally provoked, all responses remain measured. When measured, harmony is achieved.

What is harmony? It is the harmony of nature, the unity of inner and outer—this unity is the *"central"* state before arousal, which is nature itself. The centrality of nature and the harmony of emotion are the Dao’s *"central"* and *"one"*—the all-pervading Way. By governing emotion externally, nature naturally rests within. When emotion governs the external consciousness and consciousness dissolves, emotion returns to the primordial emotion of pre-heaven, the false merges into the true, and Qian Gold is restored.

The alchemical texts speak of primordial essence and primordial emotion, dissolving the false self and pushing it outward to summon the true self, forming the Golden Duke—this is the meaning of *"reversal."* To push emotion to unite with nature, one must first build dikes to defend against external provocations. If external provocations do not enter, the false self naturally dissolves, and the true self gradually returns.

Yet to summon the true self, one must first expel the false self from the spirit-terrace and sweep it clean—this is the essential work. Thus, one must begin within, though its function lies without, as the scriptures say: *"dual cultivation of inner and outer."* This is the origin of the work of return.

The *Canticle* says: *"Within, nurture the self, tranquil and void. The original root, hidden yet luminous, inwardly illumines the body. Seal the senses, fortify the spiritual root. The Three Lights sink into obscurity, warming and nourishing the child-pearl. Though unseen, it is near and easily sought."* This speaks of the initial work of nurturing nature, which is the dike of defense against externals.

*"Nurturing the self within"* refers to refining the self—cultivating the self within one’s small void, first achieving *"tranquility and emptiness"* to connect with the great void beyond, thereby merging into chaos and summoning the true self. The true self is the Qian nature, originally wondrously luminous, utterly empty yet utterly real. *"Hidden"* refers to its quiescence; when veiled by the false self’s conscious spirit, it becomes concealed in secrecy, unseen and ungraspable.

Yet its numinosity still inwardly illumines the body—how can this be known? Consider a person in deep sleep, devoid of knowledge, the conscious spirit dissolved, utterly still—yet spiritual awareness emerges. If someone calls from the side, they awaken; this awakening is the awareness of spiritual luminosity, not the conscious spirit’s awareness. Or when one encounters calamity and perceives omens beforehand, this too is the numinosity within nature. For the cultivator, if one can achieve tranquility and emptiness, one can restore this luminosity.

For nature is the fundamental substance, and emptiness is what nature itself generates. When emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness is profound, the heart naturally brightens and nature naturally appears. The key lies in *"sealing the senses."* The *"senses"* (dui) refer not to the mouth that eats and drinks, but to the gateways of the six roots. Blocking the six roots prevents inner thoughts from leaking out and outer thoughts from entering—withdrawing sight and reversing hearing, so they do not engage with externals. This is the Way of *"restraining the self and returning to propriety."* When seeing, hearing, speaking, and acting do not transgress propriety, one naturally restrains the self and returns to propriety, and *"all under heaven returns to benevolence."* Benevolence is nature.

The *"spiritual root"* is the primordial qi of pre-heaven—this is benevolence, *"that which ceaselessly generates is called benevolence."* Benevolence is the spiritual root of the myriad things. Fortifying it is *"holding fast to the center."* It is like building a wall—tending and strengthening it until it becomes firm. This is the work of laying the foundation.

chunks.original_text: 三光在天为日、月、星； 在人之三光，即耳、目、口。 此口字，不仅指口舌言，出入门户皆是也。 沉之于渊，方能“温养子珠”。 子珠，性珠也，安静虚无，而后复性，故谓之“子”。 修士以色身修法身，由后天返先天，故以后天为母，而所生之先天为子也。 珠者圆明之意，言其本来圆明也。 必先陆沉三光，目不视而神凝，耳不听而精固，口鼻不动而气聚，三光之外漏者，收而沉之大渊之中，则已失之珠，可还之合浦矣。 此珠虽“视之不见”，而其实“近而易求”，所谓“道在眼前”是也。 《悟真篇》曰：“真金既返黄金屋，一颗明珠永不离。 ”即此珠也。 修道者，欲取赤水玄珠，可使“罔象”求之。 罔象者，不知不识之谓也。 昔者黄帝失珠，使离明求之，不得，而罔象偶得之。 言无求珠之心，乃能得珠也。 道家谓此珠曰“灵珠”，又曰“宝珠”； 佛家谓之“牟尼宝珠”，又谓之“舍利子”； 道家又谓之曰“丹头”，乃人身先天之乾金也。 工夫作到虚极静笃时，此珠若隐若显，渐见渐明。 其象即在眼前，有时极其明朗，道家亦谓之“星”，又谓之“斗魁”。 魁本文星属木，为东方之宿，喻性之灵，且于《河图》为“东三”也。 又曰“夺得骊龙颔下珠”，亦此意也，颔下之珠，亦隐而不显之谓也。 工夫到真静时，于眼前常见一珠之象，是性光初露故也； 然静不笃，则不能见。 世之画佛象者，于两眉间加一圈，即形容此象也。 经曰“如来眉间放白毫光”是也。 此珠“视之不见，近而易求”，潜藏于北极大渊之中，产于东海龙宫之内，故佛家有“龙女献珠”之说。 所谓“温养子珠”者，在子珠未得之时，而安静虚无，陆沉三光以求之。 性光未复，不可寻视，及其既见，象在眼前，根本切在于身心，可谓近矣。 此类皆是象言,象者像也，像其事，或像其情也。 如性珠、性月，则是法相之相，修道工夫中应有之虚象。 然此种相，亦是虚妄，见象不可着象，若着象，则象亦化矣。 从目前虚象变化，即心中亦不能安静虚无矣。 此象初见，如一点小星，渐积渐大，而渐明以成珠。 其光刺目，开目合目，皆能见之，故称“夜光珠”。 此就性珠言之也。 至于下功性命双修，有时其象为月，道书中此类比象甚多。 盖见于外者为象，身所经者为景，修道者步步有象，步步有景； 象不可着于心，景亦不可着于身。 象因阴阳气合而成，故见象均在恍惚之时，譬如地气上蒸，因天之阳气映照，而为彩云，变幻无穷。 人身之阴气，与阳气和合，则亦有虚变之象。 阳有光而阴有色，光与色映，自生诸象。 《金刚经》曰：“凡所有相，皆是虚妄。 ”道书谓：“不可执象。 ”皆恐学人误于此也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Three Lights in heaven are the sun, moon, and stars; in man, the Three Lights are the ears, eyes, and mouth. This "mouth" does not refer merely to speech but to all gates of ingress and egress. Only when they are sunk into the abyss can one "warmly nurture the child-pearl." The child-pearl is the pearl of nature—when tranquil and empty, nature is restored, hence it is called "child." The adept refines the Dharma-body through the physical form, returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, thus regarding the postnatal as the mother and the prenatal it generates as the child. "Pearl" signifies roundness and luminosity, denoting its original radiance.

First, one must submerge the Three Lights: the eyes do not see yet spirit congeals, the ears do not hear yet essence solidifies, the mouth and nose remain unmoving and qi gathers. The outward leaks of the Three Lights are gathered and sunk into the great abyss, so that the lost pearl may be returned to Hepu. Though this pearl is "invisible when sought," it is in truth "near and easily attained"—what is meant by "the Dao is before one’s eyes." As *The Awakening to Reality* states: "Once true gold returns to the golden house, a single luminous pearl will never depart." This is that pearl.

For those cultivating the Dao who seek the Scarlet Water’s Mystic Pearl, let "Wangxiang" retrieve it. Wangxiang means "unknowing and unrecognizing." Once, the Yellow Emperor lost his pearl and sent Liming to search for it, but to no avail; Wangxiang, however, chanced upon it. This signifies that only without the intent to seek the pearl can one obtain it.

Daoists call this pearl the "Spirit Pearl" or "Treasure Pearl"; Buddhists name it the "Muni Treasure Pearl" or "śarīra." Daoists also refer to it as the "Elixir Head," the prenatal Qian-metal of the human body. When practice reaches the state of extreme emptiness and profound stillness, this pearl appears and disappears, gradually becoming visible and bright. Its image manifests before the eyes—at times, it is exceedingly luminous. Daoists also call it the "star" or "Dipper’s bowl." The bowl, originally the Wen star of wood, is the eastern constellation, symbolizing the numinosity of nature and corresponding to "East Three" in the *River Chart*. It is also said, "Seizing the pearl beneath the black dragon’s chin"—this too refers to the pearl’s hidden, unmanifest nature.

When practice attains true stillness, a pearl-like image often appears before the eyes, for this is the initial revelation of nature’s light. Yet if stillness is not profound, it cannot be seen. Those who paint Buddhist images place a circle between the brows to depict this phenomenon, as the sutra says: "The Tathāgata emits white light from between his brows."

This pearl, though "invisible when sought," is "near and easily attained," concealed within the North Pole’s great abyss and born in the Dragon Palace of the Eastern Sea—hence the Buddhist tale of the "dragon maiden offering the pearl." "Warmly nurturing the child-pearl" means that before the pearl is obtained, one must remain tranquil and empty, submerging the Three Lights to seek it. Before nature’s light is restored, one must not search for it; once seen, its image appears before the eyes, its root fundamentally residing in body and mind—truly near.

All such descriptions are figurative. "Figure" means likeness—likening the matter or the state. Terms like "pearl of nature" or "moon of nature" are the forms of dharma-reality, virtual images that arise in the course of Daoist practice. Yet these images are also illusory; one must not cling to them, for if one does, the image will dissolve. As the virtual image before the eyes transforms, the mind too can no longer remain tranquil and empty.

When this image first appears, it resembles a tiny star, gradually accumulating and expanding until it brightens into a pearl. Its light dazzles the eyes, visible whether they are open or closed—hence the name "night-shining pearl." This describes the pearl of nature. In the dual cultivation of nature and life, the image sometimes manifests as the moon, and Daoist texts abound with such metaphors.

What is seen externally is called "image," while what the body experiences is called "scene." In Daoist practice, every step has its image, every step its scene; yet one must not fixate on images in the heart or cling to scenes in the body. Images arise from the union of yin and yang qi, so they appear in moments of vagueness and indistinctness—like earth’s vapor rising and, illuminated by heaven’s yang qi, forming colorful clouds that shift endlessly. When the yin qi of the human body harmonizes with yang qi, virtual images likewise arise. Yang possesses light, yin possesses color; when light and color intermingle, all manner of images naturally emerge.

As the *Diamond Sutra* states: "All conditioned phenomena are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows." Daoist texts warn: "Do not cling to images." Both caution practitioners against falling into error here.

chunks.translated_text:
The terms "warming and nurturing" encompass the work of fire and timing. "Warming" means neither cold nor parched; "nurturing" means containing and fostering. If one falls into dull emptiness, the water grows cold; if thoughts do not cease, the fire turns parched. Cold water and parched fire prevent the formation of the pearl of the child. One must preserve the insubstantial while guarding the substantial, neither aiding nor forgetting, to warm it; and nurture it with unbroken continuity, using it without strain—only then can the hidden nature gradually become luminous, and the primordial spiritual root gradually firm. This is what is called "cultivating and nurturing the bud."

**Fifth Lesson: Utmost Emptiness and Profound Stillness—Merging Sentiment with Nature**
**The Two Apertures Method Naturally Connects with Spirit Illumination**

The *Canticle* states: "Gradually the Yellow Center becomes permeable with principle, moistening and nourishing the skin and flesh. Beginning with rectitude ensures completion; standing firm at the outset allows no holding back. The One veils and conceals—none in the world know it." This speaks of the efficacy of refining the self: the spiritual root is restored, and resonance brings immediate communion.

Once one attains tranquility and emptiness to nurture the root of one’s nature, the original countenance can gradually be recovered. By inwardly illuminating the body, closing the aperture of the mouth, and turning the light back to reflect, the spiritual root gradually grows, forming the luminous pearl that restores one’s primordial hun-tun spirit—this is the internal process. Yet the path of internal nurturing hinges on the word "tranquility," which arises from striving toward effortless ease. When first undertaking self-refinement, the six senses scatter outward, making stillness impossible. Through persistent practice of concentration—reducing and further reducing until reaching non-action—over time, body and mind attain great stability. Naturally, non-action prevails: effort is not applied, yet its function operates spontaneously; thoughts are not forcibly suppressed, yet they subside of their own accord. Only then is "tranquility, emptiness, and non-being" achieved. Within the empty chamber, whiteness arises, and from the void emerges a single point of true yang—this is the originally hidden luminous nature, forming the mysterious aperture of the central palace. As the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* states: "The medicine is born in the mysterious aperture."

This point of true yang is the great medicine. Initially born within the void, it has yet to be felt in the body, so one must concentrate the spirit into the qi cavity to warm and nurture this pearl of the child—the pearl being the generated true yang. "The three lights sinking" refers to concentrating the spirit into the qi cavity, which is also the "mysterious aperture." The medicine is the "wondrous aperture," and also fire—different names for the same thing, known to few.

Though this medicine and this aperture are invisible to the eye, they are near and easily sought. When spirit and qi converge, the three palaces fill with qi; the mechanism stirs, and the flute sounds—then the Yellow Center becomes permeable with principle. The phrase "the Yellow Center becomes permeable with principle" comes from the *Book of Changes*, *Kun* hexagram: "The Yellow Center permeates with principle, rightly positioned within the body. Beauty resides within and flows to the four limbs." This describes the principle of external resonance and internal response.

Here, "principle" refers to the principle of the Supreme Ultimate’s qi; it also means "interior" and "ritual," as the ancient characters were interchangeable, signifying the movement from external to internal. Thus, beauty resides within and manifests in the four limbs. Only when the Yellow Center becomes permeable with principle can its effects extend to the body—this is what the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* calls "the fire timing activates the yang furnace."

When stripping reaches its extreme, it returns—*Fu* (Return) is the initial line of *Qian* (Creative). By the fifth line of *Kun* (Receptive), emptiness has reached its utmost, and stillness has become profound. The fourth line, "the sack is tied," marks the moment when the myriad things return to their root; the fifth line, bearing "the yellow skirt, supremely auspicious," signifies the rise of the primordial at the end of integrity—precisely the time when the myriad things recover their mandate. Transforming into *Fire over Earth* (*Jin*), "the noble person illuminates his virtue." "Illuminating one’s virtue" means that virtue is the principle and qi of the primordial Supreme Ultimate—"illuminating" also means "clarifying," thus clarifying one’s own luminous virtue.

"The Yellow Center becomes permeable with principle" is the resonance of principle and qi, through which true yang arrives. The four limbs are the first to respond, experiencing a sense of ease and expansion. The *Xian* (Influence) hexagram of the *Book of Changes* takes this as its image: the first line says, "Influence in the big toe," followed by "influence in the calf" and "thigh," culminating in "cheeks and tongue." The arrival of external yang is first felt in the hands and feet; through sustained resonance, it gradually extends to the entire body, progressing through *Fu* (Return), *Lin* (Approach), *Tai* (Peace), *Da Zhuang* (Great Strength), to *Guai* (Breakthrough) and *Qian* (Creative). When hardness and softness first unite, clouds drift and rain falls, and the myriad things all flourish. When a single yin meets (in *Gou*), the fluids beneath the tongue are generated. Thus, the imagery of the *Xian* hexagram culminates at the cheeks and tongue.

Shao Yong’s poem, "Thirty-six palaces all are spring," describes the arrival of true yang at the palace, filling the entire body with supreme harmony. The formless method is nurtured by yin and permeated by yang—yin is emptiness, yang is wondrous being. The physical body of form is moistened by yin and permeated by yang—yang is metal essence, yin is wood fluid. As Lü Dongbin’s poem says, "I know how to arrange the four yin and yang"—this is the meaning.

"Yellow skirt" refers to the Yellow Center; "primordial" refers to the initially permeating yang. Because it permeates principle, it is called "auspicious"—this is what the *Mirror of Ingesting the Medicine* calls "receiving qi is auspicious." In the *Kun* hexagram, from "eternal integrity" to the fifth line, integrity ends and the primordial arises, giving birth to yang. The top line marks the union of yin and yang, where "dragons contend."

The *Canticle* further states: "Golden sand enters the five viscera, dispersing like mist and rain."

chunks.original_text: 熏蒸达四体，颜色悦怿好。 ”盖一点真阳，生于虚中，正是重阴之下，一阳来复之象，故老子曰“静曰复命”也。 阳之初复，凝于玄窍，玄窍即黄中也。 由黄中而内中通于一身，其灵根仍在玄窍之中，而其气已充沛乎四肢，上下透彻，肌肤和煦，而且润泽，《参同契阐幽》谓“温养子珠，勿忘勿助，久之神明自生，渐渐四通八达，身中九窍百脉，三百六十骨节，八万四千毛孔，一齐穿透，自然光润和泽，感而遂通”是也。 “美在其中”一句，即指阴、阳交感，仍在玄窍之中。 此《西游记》孙悟空，入水帘洞，即称“美猴王”之意。 猴为申，申字一中之中，设象极妙。 此中原是天造地设的家当，惜世人悟得空者少耳，“初正终修，干立末持”两句，所以明安养之为要，而工夫之必以渐入也。 在修道者，念必须正，无念之念，方为正念，方能发生造化； 否则不着有即着无，皆于事无当。 故曰：“初正则终修，干立末可持。 一者以掩蔽，世人莫知之。 ”一者，经曰“得其一，万事毕”，一即太极之一炁也。 独立而神，在阴阳未分之先，所以能生万物，能神能化，在人为乾元之祖性，先天之元神。 惜人尽以识神掩蔽，不知其有而求之，故离道日远矣。 若就命而论，当太极一炁未分阴阳之时，即为先天真阳，为万物之命根，人得之生身，故谓之“命宝”。 破体之后，下陷命门，以至阴跷，幽杳难见，虽日用而不知灾害矣。 性、命二者，实一物也。 受气之初，性命未分，及至分而掩蔽随之，世人就其顺者用之，遂忘其本。 《敲爻歌》曰“附耳低言玄妙诀，提上蓬莱第一峰”，即谓下陷坎宫之元气，修道者须提之使上升离宫。 “附耳低言”者，为须去耳目聪明，收视返听，塞兑缄口也。 坎为耳，兑为口，言出于口，声入于耳，口耳相通，要在虚空一窍，存无守有，由太渊中提出真阳，还之蓬莱峰上，藏之于耳中。 《西游记》孙悟空得金箍棒，由铁板桥下，入东海龙宫，于海藏取出，而起意者，为赤尻马猴，及通臂猿猴之四元帅将军。 水晶宫以比阴跷一穴，赤尻即两股间之《巽》卦，通臂下两手总持门之《艮》卦。 至金箍棒，以比元气，能大能小，顶天立地，而能随心所欲。 其变为极小，如绣花针，而藏之于耳者，命门与耳同为坎卦，元气本相通也。 比譬极妙，可参观之。 《契》又曰：“耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 ”即收视返听之意。 “真人潜深渊，浮游守规中”者，规中一窍，即虚空一穴； 浮游者，勿忘勿助之火候； 三宝即前之三光。 谓光者，从凝神言； 谓宝者，从精、气、神言。 “旋曲以视听”者，视听专一，旋之于内，曲即一偏之谓，由曲可以进于至诚也。 “开阖皆合同”者，一呼一吸，阴惨阳舒，不疾不徐，合其符节也。 观此句，可知口非指语言之口矣。 惟此为第一要求，故曰“为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷”，即绵绵不绝，固根深蒂也； 真息往来，循环不尽也。 如此然后“离气”乃“纳荣卫”，即前述之木液，自舌以下重楼，归营卫，以养身，道家谓之“玉液炼形”也。 “坎乃不用聪”者，离气返之于坤，则坎阳上还于乾，金足，坎自不漏矣。 单举坎言，另有深义，后于工夫中详之。
chunks.translated_text:
The steaming warmth reaches the four limbs, and the complexion becomes joyful and radiant. For this single spark of true yang is born within emptiness—precisely the image of "one yang returning" beneath the heavy yin. Thus Laozi says, "Stillness is called returning to destiny."

At the yang’s first return, it congeals within the Mysterious Aperture, which is none other than the Yellow Center. From the Yellow Center, it inwardly pervades the entire body. Though its numinous root remains within the Mysterious Aperture, its qi already fills the four limbs, penetrating above and below, warming the skin, and moistening it. As the *Clarifying the Obscure in the Kinship of the Three* states: "Nurture the child-pearl, neither forgetting nor aiding. Over time, spirit and clarity arise of themselves, gradually permeating all directions. The nine orifices, hundred vessels, three hundred sixty bones and joints, and eighty-four thousand pores of the body all become unobstructed, naturally luminous, moist, and harmonious—stimulated, they respond and penetrate." The phrase "beauty lies within" refers to the intercourse of yin and yang, which still occurs within the Mysterious Aperture. This is the meaning behind *Journey to the West*’s Sun Wukong entering the Water Curtain Cave and being named "Handsome Monkey King." The monkey represents *shen* (申), and within the character *shen* lies the center of the center—an exquisitely crafted symbol. This center is the natural endowment of heaven and earth, yet few in the world awaken to its emptiness.

The lines "First rectify, then cultivate; establish the stem before grasping the branch" clarify the necessity of nurturing and the gradual nature of practice. For the cultivator, thoughts must be upright—only the thought of no-thought is true thought, capable of engendering transformation. Otherwise, clinging to existence or nonexistence alike will fail to accord with the matter. Thus it is said: "First rectify, then cultivate; establish the stem before grasping the branch. The One veils and conceals—none in the world know it." The One, as the scriptures say, is "attaining the One, and all affairs are complete." The One is the single qi of the Supreme Ultimate. Independent and spirit-like, it exists before the division of yin and yang, thus able to generate the myriad things, to be spirit-like and transformative. In humans, it is the primordial nature of the *Qian* origin, the precelestial original spirit. Alas, people invariably obscure it with the acquired spirit, unaware of its existence and thus seeking it, drifting ever farther from the Dao.

From the perspective of destiny: when the single qi of the Supreme Ultimate has not yet divided into yin and yang, it is the precelestial true yang, the root of life for the myriad things. Humans receive it to form their bodies, hence it is called the "treasure of destiny." After the body is broken, it sinks into the Gate of Destiny, descending into the Yin Heel vessel, obscure and difficult to perceive. Though used daily, its calamities go unnoticed. Nature and destiny are in truth one thing. At the moment of receiving qi, nature and destiny are undivided; once divided, obscuration follows. People use what follows naturally and forget their origin. The *Song of Tapping the Trigrams* says, "Whispered close to the ear, the wondrous secret—ascend to Penglai’s first peak," referring to the primordial qi sunken in the *Kan* palace, which the cultivator must draw upward to the *Li* palace. "Whispered close to the ear" means one must abandon the cleverness of ears and eyes, withdraw vision and return hearing, seal the mouth and close the orifices. *Kan* is the ear, *Dui* is the mouth; speech issues from the mouth, sound enters the ear, and mouth and ear communicate through the single aperture of emptiness. By preserving nonbeing and guarding being, one draws forth true yang from the Great Abyss and returns it to Penglai Peak, concealing it within the ear.

In *Journey to the West*, Sun Wukong obtains the golden-hooped staff from beneath the Iron Plate Bridge, entering the Dragon Palace of the Eastern Sea to retrieve it from the sea’s treasury. The ones who inspired this were the Four Marshal Generals: the Red-Buttocked Horse Monkey and the Long-Armed Ape Monkey. The Crystal Palace symbolizes the Yin Heel cavity; the red buttocks represent the *Xun* trigram between the thighs, and the long arms signify the *Gen* trigram of the two hands holding the Gate. The golden-hooped staff symbolizes the primordial qi, able to grow vast or shrink small, to support heaven and stand upon earth, and to follow the heart’s desire. When transformed into something minute, like an embroidery needle, and concealed within the ear, it is because the Gate of Destiny and the ear both belong to the *Kan* trigram, and the primordial qi naturally flows between them. The analogy is exquisitely crafted and worth contemplating.

The *Kinship of the Three* further states: "The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—close and seal, do not let them open and communicate." This is the meaning of withdrawing vision and returning hearing. "The true person lurks in the deep abyss, floating and roaming while guarding the compass’s center"—the compass’s center is the single aperture of emptiness. "Floating and roaming" refers to the firing times of neither forgetting nor aiding. The "three treasures" are the three luminants mentioned earlier. "Luminants" describes them from the perspective of concentrated spirit; "treasures" describes them as essence, qi, and spirit. "Turning and bending to see and hear" means focusing vision and hearing inward. "Bending" refers to partiality, through which one may advance to utmost sincerity. "Opening and closing all accord as one" means that with each inhalation and exhalation, yin contracts and yang expands, neither hurried nor delayed, matching their rhythms. From this line, one may understand that the "mouth" does not refer to the mouth of speech.

This is the foremost requirement, hence it is said: "It is the pivot and linchpin of the self, inexhaustible in movement and stillness"—that is, unbroken and continuous, deeply rooted and firmly established. The true breath comes and goes in endless circulation. Only then does the *Li* qi "absorb the constructive and defensive," referring to the aforementioned wood fluid, which from beneath the tongue descends the Tower of Nourishment to return to the constructive and defensive, nourishing the body. Daoists call this "refining the form with jade liquid." "The *Kan* no longer uses its hearing" means that when the *Li* qi returns to *Kun*, the *Kan* yang ascends back to *Qian*, the metal is sufficient, and *Kan* naturally ceases to leak. Mentioning *Kan* alone carries deeper meaning, to be detailed later in the practice.

chunks.original_text: 兑合不谈、希言以顺鸿蒙之象，使神气不外散也。 “合”字双关，非闭口已也。 “三者既关键”，三者即上举之耳、目、口、也。 “缓体处空房”，亦系三光陆沉之义。 “委志归虚无，无念以为常”者，即至诚专密，安静虚无之义。 既曰“委志”，即见不是顽空，顽空不是委志。 盖用一“志”字，即是空而不空，以真意内守也。 “心专不纵横”者，必须不越方寸，十字为一直一横，中心即是交点，若纵横，即越过此窍矣。 “寝寐神相抱”，即以神抱气，绵绵不绝也； “觉悟候存亡”者，即觉知“活子时”、“活午时”也，时至神知也。 因而颜色浸润，骨节坚强，身上众阴退尽，阳气来复。 “修之不辍休，庶炁云雨行。 ”阳气来在身，犹若云行，凉液下降，霈若雨施。 既如春泽，又象冰解，自上流下，自下逆上，脑与涌泉之间，周而复始。 其在无极洞中，大小虚空内，往来周流者，因后天形身，骨节闭塞，唯此虚空一穴，脉脉相通。 虽在外往来，而与周身之八脉九经，处处贯通者也。 张紫阳真人《八脉经》曰：“阴跷一穴，人身之八脉九经，皆环拱之。 阴跷一动，而八脉九经皆动。 ”虚空一穴，与八脉九经流通，职是故也。 此二章词义略同，但前系专言炼己，此则性命工夫，火候景象，无不备具，即此已将修真之要义泄尽矣。 丹经常言：“借假修真。 ”夫借假修真者，借假我以修真我之谓也。 色身为假我，法身为真我，此自身言之也;元神为真我,识神为假我,此自心言之也;妄意为假我,真意为真我,此自意言之也。 总之一真而无不真，一假而靡不假，后天之精、气、神皆假也，惟先天之元精、元气、元神，乃谓之真。 三者返原，谓之全真。 然以后天破体之人，三者皆假，今欲修之，究从何处招来“全真”以易假乎？ 盖真我即为法身，法身未成，真我未见以前，先不管真我、假我，真假皆我也。 即由假我，以招真我，道书谓之“即假修真”。 去其假者，而真面目自露矣。 如识神本假，招真我即从识神招之。 下手之初，仍借识神用工，至诚专密，正心诚意，将假我之六识，并为一识，佛经谓：“归并三心，灭除四相。 ”三心者，过去、未来、现在也； 归并三心，即除去过去、未来之心，而归于现在一心。 《易·艮卦》曰“君子思不出其位”，即物来顺应之现在心也。 “四相”，即人、我、众生、寿者，《金刚经》言之详矣。 将六合一，守定此一，再将所守之一，归于虚空，而元神出矣。 惟下手工夫，太空亦非所宜，修丹先宜用有，陆仙潜虚之说也。 入室之初，不能纯然清净无为者，因无为是“慎独”工夫。 身无为，而心不能清净，究有何用！ 先须有诚意，方能得真清净； 真清净，则不无为而自无为矣。 “真意”即诚意也，六识并入专一之意，此意若有若无，若存若忘，内念不起，外念不入，炼之既熟，心中自然清净，而意乃诚矣。 是时心中混混沌沌，不识不知，色、声、香、味、触、法，皆不能入，而虚空之中，恍惚有一点孤明历历之意在，又实无所觉知，如赤子之一任天真，非有想，非无想也：儒谓“诚意”，道谓“真意”，佛谓“正觉”。 是时，此真意复到混沌之时，而元神出矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Dui* union refrains from speech, uttering few words to accord with the primordial chaos, preventing the spirit and qi from scattering outward. The word "union" has a double meaning—it is not merely closing the mouth. "The three are thus interlinked": these three refer to the aforementioned ears, eyes, and mouth. "Relax the body in an empty chamber" also signifies the submersion of the three luminaries. "Entrust the will to emptiness and non-thought as the constant" means maintaining utmost sincerity, profound stillness, and emptiness. Since it is called "entrusting the will," it is evident this is not dull emptiness—dull emptiness is not the entrusting of the will. The use of the word "will" signifies emptiness that is not empty, for the true intention is inwardly guarded. "The mind is focused, neither scattered nor straying" requires not overstepping the square inch—ten characters form a vertical and a horizontal line, their intersection being the center; if one strays beyond, they have already passed this aperture. "In sleep, spirit and qi embrace" means the spirit embraces the qi in unbroken continuity. "Upon waking, await the presence or absence" refers to recognizing the "living midnight" and "living noon"—when the time arrives, the spirit knows. Thereupon, the complexion becomes radiant, the bones and joints grow firm, all yin in the body retreats, and yang qi returns. "Practice without ceasing, and the qi will move like clouds and rain." When yang qi arises in the body, it flows like clouds; when cool fluid descends, it showers like rain. Like spring’s moisture or melting ice, it flows downward from above and ascends from below, circulating endlessly between the brain and the bubbling spring. Within the boundless cavern of the Wuji, in the vast and small voids, it moves and flows ceaselessly. Due to the blockages in the postnatal physical form and its bones and joints, only this single void aperture remains interconnected. Though it moves externally, it is everywhere linked with the eight vessels and nine meridians of the entire body.

Master Zhang Ziyang’s *Treatise on the Eight Vessels* states: "The Yin Qiao vessel is a single aperture around which the eight vessels and nine meridians of the human body all revolve. When the Yin Qiao moves, all eight vessels and nine meridians move with it." The void aperture communicates with the eight vessels and nine meridians for this very reason. These two chapters share similar meanings, but the former focuses solely on refining the self, while this one encompasses both nature and life, the firing times, and all phenomena—here, the essential principles of cultivation are fully revealed.

The alchemical classics often say: "Borrow the false to cultivate the true." Borrowing the false to cultivate the true means using the false self to refine the true self. The physical body is the false self, while the Dharma body is the true self—this is spoken from the perspective of the body. The original spirit is the true self, while the acquired spirit is the false self—this is spoken from the perspective of the mind. The deluded intention is the false self, while the true intention is the true self—this is spoken from the perspective of intention. In sum, one truth encompasses all truth, and one falsity pervades all falsity. The postnatal essence, qi, and spirit are all false; only the prenatal original essence, original qi, and original spirit are called true. When these three return to their origin, it is called "perfect truth."

Yet for those whose bodies are broken by the postnatal, all three are false. Now, in seeking to cultivate them, from where can one summon "perfect truth" to replace the false? The true self is the Dharma body; before the Dharma body is formed and the true self appears, one should not concern themselves with true or false selves—both true and false are the self. It is by means of the false self that the true self is summoned, which the Daoist texts call "cultivating the true through the false." By removing the false, the true countenance naturally emerges. For instance, the acquired spirit is false; to summon the true self, one begins with the acquired spirit. At the outset, one still relies on the acquired spirit to practice, with utmost sincerity, focusing the mind and rectifying intention, merging the six senses of the false self into one. The Buddhist scriptures speak of "unifying the three minds and eliminating the four marks." The three minds are the past, future, and present; unifying the three minds means removing the minds of the past and future and returning to the single mind of the present. The *Book of Changes*’ *Gen* hexagram says, "The noble person’s thoughts do not go beyond their position"—this is the present mind that responds to things as they come. The "four marks" are the self, others, sentient beings, and lifespan, as explained in detail in the *Diamond Sutra*. Unify the six into one, and firmly guard this one. Then, return this guarded one to emptiness, and the original spirit will emerge.

However, at the beginning of practice, the great emptiness is not yet suitable. In cultivating the elixir, one must first employ existence—this is the teaching of the "land immortals who dwell in the void." At the start of entering the chamber, one cannot yet achieve pure stillness and non-action, for non-action is the work of "vigilance in solitude." If the body is inactive while the mind remains unsettled, what use is it? First, one must have sincere intention to attain true stillness; with true stillness, one naturally achieves non-action without striving for it. "True intention" is sincere intention—the six senses merge into this single, focused intention, which is neither present nor absent, neither held nor forgotten. Inner thoughts do not arise, and outer thoughts do not enter. With sufficient refinement, the mind naturally becomes still, and the intention becomes sincere. At this time, the mind is in a state of primordial chaos, unaware and unknowing. Sights, sounds, scents, tastes, touches, and phenomena cannot enter, and within the emptiness, there vaguely appears a solitary, luminous point of awareness—yet in truth, there is nothing perceived. Like an infant yielding to natural innocence, it is neither thought nor non-thought. The Confucians call this "sincere intention," the Daoists call it "true intention," and the Buddhists call it "right awakening." At this moment, when the true intention returns to the state of chaos, the original spirit emerges.
chunks.overlap_context: referring to the aforementioned wood fluid, which from beneath the tongue descends the Tower of Nourishment to return to the constructive and defensive, nourishing the body. Daoists call this "refining the form with jade liquid." "The *Kan* no longer uses its hearing" means that when the *Li* qi returns to *Kun*, the *Kan* yang ascends back to *Qian*, the metal is sufficient, and *Kan* naturally ceases to leak. Mentioning *Kan* alone carries deeper meaning, to be detailed later in the practice.

chunks.original_text: 修道者，多易着有着无，若欲不着，其间有甚？ 此宜体会者也。 请自试验之，即“坐垂温”是也。 在一念不起，一意不散时，若工夫做得合法，玄窍处自有温温然一团无形之炁。 此炁似气非气，实神、气凝合之象，真意内蕴，乃有此景。 此温气不易保留，心一动即散矣。 有此微温之鼎，药物亦即此也。 若无此，即为“煮空为铛，静坐孤阴”矣。 《契》喻之春泽解冰，皆有“温”字在内，取温煦、融和之意也。 火怕炎，水怕寒，发热即炎，无温即寒，皆非法也。 惟温温，方得火候之正。 阳精既生，铅鼎既立，然后识神乃泯，元神乃凝。 《契》谓“凝神成躯”，即凝元神而成法身也。 盖元神者，法身之主也； 识神者，色身之主也：皆不离于我身，而我则有真我、假我之别。 真者，本无生灭； 假者，用尽则死。 胎儿在腹，元神凝为◎象，此即胎儿之法身也。 及有形之色身完成，而元神退位，识神来附之矣。 成胎之初，先有胎原，胎原者何？ 即性命藏于内，而精血包于外之◎也。 内虚者，法身之原； 外实者，色身之原也。 即男女交媾后，过七天，腹下有如黄豆大之一物，至静时便能跳动，下至子宫，上冲心府者是也。 有此乃娠，凡惯娠之妇人，皆知之。 胎原在腹中，本随时转动，而人在动时，因识神用事，故不之觉。 到静时神光内照，即觉之矣。 七日即一阳来复之时也，《旧约》上帝七日而造成世界，亦取七日来复之意。 修道者，亦须修到有此。 名曰“丹原”，亦谓“丹头”，其象与胎原无异也。 丹原即内玄关，玄关有内外上下之分，后当详细述之。 胎原在母腹中，时时跃跳，而丹原初成，亦上冲心府，下至命门，其象正同，故谓之结胎也。 胎原渐积，而生经络、脏腑、骨节、皮肉，以成形身。 其所以长成有形之体，则由神气运用于内而精血发舒于外。 七月胎成之后，神气在无形中，仍结一团，住于胎儿之脐下，跃如转轮。 故母之呼吸，能由脐带通入，亦成一呼一吸，轮转无一息住，呼吸亦无一息停，故谓之“胎息”。 胎息由脐下以上通泥丸，下至涌泉，周身毛孔，无不熏蒸，此胎儿之所以时时盗天地之元气，以成人也。 修士亦必修到胎息，心息相依，行则同行，住则同住，而凝和为真金鼎，廖蟾辉曰“前对脐轮后对肾，中间有个真金鼎”、李涵虚曰“止则止于肾堂之前，脐轮之后，维系乎规矩之中”是也。 佛经曰“法轮常转”，亦指此言。 再由胎息进为真息，则六脉已停，气归根，周身毛孔自然呼吸，不由口鼻出入，置鸿毛于鼻端，皆不能动。 而一团先天祖炁，在无形中往来升降，佛经曰“转大法轮”、白玉蟾曰“自在河车几百遭”是也。 盖后天破体之人，呼吸之气，仅至“中脘”，不能息息达于脐下； 真人之息，息息归根，深达于踵，由任、督二脉升降，而散之八脉九经，《庄子》曰“真人之息以踵，常人之息以喉”（见《庄子·大宗师》）是也。 俗语之“立定脚跟”、“脚踏实地”、“真履实践”皆是也。 故修道自《履》卦入手，孔子曰：“履，德之基也。 ”（见《易·系辞下》）德者，得也，得理炁之正者也。 天以生生不已为德，而生生不已，由浩然之气流行； 人以五常四维为德，而四维五常，亦由浩然之气所生。
chunks.translated_text:
The practitioner of the Dao often becomes attached to either existence or non-existence—how, then, may one avoid such attachment? This is what must be deeply realized. Let us test this through practice, as in "sitting with gentle warmth." When not a single thought arises and not a single intention scatters, if the work is done correctly, within the mysterious aperture there naturally arises a formless mass of qi, warm and subtle. This qi is like breath yet not breath, truly the coalescence of spirit and qi, with true intention inwardly enfolded—this is the scene that appears. This warmth is not easily retained; the moment the mind stirs, it dissipates. With this subtle warmth as the crucible, the medicinal substance is precisely this. Without it, one is but "boiling emptiness in a cauldron," a state of "solitary yin in silent sitting."

The *Canticle* compares this to spring thaw melting ice, both containing the character for "warmth," drawing on the meaning of gentle warmth and harmonious fusion. Fire fears scorching, water fears freezing; overheating is scorching, lack of warmth is cold—neither is proper. Only with gentle warmth is the firing process correct. Once yang essence is born and the lead crucible established, the consciousness of perception dissolves, and the primordial spirit congeals. The *Canticle* speaks of "congealing spirit into form," which is the congealing of the primordial spirit to form the dharmakāya. For the primordial spirit is the master of the dharmakāya, just as the consciousness of perception is the master of the physical body—both are not apart from this self, yet the self is divided into true and false. The true self is fundamentally without birth or death; the false self perishes when its use is exhausted.

When a fetus is in the womb, the primordial spirit congeals into a spherical form—this is the fetus’s dharmakāya. Once the physical body is fully formed, the primordial spirit retreats, and the consciousness of perception attaches to it. At the beginning of fetal formation, there first exists the fetal origin—what is this? It is the nature and life stored within, enveloped by essence and blood in a spherical form. The inner emptiness is the origin of the dharmakāya; the outer solidity is the origin of the physical body. After a man and woman unite, after seven days, a pea-sized object appears below the navel, which, in stillness, can be felt to pulse, descending to the womb and ascending to the heart-mind—this is it. With this, conception occurs, and women accustomed to pregnancy know this well.

The fetal origin in the womb naturally moves at all times, but when a person is active, the consciousness of perception dominates, so it is not felt. In stillness, when the spirit’s light turns inward, it is perceived. The seventh day is the time of the first yang’s return; the Old Testament’s God creating the world in seven days also draws on the meaning of the seventh day’s return. The practitioner of the Dao must also cultivate until this appears—it is called the "elixir origin" or "elixir head," its form no different from the fetal origin. The elixir origin is the inner mysterious pass. The mysterious pass has inner and outer, upper and lower divisions, which will be detailed later.

The fetal origin in the mother’s womb constantly leaps and pulses, and when the elixir origin first forms, it also ascends to the heart-mind and descends to the Gate of Life—its form is identical, hence it is called "structuring the embryo." As the fetal origin gradually accumulates, it generates channels, viscera, bones, joints, skin, and flesh, forming the physical body. The reason the physical form grows is that spirit and qi operate within while essence and blood expand without.

After seven months, when the fetus is fully formed, spirit and qi, though formless, still coalesce into a mass below the fetus’s navel, pulsing like a turning wheel. Thus, the mother’s breath can pass through the umbilical cord, forming an inhalation and exhalation that turns without a single moment’s pause, nor does the breath ever cease—this is called "fetal breathing." Fetal breathing, from below the navel, ascends to connect with the Mud Pill Palace and descends to the Bubbling Spring, permeating every pore of the body. This is how the fetus constantly steals the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth to become human.

The cultivator must also refine their practice to achieve fetal breathing, where mind and breath depend on each other, moving together when in motion and resting together when at rest, congealing into the true golden crucible. As Liao Chanhui said, "In front, it faces the navel wheel; behind, it faces the kidneys—between them lies the true golden crucible." Li Hanxu said, "When stopping, it stops before the kidney hall and behind the navel wheel, bound within the compass and square." The Buddhist scriptures speak of the "Dharma Wheel constantly turning," referring to this.

Advancing further from fetal breathing to true breathing, the six pulses cease, qi returns to its root, and the entire body’s pores naturally breathe, no longer through the mouth or nose—placing a goose feather at the nostrils, it will not stir. A mass of precelestial ancestral qi moves invisibly in ascent and descent. The Buddhist scriptures speak of "turning the great Dharma Wheel," and Bai Yuchan said, "The spontaneous river chariot makes hundreds of circuits."

For those whose bodies have been broken by the postnatal, the breath only reaches the "Central Cavity" and cannot, with every breath, reach below the navel. The breath of the perfected person returns to its root with every breath, deeply reaching the heels, ascending and descending through the Conception and Governor Vessels, then dispersing through the eight extraordinary vessels and nine meridians. As *Zhuangzi* said, "The breath of the perfected person reaches the heels; the breath of ordinary people reaches the throat" (*Zhuangzi·Great Master*). Common sayings like "standing firm," "feet planted on solid ground," and "true practice and realization" all refer to this.

Thus, the practice of the Dao begins with the *Lǚ* hexagram. Confucius said, "*Lǚ* is the foundation of virtue" (*Book of Changes·Appended Judgments*). Virtue is attainment—attaining the correctness of principle and qi. Heaven’s virtue is ceaseless generation, and ceaseless generation arises from the flowing of the vast qi. Human virtue lies in the Five Constants and Four Virtues, and the Four Virtues and Five Constants are also born of the vast qi.

chunks.original_text: 《易》谓； “大人与天地合其德。 ”〈见《易·乾文言》〉即与天地阴阳之正气相合耳。 藉假修真，即于色身中提出法身。 佛书曰“去矿留金”，道书曰“淘沙见金”，杂质去则纯金出之意也。 假者如矿、如沙，去之而真金自见。 丹书比元神为“丹砂”，又比为“汞”，又为“朱汞”，生于震木之中。 又谓之青龙之玄气属木，离火中有此木液为汞，因识神为杂质，如矿如沙，必从中提出木液，方为真汞。 夫火本木生，何必火中出木？ 因识神而蔽之，识神如火，火盛而木焚，火熄则木全现。 返之而由火中出木，此中有工夫法门也。 朱汞即真汞，欲使鼎中生汞，必先池内入银（鼎是大、小虚空），《悟真篇》曰“金鼎欲留朱里汞，玉池先下水中银”是也。 其法先将水银下去，而朱汞即能取出矣。 此比喻甚妙，汞即朱汞，砂从水银中来，砂无水银，本一矿之物，有水银方可提出朱砂，朱砂亦炼水银。 其意必先将识神归一，而入鼎中，然后朱砂之元神乃出。 因识神附形而灵，今使之在虚空中，无所依附，即能转识成智，而元神复矣。 黄翼氏曾在滇桂服官，目见水银、朱砂互提锻炼之事，着有笔记甚确。 《悟真》此语，即“藉假修真”之事也。 元神、识神及意念等之分别变化，兹特详述如下：最初为无极，无极而太极，太极本无一物，而有动意； 将动未动，即仍虚空也。 太极动而生阳，图内之一点·，即先天理炁也，至动极而理炁充满太极。 动极又须静，静而一生二，为有形之气，即阴气也。 阴阳各占一方，而为两仪，两仪又分为四象：上例第一图，为天地造化之理； 第二图，为人生造化之理，与天地大造正同； 第三图，空即无性，元必本真空也； 第四图，与情对照之性，则为性、命已分之两仪，即人之本性也。 所谓元性，乃性之体，天赋于人，在受炁成胎之时，尚未有形身也。 此处务要分明，不可含混，殆即“无名天地之始”，亦即道也； 第五图之元神，即本性之动时言，浑沦为意，明白为觉； 第六图之良知，则更进一步矣。 所谓觉者，尚未有知，由觉生知，因知而即能，是谓“良能”，知本于内,能则在外矣； 第七图之识神，为后天思虑之神，故有念与识之分：念起于内，自动也； 识成于外，被动也； 第八图之元情，为本来之情，非后天之七情，即性之感触于外，而动者也，亦要细绎其义。 性处内者也，情御外者也； 性主乎心，情在乎身。 性本寂然不动者，感而遂通，则发为灵觉； 情本随时驰动者，系于外物，则为识欲。 故佛经分别触、法：感于身者谓之触，属于情者也； 蕴于心者谓之法，属于性者也。 性体既空,则法变空； 性无可说，则法亦无可说，心即是法，法即是心，此所以谓之“心法”也。 人同此心，心同此理，故可以“心心相印，一言而妙悟菩提”。 若情则根于外缘，六尘触之而后发，有动于中，必摇其精，所谓“内随外漏”是也。 故情有内外，性无内外； 无内外者谓之“中”，有内外而发于天真者谓之“和”； 中者本也，和者末也，即末以返本，由本以齐末，是谓之“双修”之道也。 元情本善，因习而变； 性是空体，无所谓变。 不变者无生灭，而变者有生灭，其所以变，唯识成之，故又谓之“情识”也。

The *Book of Changes* states, "The great person’s virtue harmonizes with Heaven and Earth" (*Book of Changes·Words of the Text on Qian*). This means aligning with the correct *qi* of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang. Borrowing the false to cultivate the true is to refine the Dharma-body from within the physical form. Buddhist texts speak of "removing ore to leave gold," while Daoist texts say "washing away sand to reveal gold"—once impurities are removed, pure gold emerges. The false is like ore or sand; when it is discarded, true gold appears of itself.

Alchemical texts compare the original spirit (*yuanshen*) to "cinnabar," also likened to "mercury" or "vermilion mercury," born within the *Zhen* trigram’s wood. They further call it the mysterious *qi* of the Green Dragon, which belongs to wood, and state that within the *Li* trigram’s fire lies this "wood-fluid" as mercury. Because the consciousness-spirit (*shishen*) is an impurity—like ore or sand—one must extract the wood-fluid from within it to obtain true mercury. Now, fire is born of wood, so why must wood emerge from fire? Because the consciousness-spirit obscures it: the consciousness-spirit is like fire, and when fire rages, wood is consumed; when fire is extinguished, wood fully appears. Reversing this to draw wood from fire is the method and gateway of practice.

Vermilion mercury is true mercury. To generate mercury within the cauldron, one must first place silver in the pool (the cauldron being the great and small emptiness). As *Awakening to Reality* says, "To retain vermilion mercury in the golden cauldron, first place silver in the jade pool." The method is to first introduce mercury, and then vermilion mercury can be extracted. This metaphor is most ingenious: mercury is vermilion mercury, and cinnabar arises from mercury. Cinnabar and mercury are originally one substance from the same ore; only with mercury can cinnabar be extracted, and cinnabar can also be refined into mercury. The meaning is that one must first unify the consciousness-spirit and enter it into the cauldron, after which the original spirit—cinnabar—emerges. Since the consciousness-spirit is inherently numinous by clinging to form, when it is placed in emptiness with no attachment, it can transform consciousness into wisdom, and the original spirit is restored.

Mr. Huang Yi once served as an official in Yunnan and Guangxi, where he witnessed the mutual refinement of mercury and cinnabar, recording it in his notes with great accuracy. The passage in *Awakening to Reality* refers precisely to the practice of "borrowing the false to cultivate the true."

The distinctions and transformations among the original spirit, consciousness-spirit, and intention are detailed as follows:

Initially, there is Non-Ultimate (*wuji*); from Non-Ultimate arises the Supreme Ultimate (*taiji*). The Supreme Ultimate originally contains nothing, yet possesses the impulse to move. When it is about to move but has not yet moved, it remains emptiness. The Supreme Ultimate moves and generates yang; the single point within the diagram represents the primordial principle-*qi*. When movement reaches its extreme, principle-*qi* fills the Supreme Ultimate. At the extreme of movement, stillness must follow. Stillness generates the One, which divides into Two, becoming tangible *qi*—yin *qi*. Yin and yang each occupy a position, forming the Two Modes (*liangyi*). The Two Modes further divide into the Four Images.

The first diagram illustrates the principle of Heaven and Earth’s creation; the second, the principle of human generation, which is identical to the great creation of Heaven and Earth. The third diagram shows that emptiness is non-nature, and the original must be rooted in true emptiness. The fourth diagram, contrasting nature with emotion, represents the Two Modes of nature and life already divided—this is the original nature of humans.

The so-called original nature is the substance of nature, bestowed by Heaven upon humans at the moment of receiving *qi* and forming the embryo, before the physical body exists. This must be clearly distinguished, without ambiguity. It is "the nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth," which is also the Dao.

The fifth diagram’s original spirit refers to the movement of this original nature: when undifferentiated, it is intention; when clear, it is awareness. The sixth diagram’s innate knowledge represents a further progression. Awareness has not yet become knowledge; from awareness arises knowledge, and from knowledge comes ability—this is "innate ability." Knowledge originates within, while ability manifests externally.

The seventh diagram’s consciousness-spirit is the spirit of postnatal thought, hence its division into thought and consciousness: thought arises internally, self-generated; consciousness forms externally, reactive. The eighth diagram’s original emotion is the fundamental emotion, not the postnatal Seven Emotions. It is the movement of nature when stirred by external stimuli—this meaning must be carefully examined.

Nature resides within, while emotion governs externally. Nature rules the heart, and emotion resides in the body. Nature is fundamentally quiescent and unmoving; when stimulated, it responds and emits numinous awareness. Emotion is inherently restless and dynamic; when bound to external objects, it becomes discriminating desire.

Thus, Buddhist scriptures distinguish between contact (*sparśa*) and dharmas: what is felt through the body is called contact, belonging to emotion; what is contained in the mind is called dharmas, belonging to nature. When the substance of nature is empty, dharmas also become empty. When nature is beyond description, dharmas are also beyond description. The mind is dharmas, and dharmas are the mind—this is why it is called "mind-dharmas." All people share this mind, and this mind shares this principle, hence the saying, "Hearts resonate with hearts, and a single word awakens enlightenment."

Emotion, however, is rooted in external conditions; it arises only after contact with the Six Dusts. When stirred within, it must disturb one’s essence—this is what is meant by "internal leakage following external dissipation." Thus, emotion has internal and external aspects, while nature has no internal or external. That which has no internal or external is called the "Center"; that which has internal and external yet arises from innate truth is called "Harmony." The Center is the root, and Harmony is the branch. Returning the branch to the root and aligning the root with the branch is the path of "dual cultivation."

Original emotion is fundamentally good but changes through habituation. Nature is an empty substance, without so-called change. The unchanging is without birth or destruction, while the changing is subject to birth and destruction. What causes change is solely the consciousness, hence it is also called "emotion-consciousness."

Thus, the practice of the Dao begins with the *Lǚ* hexagram. Confucius said, "*Lǚ* is the foundation of virtue" (*Book of Changes·Appended Judgments*). Virtue is attainment—attaining the correctness of principle and qi. Heaven’s virtue is ceaseless generation, and ceaseless generation arises from the flowing of the vast qi. Human virtue lies in the Five Constants and Four Virtues, and the Four Virtues and Five Constants are also born of the vast qi.

chunks.original_text: 意者本心将动，似乎有一点动机，而不明白，即为真意是也，修道者须修此真意。 觉则比意稍进，动而生明矣； 觉与意之不同，即在明辨与浑沦之间。 一似空非空，一即色即空，至良知由觉而生，混然天理之正，随天而发，有知见而无是非心，无好恶心，进而为良能。 良知、良能一也，即知即行，无转变心，行而即空，所谓“物来顺应”是也。 良知即“乾以易知”，良能即“坤以简能”。 大道简易，从良知、良能而来，即知即行，即行即空，即大道也。 又知、能须合一，不合一即非良知、良能，此中不容转念也。 刘悟元注《阴符经》，名曰“灵知”、“真知”。 灵知即明觉，真知即真意，由意生志及真意。 一点真意，纯一不变，即志也； 不即不离，即诚也； 亦不转念，亦不生思，持其混沦之态，即诚也。 志则较重矣。 盖动一意而不变，始终持之，是谓志，孟子曰“持其志，无暴其气”（见《孟子·公孙丑上》）是也。 若念则由识神而发，与意不同，意者将动未动，仍是混然； 念则明明白白，有事有物矣。 意一落实在，即念也，故念在道书上，为思虑之神：已往者为想，未来者为虑，现在者为思。 然念之中，只已往、未来，而无现在。 现在之思则含觉，不过较觉稍重耳，此谓之“正念”。 《易》曰“君子思不出其位”（见《易·艮象》），不出者，不涉于过去、未来也。 正念近道，故佛经谓“归并三心”，即将想、虑泯去，并现在一心，炼念者为此而已。 已往、未来、现在为三界，亦即三心，将往、来并入现在，则念转为觉矣。 念者有触即发，意者本心自动。 识念皆有触而来，识即知识也，是非好恶，皆由识生。 念尚未发于外，至识则完全露于外矣。 性系中各类，皆自动于中； 情系中各类，皆有触于外而生心。 外有所触，发现于内为念； 外有所触，仍现于外为识。 两者互相为用，而实不同，意一转即成念，觉一转即成识，善变为恶，空转为有，人生堕落，即坐此也。 试细别之： 意有称为“如意珠”者，言真意如珠，圆洁无比，转瞬即无。 而意转为念，念念相续不断，则假夺其真念，佛用“念珠”者，即取转妄念为“如意珠”也。 此念惟“慧剑”方能断之，所谓“慧剑”，即真意元神也。 元神中良知、良能、明觉等，皆统于慧根，即灵根也。 以此为剑，方能斩断邪念，盖惟真我方能去假我也。 智根由中阴来，中阴即魂，从无始劫来，不知作若干次之主人。 由太古历三代、汉、唐、六朝、五代、宋、元、明、清，不知几次，转而复生，故谓之“流浪生死”，如江中之浪，前浪推后浪，滚滚不休。 中阴带有智识，由宿生而来者，即“智根”也，如人有生时能忆前生之事，读书如已读，下笔如宿构，皆此智根之作用也。 慧根为天地之灵根，智根为历劫之灵根，又有业根，因有善恶之宿业故也。 修道者统曰“开智慧”，智、慧合而曰“通”，能知三界十方，过去未来者，赖此智、慧二根。 慧根亦即先天之灵机，夫能动曰“机”，故道书曰“机已将动”，曰“已有动机”。 未动时本虚空，机一动而生有，谓之曰“真空不碍妙有”； 机一息而归空，谓之“妙有不碍真空”。 修道者之“火候”，如“月之圆，存乎口诀；
chunks.translated_text:
Intention arises when the original heart is about to move, appearing as a faint impulse yet not fully manifest—this is true intention, which the cultivator of the Dao must refine. Awareness represents a slight advance beyond intention, where movement gives rise to clarity. The distinction between awareness and intention lies in the difference between discernment and undifferentiated wholeness. One is "seemingly empty yet not empty," while the other is "form that is simultaneously emptiness." From awareness arises innate knowledge, a spontaneous alignment with the correctness of Heavenly Principle, responding to Heaven without the mind of right and wrong, without the heart of preference or aversion. This further develops into innate capacity. Innate knowledge and innate capacity are one—knowing is acting, without a mind of transformation; acting is immediately emptying, which is what is meant by "responding naturally to things as they come."

Innate knowledge is "the Qian hexagram’s ease of knowing," while innate capacity is "the Kun hexagram’s simplicity of functioning." The Great Dao is simple and easy, arising from innate knowledge and capacity—knowing is acting, acting is emptying, and this is the Great Dao itself. Moreover, knowledge and capacity must be united; if they are not, they are not true innate knowledge or capacity. There is no room for a shifting thought in this. Liu Wuyuan’s commentary on the *Yinfu Jing* calls them "spiritual knowing" and "true knowing." Spiritual knowing is luminous awareness, while true knowing is true intention. From intention arises aspiration, and from true intention arises true aspiration.

A single point of true intention, pure and unchanging, is aspiration. Neither attached nor detached, it is sincerity; neither shifting in thought nor generating deliberation, maintaining its undifferentiated state—this is sincerity. Aspiration carries greater weight. For when one moves a single intention without wavering, holding to it from beginning to end, this is called aspiration. As Mencius said, "Hold fast to your aspiration and do not harm your qi" (*Mencius·Gongsun Chou I*).

Thought, however, arises from the consciousness-spirit and differs from intention. Intention is about to move yet has not moved, remaining undifferentiated; thought is clear and distinct, involving specific matters and objects. Once intention becomes fixed, it becomes thought. Thus, in Daoist texts, thought is the spirit of deliberation: the past is recollection, the future is anticipation, and the present is reflection. Yet within thought, there is only the past and future, not the present. Present reflection contains awareness, though slightly more substantial—this is called "right thought." The *Book of Changes* states, "The noble person’s thoughts do not go beyond their proper place" (*Yi·Gen Xiang*), meaning they do not extend into the past or future.

Right thought is close to the Dao, which is why Buddhist scriptures speak of "merging the three minds"—eliminating recollection and anticipation, uniting them into the present mind. This is the aim of refining thought. Past, future, and present constitute the three realms, also known as the three minds. Merging past and future into the present transforms thought into awareness.

Thought arises upon contact, while intention moves spontaneously from the original heart. Consciousness and thought both arise from contact; consciousness is knowledge, giving rise to right and wrong, preference and aversion. Thought has not yet manifested externally, but consciousness is fully revealed. Nature encompasses all that moves spontaneously within, while emotion encompasses all that arises from external contact, generating the heart-mind.

External contact manifesting internally is thought; external contact manifesting externally is consciousness. Though they interact, they are fundamentally different. Intention, when shifted, becomes thought; awareness, when shifted, becomes consciousness. Good turns to evil, emptiness to existence—humanity’s fall stems from this. Consider the distinctions carefully:

Intention is sometimes called the "wish-fulfilling pearl," for true intention is like a pearl—perfectly round and pure, vanishing in an instant. When intention turns into thought, thoughts follow one another endlessly, usurping the true thought. The Buddhist use of "prayer beads" aims to transform deluded thoughts into the "wish-fulfilling pearl." Only the "sword of wisdom" can sever such thoughts—the "sword of wisdom" being the original spirit of true intention.

Within the original spirit, innate knowledge, innate capacity, and luminous awareness are all governed by the root of wisdom, the spiritual root. Only this sword can sever wayward thoughts, for only the true self can dispel the false self. The root of intellect comes from the intermediate state (bardo), which is the soul, having served as master countless times since beginningless kalpas. From remote antiquity through the Three Dynasties, Han, Tang, Six Dynasties, Five Dynasties, Song, Yuan, Ming, and Qing—passing through countless rebirths—it is called "wandering in the cycle of birth and death," like waves in a river, each pushing the next, ceaselessly rolling.

The intermediate state carries knowledge from past lives, which is the "root of intellect." For example, someone who recalls past-life events at birth, or writes as if they had prepared beforehand, demonstrates the functioning of this intellectual root. The root of wisdom is the spiritual root of Heaven and Earth, while the root of intellect is the spiritual root of past kalpas. There is also the root of karma, arising from the good and evil of past actions.

Daoist cultivation is generally called "developing wisdom." When intellect and wisdom unite, it is called "penetration," enabling knowledge of the three realms and ten directions, past and future, through these two roots. The root of wisdom is also the primordial spiritual mechanism. What can move is called "mechanism," hence Daoist texts say, "the mechanism is about to move," or "there is already a moving mechanism."

Before movement, it is fundamentally empty; once the mechanism moves, existence arises—this is "true emptiness does not obstruct wondrous existence." When the mechanism ceases, it returns to emptiness—this is "wondrous existence does not obstruct true emptiness." The "fire timing" in Daoist cultivation is like "the moon’s fullness, dependent on oral transmission."

chunks.original_text: 时之子，妙在心传”，皆机也。 真意为生机，识神所生之念，曰“杀机”。 《阴符经》一“机”字，所谓“天地人皆有杀机”者，指顺行之造化也。 生、杀机即为意念之初动，“恩中有害”，真意转为念，念即害也； “害中有恩”，即念止而成意，意即恩也。 《悟真》曰“若会杀机明反覆，始知害里却生恩”。 二者互相辗转，意觉动而不知止，即转为念； 识念止，即意识止，即觉。 其消息甚微，念念相续，佛家谓之“烦恼”，《圆觉经》谓“烦恼即轮回种子”，若随顺流浪，即入轮回。 是、非，好、恶之心，统名之曰“挂碍”； 见物生心，即为挂碍，有此即有生死。 心中能无挂碍，方得清净。 二者为人生之业障，然阴阳对待，意觉念识，互相为用，烦恼止而为意，挂碍止而为觉，二者皆由空生。 无中生有，性中生意、生觉，情中生念、生识。 其不动者，一为真空，一为顽空； 顽空生念、识，真空生意、觉，此其别也。 佛家讲“化识为智”，又曰“转识成智”，《唯识论》讲之甚详。 识有八种，第七种“末那识”，由此识即到八识之元神，七识为“传送识”，传送即觉也。 转识成智之理，与道家无殊。 《金刚经》曰：“应无所住而生其心。 ”此心亦即真意； 又曰：“空四相、去三心。 ”仙佛两家，因心性用字不同，似觉微殊，其实一理也。 经曰“不可说”，又曰“凡所有相，皆是虚妄”、“离一切相，方见真心”。 又佛家所谓“阿耨多罗三藐三菩提”，即无上正等正觉，亦即慧也，元性之灵觉也。 然生机启于慧根，杀机启于智根，则为佛说所未详者。 即假修真工夫，须性命双修，有大根器者，尽修性功亦可，佛家谓“圆顿法”。 性命双修为“渐法”，其实顿、渐互为体用，渐修后亦须顿悟，方可贯澈。 顿悟者亦须渐修，方能圆满。 顿法者，不须修命功，一步返虚到底，完全以我之虚空，通天地之虚空，到修成时，自能千百亿万化身，性通而命在其中矣。 此须有大根器者，方可行之，故张紫阳真人教人顿、渐双修。 丹法有九种，最上一乘，为至真至妙之道，即现在所讲者是也。 双修大法，只此一乘，别无他法，从王重阳以后，阐发甚精。 从前道书皆假说，现方有直说者，即以太虚为鼎，太极为炉是也。 《参同契》曰“上德无为，不以察求； 下德为之，其用不休”者，即顿、渐之分也。 上德无为，下德有为； 上德专修性，下德性命双修。 柳华阳真人《慧命经》曰：“上德乃童真之体，当在‘五千四百生黄道’之一日，真阳充足之时，而下手修之，自能顿悟成道。 法用无为，而自无不为也； 下德者，已破体之人也，须用有为工夫。 上德为纯阳之体，无用筑基； 下德业已破体，真阳亏损，须先筑基。 ”“上德无为，不以察求”者，察即觉察，不必觉察火候，以觉合气，完全返虚而已足； “下德为之，其用不休”者，步步俱有火候，处处须用察求工夫。 《西游记》观世音菩萨，为灵明觉察之神，时时救难，即时时体察火候，不使火炎水寒，务求到温温程度，刻刻保存真意。 所谓“一画开天，刚合阴阳，火候微温”，即此是也。 《悟真篇》曰：“火生于木本藏烽，不为钻研莫强攻。 ”若将识神作元神用，不是陷于孤阳，即是落于寡阴，于身有害，故须谨之。
