Heaven and earth, by attaining this limitless truth and the primordial qi, can endure long; humans, by attaining this limitless truth and the primordial qi, can also achieve longevity and enduring vision. The reason people cannot endure long is that they lose the formless, scatter the bodiless, and cannot make the hundred bones and nine orifices coexist with the true body—hence they die.

chunks.original_text: 物中有六根、六尘，内而六根，外而六尘。 根尘相接之时，应即物付物，而不为所眩惑。 譬如见财物、女色等等，能处之有道，而不为所诱惑。 是即能保其元神、元气而不失，即是真常之道也。 不迷性自住，性住气自回。 不迷于物，性自能住。 性住天谷，而为天谷元神，自能“明心见性”矣。 元神既住，则真息自回。 “回”字两口，有口对口、窍对窍之意也。 性命二者，本不可分。 学者能炼性坚固，元神为其主宰而得自然神觉，则命功亦随性功而进步。 凡息亦为真息，而玄关成象矣。 盖元神与真息相依，神定气住，即息息归根。 《庄子》曰：“真人之息以踵，其息深深，若存若亡。 ”此即性住气回时之情状也。 气回丹自结，壶中配坎离。 性住气回，则一神一气，自结合而成丹。 盖元神、元气，真性、真息，相依相抱。 神驰外，气亦驰外； 性归根，气自归根，故曰“尽性以至于命”。 佛书专说性理而不至于命，及以性功既到，命功自随，为自然之结果，而可必得者也。 上两句及本句之三“自”字，即透此中消息之语，学者可以知所用力矣。 “壶中”即状如蓬壶之一窍，亦即丹鼎之意。 水火既济，坎离相配，此结丹之现象也。 既已性住气回，自然于鼎中结丹矣。 坎，月也； 离，日也，日月相配而成“丹”字也。 阴阳生反覆，普化一声雷。 配合坎离，即是取坎填离：取坎中之一阳，返之于离，而复其乾健之体； 降离中之一阴，还之于坎，以复其纯坤之象，此即阴阳反覆之事也。 修道作用，全在反覆阴阳。 人生自破体以后，阴日盛阳日衰，阳尽则死。 此即顺而行之，有生有死也。 修道者反之，自还虚、筑基、炼己，以至小周天、大周天，其作用全在采取空中之真阳，返还于吾身，以炼化吾身之浊阴，所谓“逆而修之，成仙成佛”是也。 故“反覆阴阳”一语，已将作丹之全体大用，包括无遗矣。 然欲行此道，其下手应候“地雷复”之时。 《易·复卦》之词曰：“复，其见天地之心乎！ ”当天心发现，活子时到，应聚火载金，驾动河车，以行周天。 由小周天至大周天，其道同也，必候“一阳来复”，子时到来，方可下手，做返还炼化之功。 吕祖曰：“地雷震动山头雨，待洗濯黄芽出土。 ”此时阳火阴符，周流上下，无中生有，由有返无，升降进退，而阴尽阳纯，化为一炁之阳气，此即黄芽出土时也。 学者得诀修之，则虽草野愚氓，亦可超凡入圣，脱胎而仙。 《易》曰“帝出乎《震》”，震木为东三之祖性，“先天而天弗违”，故曰“普化一声雷”也。 白云朝顶上，甘露洒须弥。 “白云朝顶上”者，大药成熟，一阳来复，阳气缘督上升，到于乾顶。 此即《悟真篇》所谓“依他坤位生成体，种在乾家交感宫”也； “甘露洒须弥”者，阳气到顶，一阴来媾，化为凉液，由顶下降，如一滴甘露，经重楼而归黄庭。 此为服食而得丹，大周天之事也。 自饮长生酒，逍遥谁得知！ 甘露入口，香味异常，服食得丹，而能长生久视，故曰“长生酒”也。 《悟真篇》曰“长男乍饮西方酒”，《无根树》曰“醍醐酒，返魂浆，起死回生是药王”，即此是也。 此为自酿自饮之长生酒，非能与他人共之者，“如人饮水，冷暖自知”也。
chunks.translated_text:
Within the realm of phenomena lie the six roots and six dusts—internally the six roots, externally the six dusts. When root and dust meet, one must respond by entrusting things to things themselves, without being deluded by them. For instance, when encountering wealth or feminine beauty, one must handle them with the Dao, without being seduced. This is how one preserves the original spirit and original qi without loss—this is the Dao of the true constant.

When not deluded by phenomena, the nature abides of itself; when the nature abides, qi returns of itself. Not being deluded by phenomena, the nature naturally abides. When the nature abides in the Heavenly Valley, it becomes the primordial spirit of the Heavenly Valley, and one can thereby "illumine the heart and see the nature." Once the primordial spirit abides, true breathing returns of itself. The character "return" (回) consists of two mouths, signifying mouth-to-mouth and aperture-to-aperture alignment.

Nature and life are originally inseparable. If the practitioner can cultivate nature to firmness, the primordial spirit becomes its sovereign and attains natural spiritual awareness, then the work of life will naturally advance alongside the work of nature. Ordinary breathing then becomes true breathing, and the Mysterious Pass takes form. For the primordial spirit and true breathing depend upon each other—when spirit settles, qi abides, and each breath returns to the root. As *Zhuangzi* says: "The true person breathes from the heels; their breath is deep and subtle, as if present, as if absent." This describes the state when nature abides and qi returns.

When qi returns, the elixir forms of itself; within the crucible, Kan and Li unite. When nature abides and qi returns, the one spirit and one qi naturally coalesce to form the elixir. For the primordial spirit and primordial qi, the true nature and true breathing, embrace and depend upon each other. When spirit scatters outward, qi also scatters outward; when nature returns to the root, qi naturally returns to the root—hence the saying, "exhausting nature to reach life." Buddhist texts focus solely on the principles of nature without addressing life, yet when the work of nature is accomplished, the work of life follows as a natural consequence, an inevitable attainment.

The three instances of "of itself" in the preceding and current lines reveal the subtle dynamics at play—practitioners may thus discern where to apply their effort. "Within the crucible" describes the aperture resembling Penglai’s gourd, which is also the meaning of the elixir furnace. With water and fire in harmony, Kan and Li unite—this is the manifestation of elixir formation. Once nature abides and qi returns, the elixir naturally forms within the furnace.

Kan is the moon; Li is the sun. Their union forms the character for "elixir" (丹). Yin and yang undergo reversal and transformation, universally transforming in a single thunderclap. The union of Kan and Li is the process of extracting from Kan to fill Li: taking the one yang within Kan and returning it to Li to restore its pure Qian vigor; descending the one yin within Li and returning it to Kan to restore its pure Kun image—this is the reversal of yin and yang.

The practice of the Dao lies entirely in the reversal of yin and yang. From birth after the breaking of the body, yin daily waxes while yang daily wanes, and when yang is exhausted, death follows. This is the natural course—life and death unfold in sequence. The Daoist practitioner reverses this process, from returning to emptiness and laying the foundation to refining the self, progressing through the Microcosmic and Macrocosmic Orbits. The entire practice consists of gathering the true yang from the void and returning it to the body to refine and transmute the body’s turbid yin—this is what is meant by "reversing the course to cultivate immortality and Buddhahood."

Thus, the phrase "reversal of yin and yang" encompasses the entire great function of elixir formation without omission. However, to embark on this path, one must await the moment of "earth thunder’s return." The *Yijing*’s *Fu* hexagram states: "Return—is this not the manifestation of Heaven and Earth’s heart?" When the heart of Heaven appears and the living midnight arrives, one should gather fire to carry metal, set the River Chariot in motion, and circulate the orbit. From the Microcosmic to the Macrocosmic Orbit, the principle is the same—one must await the "return of the one yang," the arrival of the midnight hour, before commencing the work of reversal and refinement.

As Ancestor Lü said: "When earth thunder shakes the mountain’s peak, rain awaits to wash the yellow sprout as it emerges from the soil." At this time, yang fire and yin tally circulate above and below, generating being from non-being, returning from being to non-being, ascending and descending, advancing and retreating, until yin is exhausted and yang is pure, transmuting into a single qi of yang. This is the moment when the yellow sprout emerges from the soil. If the practitioner obtains the method and cultivates accordingly, even a rustic fool may transcend the ordinary and enter sagehood, shedding the mortal coil to become an immortal.

The *Yijing* says: "The Supreme emerges from *Zhen*." *Zhen* Wood is the ancestral nature of the eastern trigram, "prior to Heaven yet Heaven does not oppose it"—hence the phrase "universally transforming in a single thunderclap."

White clouds ascend to the crown; sweet dew sprinkles Mount Sumeru. "White clouds ascend to the crown" describes the maturation of the great medicine, the return of the one yang, as yang qi ascends along the Governor Vessel to the Qian crown. This is what the *Awakening to Reality* means by "relying on Kun’s position to generate the body, planting it in Qian’s palace of mutual resonance." "Sweet dew sprinkles Mount Sumeru" describes yang qi reaching the crown, where the one yin arrives to mate, transmuting into a cool liquid that descends from the crown like a drop of sweet dew, passing through the multi-storied tower to return to the Yellow Court. This is the process of ingesting and obtaining the elixir—the work of the Macrocosmic Orbit.

One drinks the wine of immortality—who in their carefree wandering could know? The sweet dew enters the mouth with an extraordinary fragrance; by ingesting and obtaining the elixir, one attains longevity and enduring vision—hence it is called the "wine of immortality." As the *Awakening to Reality* says: "The eldest son suddenly drinks the wine of the west," and the *Rootless Tree* says: "The wine of ghee, the nectar of returning souls, is the Medicine King that revives the dead"—this is precisely it. This is the wine of immortality brewed and drunk by oneself, not to be shared with others—"like one who drinks water, knowing its warmth or coolness for oneself."

**The true constant must respond to things; in responding, one must not be deluded.**
This Dao is the "true constant." By nurturing the heart and nurturing qi, one attains the true constant and preserves the original spirit and original qi. Yet one must still respond to things—remaining impartial and magnanimous, responding to things as they come, aligning with their principles—this is "responding to things without delusion."

chunks.original_text: 甘露服下，遍体清凉，心中快乐，无可比拟，儒家谓“真乐”，颜子之“不改”者是也。 此乐只我自知，亦唯我本性虚明与太虚同体，逍遥自在，实有非语言可以形容者也。 静听无弦曲，潜通造化机。 此二句总结言之。 最初下手，自还虚始吹无孔之笛，听无弦之曲，而“性自住”，“气自回”，“丹自结”。 三“自”字，便是“潜通”。 末后“还虚”之一着，又以我之虚空，通天地之虚空，久久行持，自然粉碎虚空。 人但见我无为，而不知我已参赞天地之化育，故曰“潜通造化机”也。 都来二十句，端的上天梯。 此章仅仅二十句而已，依次说尽修道之功夫矣。 照此下功，则上天有梯，可循序而至也。 张紫阳真人人作《悟真篇》后，又作《金丹四百字》，以授白玉蟾。 盖知白玉蟾不能畅达《悟真篇》奥旨，致有“夜半风雷”之失。 《四百字》较为简易明了，即解释《悟真》之象者也。 自来注《四百字》，不下数十家，而以彭好古注为最佳。 闵一得选彭注后，又加释语，尢为明白，兹照此本直讲。 好在注释已极清楚，细玩其意，即可得之言外矣。 兹将张紫阳真人《金丹四百字》彭注、闵释，详载于后而述之： 真土擒真铅，真铅制真汞。 铅汞归真土，身心寂不动。 （彭注）人之初生，天一生坎水为肾，肾水沉重象铅。 肾生气，气中一点真一之精，是为真铅； 地二生离火为心，心火飞扬象汞。 心生液，液中一点正阳之气，是为真汞。 坎中有戊土，离中有己土。 水本阴，而阴中有真阳； 火本阳，而阳中有真阴：是为真土。 阴交于阳，阳交于阴，全凭真土。 真铅即身中之气，真汞即心中之神，真土即身中之意也。 诚能运吾之真意，使汞常迎铅，铅常制汞，铅汞归真土，则神气浑融，性情合一，而身心寂然不动矣。 虽曰不动，其实如如之中有了了，冥冥之中有昭昭。 妄心已除，而照心不昧； 肉身若死，而法身常生； 非坠顽空，而甘枯槁也。 （闵释）举意宅身以收心，即得五行攒簇，四象和合； 从此五气朝元，渐见三花聚顶。 何等直截，并不繁难，只是一个诚意，以先之耳。 按真土即真意也，亦即自然神觉也； 真铅者，先天真乙之炁； 真汞者，心中驰动之神。 以真意擒取先天真乙之炁，即以先天之气，制服飞扬之人心。 铅、汞皆归真土，三家相见于中宫，而身心寂然不动矣。 虚无生白雪，寂静发黄芽。 玉炉火温温,金鼎飞紫霞。 （彭注）虚无寂静，下手采药之功夫； 白雪黄芽，吾身药生之景象。 然以“白雪”归“虚无”，以“黄芽”归“寂静”，亦自有辩。 白雪自虚空而生，黄芽须火养而生，以火能生土也。 时当《姤卦》，天交于地，虚无则白雪自生； 时当《复卦》，地交于天，寂静则黄芽自发。 阴极而阳，则黄芽自地而长。 “玉炉”即黄庭，“火”即神，以神取气，火在玉炉之中，温温者行火之候。 “鼎”者乾位，神之本宫。 黑变红为紫，火飞上为霞，霞与火非二物也。 “玉炉火温温”，乾宫之神照入于坤宫之内。 至于鼎上飞紫霞，则神受乾火，发现于坤宫之表，有飞象矣。 《闵释》心宅身久，身得心治之初效也。 按白雪即玉液之根，黄芽即金液之本。 一由无中生有象，一由静极见动机。
chunks.translated_text:
When the sweet dew is ingested, a pervasive coolness suffuses the body, and joy fills the heart—joy beyond compare. The Confucians call this "true joy," as in Yanzi’s "unaltered" state. This joy is known only to oneself, for only one’s own inherently empty and luminous nature, one with the Great Void, can roam freely and at ease—truly beyond the reach of words to describe.

Silently listen to the stringless melody,
Stealthily penetrate the mechanism of creation.

These two lines summarize the whole. At the outset of practice, one begins by returning to emptiness, playing the holeless flute and hearing the stringless melody, so that "nature abides of itself," "qi returns of itself," and "the elixir coalesces of itself." The three "of itself"s are precisely the "stealthy penetration." In the final stage of "returning to emptiness," one’s own emptiness merges with the emptiness of heaven and earth. With prolonged practice, one naturally shatters the void. Others see only my non-action, unaware that I have already assisted in heaven and earth’s transformative nurturance—hence "stealthily penetrate the mechanism of creation."

All told, these twenty lines form the very ladder to heaven. Though this chapter comprises only twenty lines, it exhaustively describes the work of Daoist cultivation. Follow this practice, and the ladder to heaven stands ready, allowing one to ascend step by step.

After composing the *Awakening to Reality*, the Perfected Zhang Ziyang wrote the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* and transmitted it to Bai Yuchan. He knew that Bai Yuchan could not fully grasp the profound subtleties of the *Awakening to Reality*, leading to the error of "midnight wind and thunder." The *Four Hundred Words* is simpler and clearer, serving as an explication of the *Awakening*’s imagery. Countless commentaries on the *Four Hundred Words* exist, but Peng Haogu’s is the finest. Min Yide selected Peng’s commentary and added his own annotations, making it especially lucid. Since the annotations are already exceedingly clear, a careful study of their meaning will reveal what lies beyond words. Below, we present the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* by the Perfected Zhang Ziyang, with Peng’s commentary and Min’s annotations, and expound upon them:

True earth seizes true lead,
True lead restrains true mercury.
Lead and mercury return to true earth,
Body and mind still and unmoving.

*(Peng’s Commentary)*
At the beginning of human life, Heaven’s One generates Kan Water as the kidneys, and kidney water, heavy and dense, resembles lead. The kidneys generate qi, and within qi lies a single essence of True One—this is true lead. Earth’s Two generates Li Fire as the heart, and heart fire, volatile and soaring, resembles mercury. The heart generates fluid, and within fluid lies a single spark of right yang qi—this is true mercury. Within Kan resides Wu Earth, and within Li resides Ji Earth. Water is fundamentally yin, yet within yin lies true yang; fire is fundamentally yang, yet within yang lies true yin—these are true earth. Yin intermingles with yang, and yang with yin, all depending on true earth. True lead is the qi within the body, true mercury is the spirit within the heart, and true earth is the intent within the body. If one can mobilize one’s true intent to ensure mercury always welcomes lead and lead always restrains mercury, so that lead and mercury return to true earth, then spirit and qi merge, nature and emotions unite, and body and mind become still and unmoving. Though called unmoving, within this thusness there is clarity, and within this darkness there is illumination. Illusory thoughts are extinguished, yet the illuminating mind remains undimmed; the physical body seems dead, yet the Dharma-body endures—this is not a fall into inert emptiness or withered desiccation.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
By directing intent to dwell in the body and gather the mind, one achieves the clustering of the Five Phases and the harmony of the Four Images. From this, the Five Qi converge at the origin, and gradually the Three Flowers gather at the crown. How direct and unencumbered—it is simply a matter of sincerity leading the way. True earth is true intent, which is also the natural spiritual awareness; true lead is the precelestial True Yi’s qi; true mercury is the restless spirit within the heart. By using true intent to seize the precelestial True Yi’s qi, one employs precelestial qi to subdue the restless human mind. When lead and mercury both return to true earth, the Three Families meet at the Central Palace, and body and mind become still and unmoving.

From emptiness, white snow is born,
From stillness, the yellow sprout emerges.
The jade crucible’s fire glows gently,
The golden tripod emits purple radiance.

*(Peng’s Commentary)*
Emptiness and stillness are the initial efforts in gathering the medicine; white snow and the yellow sprout are the signs of the medicine’s arising within the body. Yet associating "white snow" with "emptiness" and the "yellow sprout" with "stillness" also has its distinctions. White snow arises from the void, while the yellow sprout requires the nurturing of fire, for fire can generate earth. When the time corresponds to the *Gou* hexagram, heaven conjoins with earth, and from emptiness, white snow naturally arises; when the time corresponds to the *Fu* hexagram, earth conjoins with heaven, and from stillness, the yellow sprout naturally emerges. When yin reaches its extreme, yang arises, and the yellow sprout grows from the earth. The "jade crucible" is the Yellow Court, and "fire" is spirit. Using spirit to gather qi, the fire resides within the jade crucible, and the gentle warmth is the sign of firing. The "tripod" is the Qian position, the original palace of spirit. Black transforming into red becomes purple, and fire ascending becomes radiance—radiance and fire are not two things. "The jade crucible’s fire glows gently" means the spirit of the Qian Palace illuminates within the Kun Palace. When the tripod emits purple radiance, the spirit, receiving the fire of Qian, manifests beyond the Kun Palace, revealing the image of ascent.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
The heart dwelling in the body for a long time marks the initial effect of the body being governed by the mind. White snow is the root of jade fluid, and the yellow sprout is the origin of golden fluid. One arises from nothingness into form, the other emerges from extreme stillness into movement.

As the *Awakening to Reality* says: "The eldest son suddenly drinks the wine of the west," and the *Rootless Tree* says: "The wine of ghee, the nectar of returning souls, is the Medicine King that revives the dead"—this is precisely it. This is the wine of immortality brewed and drunk by oneself, not to be shared with others—"like one who drinks water, knowing its warmth or coolness for oneself."

chunks.original_text: “玉炉”“金鼎”，便是白雪黄芽长生之处。 惟玉炉中有天然火候，温温营养，紫霞乃能飞入金鼎之中，即以神驭气而成道也。 真意不散，火自温温矣。 华池莲花开，神水金波静（一作净）。 夜深月正明，天地一轮镜。 （鼓注）紫阳《本序》云：“以铅作汞，名曰华池； 以汞入铅，名曰神水。 ”即此而观，华池为命蒂，神水为性根。 欲性命浑融，始以汞投铅，次以铅制汞。 坎宫真一之精，载正阳之炁而上升，气象似莲花之开矣； 离宫正阳之炁，，随真一之精而下降，安静似金波之净矣。 至时之将子，水清金白，而性命神气两相浑合矣，故曰“天地一轮镜”。 只在以性合命。 凝神入气穴是也。 昔人谓“炼丹无别法，但引神入华池，万事毕矣”，正是此意。 （闵释）心身合一，纯乎天理。 自然运行，乃得有下手之时也。 按“华池莲花开”，神入炁穴也； “神水金波静”，推性合情也。 佛典以莲花开，为慧光发现。 离火中有真水，是为神水，以喻真汞，亦即心也。 心地光明，则情识静伏，金波自静，金波以喻情识也。 “夜深月正明”，是性光显耀，心月圆明之象，夜半则外境清净之时也。 此时万景澄清，一轮独耀，炉火纯青，身心如如不动矣。 此章盖言炼己纯熟，性光发现之时也。 朱砂炼阳气，水银烹金精。 金精与阳气，朱砂而水银。 （彭注）朱砂是液中正阳之气，水银是水中真一之精。 补离宫之阴，液中采取真一之精。 “金精与阳气”，以阳火炼之，则如朱砂； 以阴符养之，则如水银，非二物也。 （闵释）得下手时，极炼极烹，仍以心治身，以身养心以待之，无别法也。 按，朱砂炼之，即是阳气； 水银烹之，是为金精。 阳气金精，即在朱砂水银之中，不经猛火烹炼，则其物不出。 此以喻元神与道心，即在识神人心之中。 能将识神人心去尽，即能返还元神道心，而得其真宰。 即朱砂水银，亦是一物，同出异名，合之为道。 盖言能保其元神，则道心自见。 《悟真篇》曰：“本是水银一味，周流历遍诸辰。 ”即是此意，其比喻甚妙而当也。 日魂玉兔脂，月魄金乌髓。 掇来归鼎内（一作中），化作一泓水。 （彭注）太阳木火为日魂，魂藏神，而阳中有阴，阴即月魄。 日非月无以生其光，故曰“玉兔脂”，脂从精也； 太阴金水为月魄，魄藏精，而阴中有阳，阳即日魂。 月非日无以成其体，故曰“金乌髓”，髓从神也。 犹朱砂是日中之精，中感月华而生真炁； 水银是月中之华，中感日精而生真铅。 大修行人，上士以神化气，以气化精； 中士以精留气，以气留神。 精神浑合，调和于宝鼎之中，则甘露自降，而为一泓水矣。 （闵释）交养融和，而身心始化也，夫然后将以观其窍。 按，真汞真铅，是为药物，藉以成丹者也。 而此药物，阴阳互藏：真铅，阳物也，是为日魂，而藏于水中，为坎之中爻； 真汞，阴也，是为月魄，而藏于火中，为离之中爻。 修道者，将此药物投入鼎内，四大熏蒸，阳气上升，到昆仑之颠，配合真阴，化而为液，仍归鼎中，是为还丹。 此章以明阴阳互藏，修道者应颠倒阴阳，使归鼎内也。 药物生玄窍，火候发阳炉。 龙虎交会时，宝鼎采玄珠。 （彭注）“玄窍”即玄牝，玄阳而牝阴，总谓之玄窍。
chunks.translated_text:
"The jade crucible" and "golden tripod" are the very places where white snow and yellow sprout attain longevity. Only within the jade crucible does the natural firing process occur—its gentle warmth nurturing until purple radiance ascends into the golden tripod, where spirit guides qi to accomplish the Dao. When true intent remains undispersed, the fire naturally glows gently.

The lotus of the Flowery Pond blooms,
The spirit-water’s golden waves grow still (or: pure).
Deep in the night when the moon shines bright,
Heaven and earth become a single mirror.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
Master Ziyang’s *Preface* states: "Using lead to refine mercury is called the Flowery Pond; infusing mercury into lead is called spirit-water." From this perspective, the Flowery Pond is the stem of life, while spirit-water is the root of nature. To merge nature and life, first cast mercury into lead, then use lead to govern mercury. The true essence of the Kan Palace, bearing the upright yang qi, ascends—its appearance like the blooming of a lotus. The upright yang qi of the Li Palace, following the true essence, descends—its tranquility like the stillness of golden waves. When the hour approaches midnight, water clears and metal whitens, and nature and life, spirit and qi, merge into one. Thus it is said, "Heaven and earth become a single mirror." This is simply the union of nature with life—concentrating spirit into the qi cavern.

The ancients said, "There is no other method in elixir refinement; merely guide spirit into the Flowery Pond, and all matters are complete." This is precisely the meaning.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
When heart and body unite, purely following Heaven’s principle, the natural workings begin, and the time to commence arrives. The line "The lotus of the Flowery Pond blooms" signifies spirit entering the qi cavern; "The spirit-water’s golden waves grow still" signifies extending nature to harmonize with emotion. Buddhist scriptures take the blooming of the lotus as the manifestation of wisdom-light. Within the fire of Li resides true water—this is spirit-water, an analogy for true mercury, which is also the heart. When the heart-ground is luminous, emotional consciousness quiets, and golden waves naturally still—golden waves being a metaphor for emotional consciousness. "Deep in the night when the moon shines bright" is the radiance of nature’s light, the image of the heart-moon’s full brilliance. Midnight is the time when external realms are most serene. At this moment, all scenes are clear, a single wheel shines alone, the furnace fire turns azure, and body and mind remain unmoving. This passage describes the time when inner cultivation matures and the light of nature manifests.

Cinnabar refines yang qi,
Quicksilver cooks metal essence.
Metal essence and yang qi—
Cinnabar and quicksilver.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
Cinnabar is the upright yang qi within liquid; quicksilver is the true essence within water. To replenish the yin of the Li Palace, extract the true essence from the liquid. "Metal essence and yang qi" when refined with yang fire become like cinnabar; when nurtured with yin tally, they become like quicksilver—yet they are not two things.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
When the time to commence arrives, refine and cook intensely, yet still govern the body with the heart and nurture the heart with the body—there is no other method. Cinnabar, when refined, is yang qi; quicksilver, when cooked, is metal essence. Yang qi and metal essence reside within cinnabar and quicksilver; without fierce firing and cooking, their true nature does not emerge. This is an analogy for original spirit and the heart of Dao, which reside within the spirit of consciousness and the human heart. By eliminating the spirit of consciousness and the human heart, one can return to the original spirit and the heart of Dao, attaining true mastery. Even cinnabar and quicksilver are one thing—different names for the same essence, united to form the Dao. This speaks of preserving the original spirit, whereby the heart of Dao naturally appears. As the *Wuzhen Pian* says: "It is originally a single taste of quicksilver, circulating through all the celestial stems." This is the meaning, and the analogy is most apt and fitting.

The sun’s soul is the jade hare’s marrow,
The moon’s spirit is the golden crow’s pith.
Gather them into the tripod’s interior,
And they transform into a pool of water.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
The sun’s wood-fire is the sun’s soul, which stores spirit, and within yang resides yin—yin being the moon’s spirit. The sun cannot generate its light without the moon, hence "the jade hare’s marrow," marrow deriving from essence. The moon’s metal-water is the moon’s spirit, which stores essence, and within yin resides yang—yang being the sun’s soul. The moon cannot complete its form without the sun, hence "the golden crow’s pith," pith deriving from spirit. Just as cinnabar is the essence within the sun, which, when touched by the moon’s radiance, generates true qi; quicksilver is the radiance within the moon, which, when touched by the sun’s essence, generates true lead. Great cultivators and superior adepts transform spirit into qi, and qi into essence; middling adepts retain essence to preserve qi, and qi to preserve spirit. When spirit and essence merge and harmonize within the precious tripod, sweet dew descends, forming a pool of water.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
Through mutual nurturing and fusion, body and mind begin to transform, and only then can one observe the aperture.

The true mercury and true lead are the medicinal substances used to complete the elixir. These medicinal substances contain yin and yang within each other: true lead, a yang substance, is the sun’s soul, yet it is stored within water as the central line of Kan; true mercury, a yin substance, is the moon’s spirit, yet it is stored within fire as the central line of Li. The cultivator gathers these medicinal substances into the tripod, where the four great elements steam and fuse, yang qi ascends to the summit of Kunlun, unites with true yin, transforms into liquid, and returns to the tripod—this is the returning elixir. This passage clarifies the mutual containment of yin and yang, instructing the cultivator to invert yin and yang, returning them to the tripod.

Medicinal substances arise in the mysterious aperture,
Firing processes ignite the yang furnace.
When dragon and tiger meet,
The precious tripod gathers the mysterious pearl.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
"The mysterious aperture" is the mysterious female—mysterious yang and female yin—together called the mysterious aperture.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
The heart dwelling in the body for a long time marks the initial effect of the body being governed by the mind. White snow is the root of jade fluid, and the yellow sprout is the origin of golden fluid. One arises from nothingness into form, the other emerges from extreme stillness into movement.

chunks.original_text: 人身下田为炉，乃神之所栖，火发于此，故曰“阳炉”，炉上则鼎也。 静极而动，药物自生，时当采取。 得药之后，苟无火候以烹炼之，其药复散，玄珠何从而产哉！ 是必“拨转顶门关捩子，夺取骊龙颔下珠”。 药即是火，火即是药，药火合一，则龙虎交会而胎悬宝鼎，自产黍米之玄珠矣。 然必玄窍生药，方可阳炉发火。 若机未至，而先助长，则外火虽行，内符不应，适以自焚其躯耳。 大抵神气和融，则玄窍自见。 玄窍既见，则火候自知； 火候既知，则龙虎自并。 龙虎既并，则玄珠自成，其妙在动静之间，不差毫发可也。 （闵释）身心纯一不杂，化象豁然，尤须一意主持，慎独是至要也。 ○前五节，只着力一“静”字，至此加一“敬”字为主持。 “主敬存诚”工夫，其在斯乎！ 按，药物即是真铅、真汞，亦即神气是也。 积金实腹以后，方能玄关成象； 腹中有药，玄窍方生也。 阳炉者，太极炉也； 神气二者，是药物、是火。 既已玄关成象，自能火发阳炉； 一龙一虎，交会于中宫，而产生玄珠矣。 玄珠，金丹之别名也。 龙属木，是为木汞； 虎属金，即系金铅。 龙虎交会，亦即金木交并。 玄珠有象遂阳生，实缘宝鼎烹龙虎。 此章言金木并而结丹也。 此窍非凡窍，乾坤共合成。 名为神气穴，内有坎离精。 （彭注）“此窍”即上玄窍，以其不属有无，不落方体，超乎身心之外，出乎恍惚之间，故曰“非凡窍”。 人身上乾而下坤，乾之中爻索坤而成坎，坎居坤位而气居之； 坤之中爻索乾而成离，离寄乾位而神居之。 神者，心中之汞也； 气者，身中之铅也。 心为神室，身为气符，故曰“名为神气穴”。 身中有一点真阳之气，气属离； 心中有一点真阴之精，精属坎，故曰“内有坎离精。 ” （闵释）身心浑然，静观得窍，即非肉体凡身矣。 此后更须戒慎身心，勿离勿放，大旨惟必诚其意，克欲从严是也。 按，玄关一窍，为至玄至妙之机关。 张祖本章序文，解释之曰：“能知此窍，则冬至在此，药物在此，火候在此，沐浴在此，结胎在此，脱胎亦在此矣。 无边旁，无内外，乃神气之根，虚无之谷。 ”其言可谓深切着明矣。 盖此窍乃太极之理气所成，为人性命之根，故曰“乾坤共合成”也； 吾人后天身中，已隐而不现，必须药物到身，结成丹原，而后此窍显现，故曰“名为神气穴，内有坎离精”也。 所谓坎离之精，即是药物。 葛仙翁《玄玄诗》曰：“乾坤合处乃真中，中在虚无甚空阔。 簇将龙虎窍中藏，造化机枢归掌握。 ”即此两章之注解也。 玄关一窍之性质，及其作用，已发挥无余矣。 而世人乃于形身上求玄关，不亦愚乎！ 木汞一点红,金铅四斤黑。 铅汞结丹砂,耿耿紫金色。 （彭注）心中一点真阴之精，名曰“木汞”。 木数三，内涵真阳之气为一，故曰“一点”； 木能生火，火色红，故曰“一点红”； 身中一点真阳之气，名曰“金铅”。 金数四，故曰“四斤”； 铅色黑，金水同宫，故曰“四斤黑”。 初以红入黑，次炼黑入红，红黑相投，结成黍米之珠于宝鼎，而“耿耿”如紫色矣。 红与黑相同，其色紫，故曰“紫金色”。 然铅汞非有定物，红黑有定色，一点、四斤，亦非有定数也。 得意者当自知。
chunks.translated_text:
The lower elixir field of the human body is the furnace, where the spirit resides, and fire arises from here—hence it is called the "yang furnace." Above the furnace is the tripod. When stillness reaches its extreme, movement arises, and the medicinal substances naturally emerge—this is the time for their gathering. After obtaining the medicine, if there is no firing process to refine it, the medicine will scatter again, and how could the mysterious pearl be produced? One must "turn the pivot at the crown gate and seize the pearl beneath the black dragon’s jaw." The medicine is fire, and fire is medicine; when medicine and fire unite, dragon and tiger meet, the embryo hangs in the precious tripod, and the millet-like mysterious pearl is naturally born. Yet only when the mysterious aperture produces the medicine can the yang furnace emit fire. If the moment has not arrived but one forces growth prematurely, external fire may act, but the internal tally will not respond—this will only burn one’s own body. Generally, when spirit and qi harmonize, the mysterious aperture appears of itself. Once the mysterious aperture appears, the firing process is naturally known; once the firing process is known, dragon and tiger naturally merge. When dragon and tiger merge, the mysterious pearl is naturally formed—its subtlety lies in the interplay of movement and stillness, not deviating by even a hair’s breadth.

*(Min’s Annotation)*
When body and mind are purely unified without admixture, the symbolic transformation becomes suddenly clear. Yet one must maintain single-minded focus, for vigilance in solitude is of utmost importance. The preceding five sections emphasize only the word "stillness," but here the word "reverence" is added as the guiding principle. The work of "maintaining reverence and preserving sincerity" lies precisely here!

Observe: the medicinal substances are true lead and true mercury, which are also spirit and qi. Only after filling the abdomen with metal can the mysterious pass take form; when the abdomen contains medicine, the mysterious aperture arises. The yang furnace is the Supreme Ultimate furnace; spirit and qi are both the medicinal substances and the fire. Once the mysterious pass takes form, fire naturally arises from the yang furnace; one dragon and one tiger meet in the central palace, giving birth to the mysterious pearl. The mysterious pearl is another name for the golden elixir. The dragon pertains to wood and is called wood mercury; the tiger pertains to metal and is called metal lead. The meeting of dragon and tiger is also the merging of metal and wood. When the mysterious pearl takes form, yang is born—this truly stems from the precious tripod refining dragon and tiger. This chapter speaks of the merging of metal and wood to congeal the elixir.

This aperture is no ordinary aperture,
For it is jointly formed by Qian and Kun.
Called the cavity of spirit and qi,
Within it lies the essence of Kan and Li.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
"This aperture" refers to the aforementioned mysterious aperture. As it belongs neither to being nor non-being, transcends form and location, and exists beyond body and mind, emerging in the realm of the indistinct, it is called "no ordinary aperture." In the human body, Qian is above and Kun below; Qian’s central line seeks Kun to form Kan, which occupies Kun’s position while qi resides within it. Kun’s central line seeks Qian to form Li, which lodges in Qian’s position while spirit resides within it. Spirit is the mercury within the heart; qi is the lead within the body. The heart is the chamber of spirit, and the body is the tally of qi—hence it is called "the cavity of spirit and qi." Within the body lies a point of true yang qi, which pertains to Li; within the heart lies a point of true yin essence, which pertains to Kan—hence it is said, "within it lies the essence of Kan and Li."

*(Min’s Annotation)*
When body and mind merge into oneness, and stillness reveals the aperture, one is no longer a mortal body of flesh. Thereafter, one must guard body and mind with caution, never straying nor releasing them. The essential principle lies solely in sincerity of intention and strict mastery of desires.

Observe: the mysterious pass is the most profound and wondrous mechanism. Master Zhang’s preface to this chapter explains it thus: "To know this aperture is to know where the winter solstice occurs, where the medicinal substances reside, where the firing process takes place, where bathing occurs, where the embryo forms, and where the embryo is shed. It has no boundaries, no inside or outside—it is the root of spirit and qi, the valley of emptiness." His words are truly incisive and illuminating.

This aperture is formed by the principle and qi of the Supreme Ultimate, the root of human nature and life—hence it is said to be "jointly formed by Qian and Kun." In our postnatal bodies, it is hidden and invisible; only when medicinal substances enter the body and the elixir’s origin is congealed does this aperture manifest—hence it is called "the cavity of spirit and qi, within which lies the essence of Kan and Li." The essence of Kan and Li is the medicinal substance. As the Immortal Ge’s *Xuanxuan Poem* says:
*"Where Qian and Kun unite is the true center,
The center lies in emptiness, vast and boundless.
Gather dragon and tiger within the aperture,
And the pivot of creation rests in your grasp."*
This perfectly annotates these two chapters. The nature and function of the mysterious pass have been fully expounded. Yet people still seek the mysterious pass in the physical body—how foolish!

A speck of wood mercury, crimson red,
Four pounds of metal lead, pitch black.
Lead and mercury congeal cinnabar,
Glowing with the hue of purple gold.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
The point of true yin essence within the heart is called "wood mercury." Wood corresponds to the number three, containing one point of true yang qi—hence it is called "a speck." Wood generates fire, and fire is red—hence it is called "a speck of red." The point of true yang qi within the body is called "metal lead." Metal corresponds to the number four—hence it is called "four pounds." Lead is black, and metal and water share the same palace—hence it is called "four pounds of black." First, red enters black; then, black is refined into red. Red and black merge, congealing a millet-like pearl in the precious tripod, which shines with a purple glow. Red and black combine to form purple—hence it is called "the hue of purple gold." Yet lead and mercury are not fixed substances, red and black have fixed colors, and "a speck" and "four pounds" are not fixed quantities. Those who grasp the meaning will understand for themselves.

chunks.original_text: （闵释）仍是身心浑化，主敬存诚工夫。 真积日久，至道大凝之时矣，夫然后快足于心，乃可以清净自然为运用也夫。 按，此章再言金木交并，而结大丹之事也。 汞，火也，而木汞为火中木液，其色仍红，东三南二成一五也； 铅，水也，而金铅则为水中金，其色仍黑，北一西四成一五也。 因中央黄婆之勾引，而结成金液还丹，故曰“铅汞结丹砂，耿耿紫金色”也。 又按，彭注本为“金铅四斤黑”，而讲者所据本文为“金铅三斤黑”，“三”、“四”两字不符。 彭注仍照原文载入，以存其真。 本文则从讲者所据之本，作“三”字，不免两岐。 特附注于此，学者详焉。 家园景物丽，风雨正春深。 犁（一作耕）锄不费力，大地皆黄金。 （彭注）“家园”者，身中之真土也； “景物”者，身中药物景象也。 时一阳来复之际，但鼓巽风，以吹坤土，即引神水以润华池。 及至三阳交泰之时，亦慎不费采取之力，但勿忘勿助，而大地黄芽自土中而迸出矣。 谓之金者，言其结成金丹也。 （闵释）集义所生之气，至大至刚，惟以直养无害而已矣。 按，家即“此般至宝家家有”之家，“家园物丽”，则自有之药已足之意也； “风雨春深”，则火候已到炉火纯青之时也。 此时应悠游自在，勿忘勿助，故曰“犁锄不费力”，一费力反有害于丹也。 迨到脱胎神化，则山河大地，皆成七宝，吾身亦已金光罩身，故曰“大地皆黄金”也。 此章言温养大丹之功。 《悟真篇》曰：“要知炼养还丹法，自向家园下种栽。 不假吹嘘并着力，自然果熟结灵胎。 ”即此章之解释也。 真铅生于坎，其用在离宫。 以黑而变红，一鼎云气浓。 （彭注）肾生气，气中真一之水为真铅。 真一之水,即离宫正阳之气，气液相合，气中收取真一之水。 非液中采取正阳之气，使母子相逢而顾恋，则金隐于水，无由上升。 盖以神驭气，千古传心之要诀也。 故曰“其用在离宫”，体在坎而用在离也。 是铅既以火而出，水则以黑变红。 药即是火，但见自三关路头，以抵九重天上，油然而兴，霏然而升，翕然而蒸，霭然而凝，而其气如云之浓，上升鼎内矣。 （闵释）此承上节，特标身心浑化之工用，全在以心治身之所致也。 静之力也。 按，真铅生于坎中，坎本水也，而此真铅实为水中真火，故曰“用在离宫”。 命门真火上冲心腑，与离宫真水相交，其初本黑。 黑，水色也，因与火交，黑变为红，而鼎生云气。 本文第二章曰“鼎上飞紫霞”，即此至浓之云气也。 此章以明真铅之作用也。 真汞产于离，其用却在坎。 姹女过南园，手持玉橄榄。 （彭注）汞虽产自离宫，然非得北方之正气以制伏之，则常欲去人，不得凝聚，故曰“其用却在坎。 ”姹女者，汞也； 南园者，离也。 离中之汞，一见坎中之铅，则铅汞相投，将舍离宫，而同降坎位，故曰“过南园”。 一过南园，而汞水成白雪矣。 “玉”者，象其色之白也； “橄榄”者，象其不方不圆也。 （闵释）此复标身心浑化之工用，全在以身养心之所致也。 敬之至也。

(Min’s Exegesis) This remains the work of merging body and mind, of maintaining reverence and preserving sincerity. Through true accumulation over time, when the great Dao congeals to its fullest, then—and only then—will the heart be fully satisfied, and one may employ the practice of pure spontaneity.

Note: This chapter again speaks of the intermingling of metal and wood, culminating in the formation of the Great Elixir. Mercury is fire, and "wood mercury" is the liquid of fire within wood, its color still red; east (three) and south (two) together make five. Lead is water, and "metal lead" is the metal within water, its color still black; north (one) and west (four) together make five. Through the matchmaking of the Yellow Dame of the Center, the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir is formed—hence the saying, "Lead and mercury congeal cinnabar, shining with the hue of purple gold."

Further note: Peng’s commentary records "four pounds of black metal lead," while the version cited by the lecturer reads "three pounds of black metal lead." The characters "three" and "four" do not align. Peng’s commentary retains the original text to preserve its authenticity, while the main text follows the lecturer’s version, using "three." This discrepancy is duly noted here for scholars to consider.

The homestead’s scenery is fair,
Wind and rain deepen spring’s care.
Plowing (or tilling) costs no toil,
All the earth turns to gold.

(Peng’s Commentary) "Homestead" refers to the true earth within the body; "scenery" refers to the manifestations of the medicinal substances within. When the time of the return of the first yang arrives, simply stir the wind of Xun to blow upon the earth of Kun, thereby drawing the divine water to moisten the Flowery Pond. By the time the three yangs intermingle in harmony, one must be cautious not to expend effort in gathering, but rather neither forget nor force—then the yellow sprout of the earth will naturally burst forth. It is called "gold" because it coalesces into the Golden Elixir.

(Min’s Exegesis) The qi generated by the accumulation of righteousness is vast and unyielding; it is merely nurtured directly without harm. Note: "Homestead" here is the "treasure possessed by every household" mentioned earlier. "The homestead’s scenery is fair" signifies that one’s innate medicine is already sufficient. "Wind and rain deepen spring’s care" indicates that the firing process has reached the stage of "pure azure in the crucible." At this time, one should remain at ease, neither forgetting nor forcing—hence "plowing costs no toil." Any exertion would instead harm the Elixir. When the spiritual embryo is delivered and transformed, mountains, rivers, and the great earth all become the Seven Treasures, and one’s body is enveloped in golden light—hence "all the earth turns to gold." This chapter speaks of the work of nurturing the Great Elixir. As *Awakening to Reality* states: "To know the method of refining and nurturing the Returned Elixir, / One must plant the seed in one’s own homestead. / No need for blowing or forcing, / The fruit will naturally ripen, forming the spiritual embryo." This is the explanation of the present chapter.

True lead is born in Kan,
Its function lies in Li.
From black it transforms into red,
A dense cloud of qi fills the crucible.

(Peng’s Commentary) The kidneys generate qi, and the true water of the One within qi is true lead. This true water of the One is the correct yang qi of the Li Palace. When qi and liquid merge, the true water of the One is gathered from within the qi—not the correct yang qi extracted from the liquid—so that mother and child meet and cherish each other. Then metal is concealed within water, and there is no way for it to ascend. For the spirit to guide qi is the essential oral transmission of the ages. Hence it is said, "Its function lies in Li," for its substance is in Kan while its function is in Li. Once lead emerges through fire, water transforms from black to red. The medicine is fire itself. From the path of the Three Passes, it rises to the Ninefold Heaven, surging forth, ascending lightly, gathering and steaming, condensing like mist—its qi as dense as clouds, ascending into the crucible.

(Min’s Exegesis) This continues the previous section, emphasizing that the work of merging body and mind depends entirely on the governance of the body by the mind. It is the power of stillness. Note: True lead is born in Kan, which is fundamentally water, yet this true lead is the true fire within water—hence "its function lies in Li." The true fire of the Gate of Life surges upward into the heart’s palace, where it meets the true water of the Li Palace. Initially, it is black. Black is the color of water, but through its union with fire, black transforms into red, and the crucible generates cloud-like qi. The second chapter of the original text says, "Purple mist flies above the crucible"—this is the same dense cloud-like qi. This chapter clarifies the function of true lead.

True mercury is produced in Li,
Its function, however, lies in Kan.
The maiden passes through the southern garden,
Holding a jade olive in her hand.

(Peng’s Commentary) Though mercury is produced in the Li Palace, without the correct qi of the north to subdue it, it constantly seeks to leave the body and cannot be congealed—hence "its function lies in Kan." The maiden is mercury; the southern garden is Li. When the mercury in Li encounters the lead in Kan, lead and mercury unite, abandoning the Li Palace to descend together into the Kan position—hence "passes through the southern garden." Once it passes through the southern garden, the mercury water becomes white snow. "Jade" symbolizes its white color; "olive" symbolizes its shape, neither square nor round.

(Min’s Exegesis) This again emphasizes that the work of merging body and mind depends entirely on the nurturing of the mind by the body. It is the utmost of reverence.
chunks.overlap_context: ame palace—hence it is called "four pounds of black." First, red enters black; then, black is refined into red. Red and black merge, congealing a millet-like pearl in the precious tripod, which shines with a purple glow. Red and black combine to form purple—hence it is called "the hue of purple gold." Yet lead and mercury are not fixed substances, red and black have fixed colors, and "a speck" and "four pounds" are not fixed quantities. Those who grasp the meaning will understand for themselves.

chunks.original_text: 按，真汞生于离中，离本火也，而此真汞实为火中真水，故曰“用却在坎”。 当真阳上升到离宫时，即合离中真水化液，而下降于坎宫，而真水真火相交，故曰“其用却在坎”。 “姹女过南园”者，自离而来也。 言真汞由南离到坎府，而与真火相交，结成玉液还丹，故曰“手持玉橄榄”。 还丹本为仙人所证之果，此为玉液还丹，故以“玉橄榄”象之。 此章以明真汞之作用也。 震兑非东西，坎离不南北。 斗柄运周天,要人会攒簇。 (彭注)震东兑西,离南坎北，八卦之方位。 天道运行，无时休息，而斗柄转移，逐月各指一方，阴阳寒署，不愆其期。 人身一天地也，自玄谷上泥丸，复下重楼，以归北海，谓之“周天”。 其斡旋之机，亦由乎斗柄。 一年十二月，一月三十日，共三百六十日。 一日一百刻，一年计三万六千刻。 一日之功，可夺三万六千刻之气。 言修丹之士，运周天火候，于一日之内，以一日易一年，以十二时易十二月。 攒年于日，簇月于时，惟随斗柄以为转运，而东西南北，不必言矣。 斗柄一差，则时令乖忒，慎之慎之。 按，结丹药物，彻始彻终,为真汞真铅二物。 真汞生自离，离居南方； 真铅生于坎，坎居北位，谓“南离北坎”。 然真汞又谓离中木液，木居东方属震； 真铅又为水中金，金居西方属兑，故又谓“东震西兑”。 其实汞铅二物，于东西南北并无定位。 修道者烹炼铅汞以成丹，全在中央真意，调和神气，握定斗柄之机枢，攒簇一年之气候，运行周天，随斗柄之所指以为转移，故曰“斗柄运周天，要人会攒簇”也。 火候不用时，冬至不在子。 及其沐浴时（一作法），卯酉亦（一作时）虚比。 （彭注）火之为物，太大则炎，太小则冷，要在调和得中，故火必曰“候”。 一日有六候，候者吾身之节候。 何时之有？ 吾身静极而动，在月即为冬至，在日即为冬至，在日即为子时，迎此机而与之俱动，则火候在此矣。 大抵一阳升为子，一阳降为午，阳升阴降为卯，阴升阳降为酉。 所谓“不刻时中分子午”，非必以冬至为子，夏至为午，兔鸡之月为卯酉也。 如外丹进火为子，抽火为午，不增火不减火为沐浴，不拘子午，亦不拘卯酉也。 （闵释）此二节，统言身心浑一之工用，专赖一真意主持之，静之力也，敬之至也。 其实诚之至，而无息也。 真人复示此八十字，不但授学者以运用之柄，且为执文泥象之士，扫除一切丹书眼障而言也。 按，丹法以子午卯酉为四正，进火退符、温养沐浴，皆在此矣。 所谓“冬至”，即一阳来复，应进火之时； 中逢卯酉，应沐浴之时。 其实，此为作丹之法度，皆按比象而言。 学者不可泥象执文，求之于晷刻之上也。 《入药镜》曰：“一日内，十二时，意所到，皆可为。 ”每日十二时，但逢阳生符信，随时皆可作丹，不必定为年中之冬至、日中之子时也。 观于“活子时”之名称，可知之矣。 子午如此，卯酉可知。 学者运行周天，务当循指认月，万勿刻舟求剑，至负张祖叮咛之意可也。 乌肝与兔髓，擒来归一处。 一粒复一粒，从微而至着。 （彭注）人禀天地真元之炁三百八十四铢，其重一斤。 八两，日之精，故曰“乌肝”，即木液也； 八两，月之精，故曰“兔髓”，即金精也。
chunks.translated_text:
Now, true mercury is born within Li, and Li is fundamentally fire. Yet this true mercury is in fact the true water within fire—hence "its function lies in Kan." When true yang ascends to the Li Palace, it immediately combines with the true water within Li to form an essence, which then descends into the Kan Palace. There, true water and true fire merge—hence "its function lies in Kan." "The maiden passes through the southern garden" means she comes from Li. It speaks of true mercury traveling from southern Li to the Kan mansion, where it unites with true fire to congeal into the jade liquid returning elixir—hence "hand holding a jade olive." The returning elixir is the fruit attained by immortals; this is the jade liquid returning elixir, thus symbolized by the "jade olive." This passage clarifies the function of true mercury.

Zhen and Dui are not east and west; Kan and Li are not south and north.
The Dipper’s handle revolves through the celestial cycle—one must grasp its gathering and clustering.

(Peng’s Commentary) Zhen is east, Dui is west, Li is south, and Kan is north—these are the directional positions of the eight trigrams. The Dao of Heaven operates without ceasing, and the Dipper’s handle shifts month by month, pointing in turn to each direction. Yin and yang, cold and heat, never miss their appointed time. The human body is a microcosm of heaven and earth: from the Mysterious Valley it ascends to the Mud Pill Palace, then descends past the Double Towers to return to the Northern Sea—this is called the "celestial cycle." The mechanism of its revolution likewise depends on the Dipper’s handle. A year has twelve months, a month thirty days, totaling three hundred and sixty days. A day has one hundred ke, so a year amounts to thirty-six thousand ke. A single day’s work can seize the qi of thirty-six thousand ke. It speaks of the cultivator of the elixir, who circulates the celestial cycle’s fire times: within one day, one day replaces a year, and the twelve hours replace the twelve months. Years are gathered into days, months into hours—only by following the Dipper’s handle in its revolutions, and east, west, south, and north need not be mentioned. If the Dipper’s handle errs even slightly, the seasons will fall into disorder. Be cautious, be cautious indeed.

Now, the ingredients for congealing the elixir, from beginning to end, are two things: true mercury and true lead. True mercury is born from Li, and Li resides in the south; true lead is born from Kan, and Kan resides in the north—hence "southern Li and northern Kan." Yet true mercury is also called the wood essence within Li, and wood resides in the east, belonging to Zhen; true lead is also the metal within water, and metal resides in the west, belonging to Dui—hence "eastern Zhen and western Dui." In truth, the two substances of mercury and lead have no fixed positions in east, west, south, or north. For the cultivator who refines lead and mercury to form the elixir, everything depends on the true intention at the center, harmonizing spirit and qi, firmly grasping the pivotal mechanism of the Dipper’s handle, gathering and clustering the qi of a full year, circulating the celestial cycle, and revolving in accord with the Dipper’s handle—hence "the Dipper’s handle revolves through the celestial cycle—one must grasp its gathering and clustering."

Fire times do not rely on hours; the winter solstice is not confined to *zi*.
When it is time for bathing (or "the method"), *mao* and *you* are also (or "at times") empty comparisons.

(Peng’s Commentary) Fire, as a thing, if too great becomes scorching, if too small becomes cold—its key lies in harmonious moderation, hence fire must be called "times." A day has six times, and these times are the nodal points of our body. What hour is there? When our body reaches the extreme of stillness and begins to move, in the month this is the winter solstice, in the day this is the *zi* hour. Seizing this moment and moving in unison with it, then the fire times are here. Generally, *zi* is when yang ascends, *wu* is when yang descends, *mao* is when yang ascends and yin descends, and *you* is when yin ascends and yang descends. The saying "do not divide *zi* and *wu* by the hour" does not mean one must take the winter solstice as *zi* and the summer solstice as *wu*, or the months of the hare and rooster as *mao* and *you*. For external elixirs, adding fire is *zi*, withdrawing fire is *wu*, neither increasing nor decreasing fire is bathing—it is not bound to *zi* and *wu*, nor to *mao* and *you*.

(Min’s Exegesis) These two passages together speak of the work of merging body and mind into one, relying entirely on the true intention to preside over it—this is the power of stillness, the utmost of reverence. In truth, it is the utmost of sincerity, without ceasing. The Perfected One again reveals these eighty characters not only to impart the handle of practice to the learner but also to sweep away all the eye-obscuring fixations of those who cling to texts and images.

Now, in elixir methods, *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you* are the four cardinal points. Advancing fire, retreating tally, warming and nurturing, and bathing all occur within them. The "winter solstice" refers to the return of the first yang, corresponding to the time for advancing fire. When it reaches *mao* and *you*, this corresponds to the time for bathing. In truth, these are the methods and measures for making the elixir, all spoken of by way of analogy. The learner must not rigidly adhere to images and texts, seeking them in the divisions of the sundial. *The Mirror for Entering the Medicine* says: "Within a single day, the twelve hours—wherever intention reaches, all can serve." Each day’s twelve hours, whenever the yang arises and the tally appears, can be the time to make the elixir—it need not be confined to the winter solstice of the year or the *zi* hour of the day. One can see this from the term "living *zi* hour." If *zi* and *wu* are like this, *mao* and *you* can be understood likewise. When learners circulate the celestial cycle, they must follow the Dipper’s handle to recognize the month, never carving the boat to seek the sword, lest they fail the earnest admonitions of Patriarch Zhang.

Crow’s liver and hare’s marrow,
Seize them and bring them to one place.
Grain upon grain,
From the subtle to the manifest.

(Peng’s Commentary) Humans receive the true primordial qi of heaven and earth, weighing three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, totaling one *jin*. Eight *liang* are the essence of the sun, hence called "crow’s liver"—this is the wood essence. Eight *liang* are the essence of the moon, hence called "hare’s marrow"—this is the metal essence.

Once it passes through the southern garden, the mercury water becomes white snow. "Jade" symbolizes its white color; "olive" symbolizes its shape, neither square nor round.

(Min’s Exegesis) This again emphasizes that the work of merging body and mind depends entirely on the nurturing of the mind by the body. It is the utmost of reverence.

chunks.original_text: 金木间隔，假戊己为媒娉，用火锻炼，日生一粒，如黍米大，重一铢八厘。 自微至着，积铢而成两，三十日重三十八铢四丝，三百日重三百八十四铢，方圆一寸而重一斤矣。 （闵释）显言只须身心交合，并无别法运用。 但以直养无害，自微至着而已。 是由“慎独”以至“心广体胖”，其气将塞乎天地矣。 按，乌肝兔髓，即真汞真铅之药物也。 此项药物，皆由点滴积聚而成。 真铅采自空中，真汞化自身内，用火烹炼以成丹，故曰“一粒复一粒，从微而至着”也。 其法有擒来、归合之二者：擒来即采取封固，归合即烹炼凝结也。 应用吾人巍巍不动之真意以为之。 此意，亦即自然神觉。 久久行持，方可成功。 《黄庭内外景经》曰：“仙人道士非有神，积精累气以成真。 ”即此章之解释也。 浑沌包虚空，虚空括三界。 及寻其根源，一粒黍米（黍米一作如黍）大。 （彭注）有世界，则有三才； 有三才，则有虚空； 有虚空，则有浑沌。 未有天地之先，浑浑沌沌，浑沌包虚空，虚空括三界。 及寻吾身受气之初，不过一粒，大如黍米。 此人生之根源，而修丹者之所当知也。 故曰：“有人要觅长生诀，只去搜寻造化根。 ” （闵释）浑沌者身也，虚空者心也，一者诚也。 身包心，心括身，所以至此者，一真意由之也。 真意在天地，为造化之枢机，在人身为生化之主宰也。 既使由之，仍不妨仍使知之。 见得真士工用，其盛大有如此者。 按，自造化之开基而言，则由无极而太极，而两仪四象、万物化生，是即“混沌包虚空，虚空括三界”也。 及至原始返终，归根复命，道在由万返三，由三返一，由一归空，故可谓生于混沌而返于混沌焉。 修道者则之，由还虚下手，即于还虚了当。 末后粉碎虚空，归于无极，而大功告成矣。 然自始基言之，实由一汞一铅、点滴积累而成，无异有形世界之起于一也。 故曰“及寻其根源，一粒如黍大”也。 《椤严经》曰：“空生大觉中，如水一沤。 发至华藏世界，则以一毫端藏三千大千世界； 三千大千世界，归本于一毫端。 ”盖自其分别者观之，则三千大千世界甚大，一毫端甚微； 自其融通者观之，则一毫端固无异于三千大千世界。 其理甚妙，可深长思也。 天地交真液，日月含真精。 会得坎离基，三界归一身。 （彭注）心液下降，肾气上升，液与气总名曰液，“天地交真液”也； 魂为乌精，魄为兔髓，总名曰精，“日月含真精”也。 坎属阴，坎中藏戊，戊为阳土，是阳者坎之基也； 离属阳，离中藏己，己为阴土，是阴者离之基也。 会得坎中戊土，基始于阳； 离中已土，基始于阴，则身心天地、身中日月，皆由真土为之运用，而三界归于一身矣。 （闵释）坎者，身也； 离者，心也； 坎离基者，意也。 坎在先天居西为魄，至后天居北是魄，已流而为精。 今统先、后天，混精、魄为一家者，身也； 离在先天居东为魂，至后天居南是魂，已显而为神。 今统先、后天，浑神、魂而为一家者，心也； 惟土居中央，会合四象，实为先后天坎离之基。 未尝因先后天而变其所者，意也。 惟上士举意宅身以收心，使身、心、意三者浑归一处，不贰不息，鞠养成真，以致盛大而能生物，岂非万物已备于我、三界归一身耶！
chunks.translated_text:
Between metal and wood lies separation; they borrow *wu* and *ji* as their matchmakers. Through the firing of the furnace, one grain is born each day, like a millet seed in size, weighing one *zhu* and eight *li*. From the subtle to the manifest, grains accumulate into *liang*; in thirty days, they weigh thirty-eight *zhu* and four *si*; in three hundred days, three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, round and one *cun* in diameter, weighing one *jin*.

(Min’s Explanation) This plainly states that one need only unite body and mind—there is no other method of practice. Simply nurture it directly without harm, from the subtle to the manifest. This is to proceed from "vigilance in solitude" to "a heart expansive and a body at ease," until one’s *qi* fills heaven and earth.

Now, crow’s liver and hare’s marrow are the medicinal substances of true mercury and true lead. These medicinal substances are all formed through the accumulation of droplets. True lead is gathered from the void; true mercury is transformed within oneself. Refined with fire to form the elixir, hence it is said, "Grain upon grain, from the subtle to the manifest." The method involves two steps: "seizing" and "uniting." "Seizing" means gathering and sealing; "uniting" means refining and congealing. One employs one’s steadfast, unshaken true intention to accomplish this. This intention is also the natural spiritual awareness. Through prolonged practice, success may be achieved. The *Huangting Neijing Waijing Jing* states: "Immortals and Daoists are not divine; they accumulate essence and amass *qi* to attain the real." This is the explanation of this passage.

Chaos envelops the void; the void encompasses the three realms. Yet when one traces its root, it is but a grain the size of a millet seed.

(Peng’s Commentary) Where there is a world, there are the Three Powers; where there are the Three Powers, there is the void; where there is the void, there is chaos. Before the existence of heaven and earth, chaos was undifferentiated. Chaos envelops the void; the void encompasses the three realms. Yet when one traces the origin of the *qi* received at the beginning of one’s life, it is but a single grain, as large as a millet seed. This is the root of human life, which those who cultivate the elixir must know. Thus it is said: "If one seeks the secret of longevity, one must search for the root of creation."

(Min’s Explanation) Chaos is the body; the void is the mind; the One is sincerity. The body envelops the mind; the mind encompasses the body. The means by which this is achieved is the true intention. True intention in heaven and earth is the pivot of creation; in the human body, it is the master of generation and transformation. Though one may follow it, one need not remain ignorant of it. When one perceives the workings of a true adept, their grandeur is as vast as this.

Now, from the inception of creation, it proceeds from Non-Ultimate to Supreme Ultimate, to the Two Modes and Four Images, to the transformation and generation of the myriad things—this is "chaos envelops the void; the void encompasses the three realms." Yet when one returns to the origin and restores life, the Dao lies in proceeding from the myriad back to the Three, from the Three back to the One, and from the One back to the void. Thus one may say that life arises from chaos and returns to chaos. Those who cultivate the Dao follow this principle: they begin with returning to the void and accomplish it. In the end, they shatter the void, return to the Non-Ultimate, and the great work is complete. Yet from the beginning, it is truly formed through the accumulation of one mercury and one lead, droplet by droplet, no different from the arising of the tangible world from the One. Thus it is said, "Yet when one traces its root, it is but a grain the size of a millet seed."

The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "The void arises within great awakening, like a bubble in water. When it expands to the Flower Treasury World, a single tip of a hair contains three thousand great thousand worlds; three thousand great thousand worlds return to the tip of a single hair." From the perspective of differentiation, three thousand great thousand worlds are vast, while the tip of a hair is minute. Yet from the perspective of interpenetration, the tip of a hair is no different from three thousand great thousand worlds. The principle is profound; it invites deep and prolonged reflection.

The true fluids of heaven and earth intermingle;
The sun and moon contain true essence.
When one grasps the foundation of *kan* and *li*,
The three realms return to one body.

(Peng’s Commentary) The fluid of the heart descends; the *qi* of the kidneys ascends. Fluid and *qi* together are called "fluid"—this is "the true fluids of heaven and earth intermingle." The *hun* is the essence of the crow; the *po* is the marrow of the hare. Together they are called "essence"—this is "the sun and moon contain true essence." *Kan* pertains to yin; within *kan* is concealed *wu*, which is yang earth—this yang is the foundation of *kan*. *Li* pertains to yang; within *li* is concealed *ji*, which is yin earth—this yin is the foundation of *li*. When one grasps that the foundation of *kan* is *wu* earth, beginning with yang, and the foundation of *li* is *ji* earth, beginning with yin, then the heaven and earth of the body, the sun and moon within the body, are all operated by true earth, and the three realms return to one body.

(Min’s Explanation) *Kan* is the body; *li* is the mind; the foundation of *kan* and *li* is intention. In the prenatal state, *kan* resides in the west as *po*; in the postnatal state, it resides in the north as *po*, having flowed into essence. Now, combining prenatal and postnatal, merging essence and *po* into one, is the body. In the prenatal state, *li* resides in the east as *hun*; in the postnatal state, it resides in the south as *hun*, having manifested as spirit. Now, combining prenatal and postnatal, merging spirit and *hun* into one, is the mind. Only earth resides at the center, uniting the Four Images, and is truly the foundation of prenatal and postnatal *kan* and *li*. That which does not change with the prenatal or postnatal is intention. Only the superior adept employs intention to dwell in the body and gather the mind, causing body, mind, and intention to merge into one, unwavering and unceasing. Nurturing them to perfection, one attains such grandeur as to generate beings—is this not the myriad things being complete within oneself, the three realms returning to one body?
chunks.overlap_context:
est admonitions of Patriarch Zhang.

Crow’s liver and hare’s marrow,
Seize them and bring them to one place.
Grain upon grain,
From the subtle to the manifest.

(Peng’s Commentary) Humans receive the true primordial qi of heaven and earth, weighing three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, totaling one *jin*. Eight *liang* are the essence of the sun, hence called "crow’s liver"—this is the wood essence. Eight *liang* are the essence of the moon, hence called "hare’s marrow"—this is the metal essence.

chunks.original_text: 此丹道之极工，圣人之能事具矣。 ○此后四节，乃重申精凝神结之工用，并非更进一层之说，慎勿疑有重立鼎炉之事，为邪说引误可也。 按，坎离即是真铅真汞，换言之，即是真阳真阴、阳气阴精是也。 天地配合，日月交光，皆此二物之作用，故能天长地久，日月永保其光明。 人能得此坎离之精而服食之，则可长生久视，而宇宙在乎手，万化生乎身，故曰“三界归一身”也。 三界即欲界、色界、无色界，亦即天、地、人，亦即是精、气、神也。 龙从东海来，虎向西山起。 两兽战一场，化作天地髓。 （彭注）心中正阳之气为龙，木能生火，震属木，故龙从东方来； 肾中真一之精为虎，金能生水，兑属金，故虎向西山起，若使龙吟云起而下降，虎啸风生而上升，二兽相逢交战于黄屋之前，则龙吞虎髓，虎啖龙精，风云庆会，混合为一，而化为天地之髓矣。 （闵释）此溯言下手时，身心初得浑凝之象，非实有战象也。 此言“战”者，言人从后天欲复先天，必须天人交战一场。 天定胜人，则情魔灭尽； 人定胜天，则理障消融。 然后天人浑合，身心乃得浑化耳。 ○按紫阳本《序》云：“心之猖狂如龙，身之狞恶如虎。 ”此节言“龙从东海来”，乃心家之魂也； “虎向西山起”，乃身家之魄也。 其实即本《序》所云“身中一点真阳之气，心中一点真阴之精，谓之二物”，即此两兽也。 本《序》又云：“心属乾，身属坤。 ”此节言“战一场”者，即陈泥丸云“以制伏身心为野战”是也。 言“化作天地髓”者，即“天地日月软如绵”是也。 彭居士忘却先天坎离本位，率从后天探象，故落出心、肾、震兑等字，殊非本旨。 应从本《序》改注如此。 按，龙者，汞也，心也，神也。 以人心易动，飞扬而不易制，故以龙呼之； 虎者，铅也，身也，气也。 以人身多欲，猖狂而常咥人，故以虎名之。 东为震而属木，西为兑而属金。 丹法驱虎从龙，乘龙制虎，是为龙虎相交； 以其为东龙西虎，故又为金木交并，在中央戊己之宫，恶战夺斗。 少焉东龙西虎俱死归厚土，化为天地之真液，日月之真精，而结成还丹矣。 是为大药归炉，炼化金液还丹之象。 《悟真篇》曰：“西山白虎正猖狂，东海青龙不可当。 两兽捉来令死斗，化成一片紫金霜。 ”所谓“天地髓”，亦即是“紫金霜”，还丹之法象也。 金华开汞叶，玉蒂长铅枝。 坎离不曾闲，乾坤经（一作今）几时。 （彭注）金花本真铅，借汞成胎； 玉蒂本真汞，借铅成形：人身汞为神，铅为精。 “金华开汞叶”者，恍恍惚惚，水中生神也； “玉蒂长铅枝”者，杳杳冥冥，火中生精也。 得诀者，坐至金花显露，玉蒂滋萌，则铅汞之枝叶已茂。 此正宜采药进火，使坎离远行于东西，乾坤周回于上下，一往一复，一升一降，如环无端，不可有顷刻之停。 盖未得药时，须要认汞叶之开，与铅枝之长。 既得药后，又要知往复之妙，升降之宜，方为始终兼尽，而圣胎圆成矣。 苟乾坤坎离不循环于十月之中，则鼎器药物暂得竟失，金花乌保其不谢？ 玉蒂乌保其不凋耶？ （闵释）此节标示，全在真意主持，务使身心刻刻交融，无一丝毫间断。 惟以心体乾道之大健，以身由坤道之大顺，自然周运不息，将复坎离而为乾坤矣。
chunks.translated_text:
This is the ultimate work of the elixir Way, the consummate achievement of the sage. ○ The following four sections reaffirm the work of congealing essence and coalescing spirit—this is not a discourse on advancing to a further stage. Take care not to suspect the establishment of another crucible and furnace, lest you be led astray by heterodox teachings.

Now, *kan* and *li* are none other than true lead and true mercury. In other words, they are true yang and true yin, yang *qi* and yin essence. The union of heaven and earth, the radiant exchange of sun and moon, are all the workings of these two substances. Thus, they enable heaven and earth to endure eternally, and the sun and moon to preserve their luminosity forever. If one can obtain the essence of *kan* and *li* and ingest it, one may attain longevity and lasting vision, holding the cosmos in one’s hands and generating the myriad transformations within the body. Hence it is said, “the three realms return to one body.”

The three realms are the realm of desire, the realm of form, and the realm of formlessness—also corresponding to heaven, earth, and humanity, as well as essence, *qi*, and spirit.

The dragon comes from the Eastern Sea,
The tiger rises from the Western Mountain.
The two beasts wage a great battle,
Transforming into the marrow of heaven and earth.

*(Peng’s Annotation)* The central yang *qi* within the heart is the dragon. Wood generates fire, and *zhen* (☳) pertains to wood, hence the dragon comes from the east. The true unity of essence within the kidneys is the tiger. Metal generates water, and *dui* (☱) pertains to metal, hence the tiger rises from the western mountain. If the dragon’s roar summons clouds to descend and the tiger’s howl stirs winds to ascend, the two beasts meet and clash before the Yellow Chamber. Then the dragon swallows the tiger’s marrow, the tiger devours the dragon’s essence, wind and clouds converge in celebration, merging into one to become the marrow of heaven and earth.

*(Min’s Explanation)* This retroactively describes the initial moment of practice, when body and mind first achieve coalescence—there is no actual battle. The word “battle” signifies that in returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, one must engage in a struggle between heaven and humanity. If heaven prevails over humanity, the demons of passion are extinguished; if humanity prevails over heaven, the obstructions of principle dissolve. Only then do heaven and humanity merge, and body and mind achieve complete transformation.

○ According to the original *Preface* of Master Ziyang: “The heart’s wildness is like a dragon; the body’s ferocity is like a tiger.” This section speaks of “the dragon coming from the Eastern Sea,” which is the *hun* of the heart; “the tiger rising from the Western Mountain,” which is the *po* of the body. In truth, these are the two substances mentioned in the *Preface*: “a single point of true yang *qi* in the body, a single point of true yin essence in the heart.” These are the two beasts. The *Preface* further states: “The heart pertains to *qian* (☰); the body pertains to *kun* (☷).” The phrase “wage a great battle” here corresponds to Chen Niniwan’s words: “subduing body and mind is like waging a field battle.” The phrase “transforming into the marrow of heaven and earth” corresponds to “heaven and earth, sun and moon, soft as silk.” Master Peng, forgetting the original positions of prenatal *kan* and *li*, hastily sought images in the postnatal realm, thus introducing terms like heart, kidneys, *zhen*, and *dui*, which deviate from the original intent. The annotation should be revised according to the *Preface*.

Now, the dragon is mercury, the heart, and spirit. Because the human heart is easily agitated, soaring and difficult to restrain, it is called a dragon. The tiger is lead, the body, and *qi*. Because the human body is full of desires, wild and often devouring, it is named a tiger. The east is *zhen* and pertains to wood; the west is *dui* and pertains to metal. In the elixir method, one drives the tiger to follow the dragon and rides the dragon to subdue the tiger—this is the union of dragon and tiger. As they are the eastern dragon and western tiger, this also represents the merging of metal and wood. In the central palace of *wu* and *ji*, they fiercely contend. Soon, the eastern dragon and western tiger both die and return to the fertile earth, transforming into the true fluid of heaven and earth, the true essence of the sun and moon, thereby congealing the returning elixir. This is the image of the great medicine returning to the furnace, the refinement of golden fluid and the returning elixir.

*The Wuzhen Pian* says:
“The white tiger of the western mountain rages wildly,
The azure dragon of the eastern sea is uncontrollable.
Seize the two beasts and make them fight to the death,
Transforming into a sheet of purple golden frost.”

The “marrow of heaven and earth” is precisely this “purple golden frost,” the symbolic image of the returning elixir.

Golden blossoms open mercury leaves,
Jade buds grow lead branches.
*Kan* and *li* never rest,
How long have *qian* and *kun* endured?

*(Peng’s Annotation)* The golden blossom is true lead, which borrows mercury to form the embryo; the jade bud is true mercury, which borrows lead to take shape. In the human body, mercury is spirit, and lead is essence. “Golden blossoms open mercury leaves” refers to the indistinct and subtle, where spirit is born within water. “Jade buds grow lead branches” refers to the profound and obscure, where essence is generated within fire. Those who grasp the method sit until golden blossoms appear and jade buds sprout, at which point the branches and leaves of lead and mercury flourish. This is the proper moment to gather the medicine and advance the fire, causing *kan* and *li* to traverse east and west, *qian* and *kun* to revolve above and below, moving back and forth, ascending and descending in an endless cycle without the slightest pause. Before obtaining the medicine, one must recognize the opening of mercury leaves and the growth of lead branches. After obtaining the medicine, one must also understand the subtleties of circulation and the proper timing of ascent and descent to achieve perfection from beginning to end and complete the sacred embryo. If *qian*, *kun*, *kan*, and *li* do not circulate throughout the ten months, the crucible and medicine, once briefly obtained, will soon be lost. How can the golden blossoms avoid withering? How can the jade buds avoid wilting?

*(Min’s Explanation)* This section emphasizes that the key lies in the true intention presiding over the process, ensuring that body and mind merge ceaselessly without the slightest interruption. Only by embodying the great strength of the *qian* Dao with the heart and the great compliance of the *kun* Dao with the body can one naturally circulate without cease, ultimately restoring *kan* and *li* to *qian* and *kun*.

Only the superior adept employs intention to dwell in the body and gather the mind, causing body, mind, and intention to merge into one, unwavering and unceasing. Nurturing them to perfection, one attains such grandeur as to generate beings—is this not the myriad things being complete within oneself, the three realms returning to one body?

chunks.original_text: 更不必疏明震兑艮巽，复障心目。 下节即申明取填之说。 按，花叶蒂枝，皆为一本所生。 “金华开汞叶”，是一坎一离，水中起火也； “玉蒂长铅枝”，亦是一坎一离，火里栽莲也。 学者积久修持，先由小周天玉液还丹，结成内丹； 再过大周天金液还丹，结成大丹：也不出一坎一离，一乾一坤之作用。 譬之华叶枝蒂，同生一本，无有二体也。 既过大周天，功圆行满，则可长生久视，与天地同其寿，日月同其明，所得坎离作用之结果，可永垂诸不朽。 有此乾坤，即有此坎离也。 且也六合之内，荒古以来，大至宇宙开基，小至朝菌夕蚓，何莫非阴阳所陶铸，即不外坎离二者之作用。 大觉金仙，则其作用之最神者也。 故乾坤有时入于混沌，金仙可以超混沌而长存，太上已经七次混沌，历过七劫而无恙。 至今日之乾坤，则早非昔日之乾坤矣。 故自其变、不变者而言之，可谓乾坤曾几何时即须历劫，而大觉至圣之坎离作用，则永永不曾有间息也。 《易》曰：“天行健，君子以自强不息。 ”（见《易·乾卦》）不息则久矣。 沐浴防危险，抽添自谨持。 都来三万刻，差失恐毫厘。 （彭注）一年十二月，共计三万六千刻，攒簇一日之内，十二月之中。 十月行火候，阳生则采药于子宫，而使之逆升，谓之抽铅； 阴生则退火于午位，而使之顺降，谓之添汞。 其余两月，卯月益水安金，酉月行火止水。 只行水候，不行火候，谓之沐浴。 以卯月生中有杀，酉月杀中有生，防火之太燥而有危险也。 除两月六千刻，止十月三万刻，故曰“都来三万刻”。 三万刻工夫，毫厘有差，则阴阳差互。 惟既防危险，又知谨持，专心致志，于一圈之中，与动俱现，与静俱隐。 期年可以养成婴儿，而为超脱之仙矣。 （闵释）惟是主敬存诚，斯其为物不贰。 苟有用之者，期月而已可也，故曰“都来三万刻”也。 差失之恐者，只须纯一无间，三万刻中无一息之停，非有别项差失可虑也。 《易》曰：“不恒其德，或承之羞。 ”（见《易·恒卦》）是所恐也。

Nor is there need to elaborate on *zhen*, *dui*, *gen*, and *xun*, lest they obstruct the mind’s eye. The following section will expound upon the method of "filling and replenishing."

Consider how flowers, leaves, stems, and buds all arise from a single root. *"Golden blossoms bloom on mercury leaves"*—this is the interplay of one *kan* and one *li*, fire rising from water. *"Jade buds lengthen lead branches"*—this, too, is the interplay of one *kan* and one *li*, lotus planted in fire. Through long and steadfast cultivation, the adept first completes the *Small Celestial Cycle* of *Jade Fluid Returned Elixir*, forming the inner elixir; then proceeds to the *Great Celestial Cycle* of *Golden Fluid Returned Elixir*, forming the great elixir—yet all remains the operation of one *kan* and one *li*, one *qian* and one *kun*. Like flowers, leaves, stems, and buds growing from a single root, there is no second body.

Once the *Great Celestial Cycle* is completed and merit is perfected, one may attain longevity and lasting vision, sharing the lifespan of heaven and earth, the radiance of sun and moon. The fruits of *kan* and *li*’s operation may thus endure forever. Where there is *qian* and *kun*, there is *kan* and *li*. Moreover, within the six directions, from primordial antiquity to the present—whether the vast foundation of the cosmos or the ephemeral morning mushroom and evening earthworm—all are molded by yin and yang, and none transcend the operation of *kan* and *li*. The enlightened golden immortal represents their most wondrous application.

Thus, while *qian* and *kun* may at times dissolve into primordial chaos, the golden immortal transcends chaos and endures eternally. The Most High has already passed through seven epochs of chaos, surviving seven kalpas unscathed. The *qian* and *kun* of today are no longer those of the past. From the perspective of change and constancy, one might say that *qian* and *kun* must undergo kalpas in but a brief span, yet the operation of *kan* and *li* in the great sage’s attainment never ceases for even a moment.

The *Book of Changes* states: *"The Way of heaven moves with vigor; the noble person strengthens the self without ceasing."* (See *Zhouyi*, *Qian* hexagram.) To cease not is to endure.

Bathing guards against peril,
Withdrawal and addition require careful vigilance.
In all thirty thousand moments,
A hair’s deviation may cause loss.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
A year has twelve months, totaling thirty-six thousand *ke*. These are gathered within a single day and the twelve months. For ten months, the fire timing is practiced: when yang arises, medicine is gathered from the *zi* palace and made to ascend in reverse—this is called "withdrawing lead"; when yin arises, fire is withdrawn at the *wu* position and made to descend in sequence—this is called "adding mercury." In the remaining two months, the third month nourishes water to stabilize metal, and the ninth month applies fire to restrain water. Only the water timing is practiced, not the fire timing—this is called "bathing." In the third month, life arises amid destruction; in the ninth month, destruction arises amid life. This guards against the peril of fire’s excessive dryness. Excluding the two months and six thousand *ke*, only ten months and thirty thousand *ke* remain, hence the saying, "In all thirty thousand moments."

Within these thirty thousand *ke* of effort, even a hair’s deviation may disrupt yin and yang. Only by guarding against peril and exercising careful vigilance, focusing the mind and intent, can one appear with movement and vanish with stillness in every cycle. After a full year, the infant may be nurtured, becoming an immortal of transcendence.

*(Min’s Explanation)*
Only through reverence and sincerity does the thing remain undivided. If one applies this method, a single month suffices—hence the saying, "In all thirty thousand moments." The fear of deviation lies solely in the need for absolute unity without interruption; within thirty thousand *ke*, there must be no pause for even a single breath. There is no other deviation to fear.

The *Book of Changes* states: *"If one does not constantly maintain virtue, disgrace may follow."* (See *Zhouyi*, *Heng* hexagram.) This is what is to be feared.

chunks.original_text: 按，丹道有“子午抽添”、“卯酉沐浴”，以进阳火抽铅，以退阴符添汞，是宜谨慎将事焉。 及至时逢卯酉，刑德临门，阴阳各半，即须沐浴以防危险，而免差池。 吾人于合丹火候，有最要之诀在也。 凡人情识用事，当夫外景现前，必易惹起情想，或生喜悦，或生惊怯。 时逢沐浴，仍宜含光默默，不起情尘，就以中央真意为我主宰，退识神而用元神，任其自然，不识不知，顺帝之则。 《大学》曰：“安而后虑，虑而后得，其严乎！ ”《入药镜》曰：“水怕干，火怕寒。 毫发差，不成丹。 ”三万刻中，应时时戒慎，以防有失也。 夫妇交会时，洞房云雨作。 一载产（一作生）个儿，个个会骑鹤。 （彭注）夫妇者，身中真阴真阳也。 真阴真阳，得真土为媒娉，结为夫妇，洞房交结，云腾雨施。 一年之内，十月怀胎，两月沐浴，胎儿气足，产个婴儿，便跨鹤自泥丸宫出矣。 九载生九个，故曰“个个”，千百亿化身，非真有九个也。 婴儿为孩，亥子交会，合为“孩”字，此结胎下手之要也。 （闵释）夫即乾也，妇即坤也，洞房即“非凡窍”也。 发明第七节大旨，总言身心得意，以擒以制，而混化之，以与天地参，皆至诚之一用也。 譬诸夫妇，得媒以婚以嫁，而交会之，以生育婴儿。 此特由“非凡窍”生，得非凡儿，全在逆之斯仙耳。 不若世间夫妇道，顺之成人也。 今再为揭喻一说：真土为意，譬诸媒也； 真铅为身，譬诸夫也； 真汞为心譬诸妇也。 得媒合夫妇，以成室家，譬诸举意混身、心，而凝至道。 然耶？ 否耶？

Now, in the Dao of the Elixir, there are the methods of "drawing and adding at midnight and noon" and "bathing at dawn and dusk," whereby one advances the Yang fire to draw forth lead and retreats the Yin tally to add mercury—these must be undertaken with utmost care. When the time arrives at dawn and dusk, with the forces of punishment and virtue at the gate, Yin and Yang each occupying half, one must bathe to guard against danger and avoid error.

In the firing times of compounding the Elixir, there lies a most crucial secret. Whenever human emotions and perceptions take hold, and external visions appear before one, they inevitably stir emotional thoughts—either joy or fear. At the time of bathing, one should still contain one’s light and remain silent, free from emotional dust. Let the true intention at the center serve as one’s master, withdrawing the consciousness of the acquired mind to employ the primordial spirit, allowing it to follow its nature, unaware and unknowing, in accordance with the Emperor’s principle.

*The Great Learning* states: *"Only after attaining tranquility can one deliberate; only after deliberation can one achieve success—how strict this is!"* *The Mirror for Compounding the Medicine* says: *"Water fears drying, fire fears cold. The slightest deviation, and the Elixir will not form."* Throughout the thirty thousand *ke*, one must remain constantly vigilant to prevent any loss.

When husband and wife unite, the bridal chamber brings forth clouds and rain. After a year, a child is born—each one able to ride the crane.

*(Peng’s Annotation)*
Husband and wife refer to the true Yin and true Yang within the body. When true Yin and true Yang, with true Earth as their matchmaker, become husband and wife, they unite in the bridal chamber, clouds rising and rain descending. Within a year—ten months of gestation and two months of bathing—the infant’s qi is full, and the baby is born, riding the crane forth from the Mud-Pill Palace. Nine years produce nine children—hence "each one"—yet these are a thousand, ten thousand, or a hundred million transformations, not truly nine in number. The infant is called a *child* (孩), formed by the union of *hai* (亥) and *zi* (子)—this is the essential point for initiating the embryo’s formation.

*(Min’s Explanation)*
The husband is Qian, the wife is Kun, and the bridal chamber is the "extraordinary aperture." This elucidates the main purport of the seventh section, speaking generally of the union of body and mind through intention, their capture and control, and their blending into oneness to stand alongside Heaven and Earth—all through the single function of utmost sincerity. It may be likened to husband and wife, who, with a matchmaker to arrange their marriage, unite to bear a child. Yet this child is born from the "extraordinary aperture," and thus is no ordinary infant; it is only by reversing the flow that one becomes an immortal. This differs from the way of worldly husband and wife, who follow the natural course to produce a human being.

Let me further illustrate with an analogy: true Earth is intention, likened to the matchmaker; true lead is the body, likened to the husband; true mercury is the heart, likened to the wife. With the matchmaker uniting husband and wife to form a household, it is like employing intention to blend body and mind, thereby congealing the supreme Dao. Is this so? Or is it not?

I venture to submit this for your consideration, Master!

Now, in the worldly union of man and woman, the two and five essences conjoin, following the natural course to give birth to a human being—this is the way of the common. Yet the Dao of immortality bears a resemblance to this. One should take the radiant maiden of the Li Palace and pair her with the golden lord of the Kan Mansion, sending them into the Yellow Chamber of the central cavern, where they may grow intimate and affectionate, becoming clouds and rain. Thereby, the numinous medicine is matched, the sacred embryo congeals, and after ten months of nurturing, qi is perfected within and spirit is complete, giving birth to the sacred child and divine descendants. In days to come, they will ride cranes in carefree flight, entering earth and penetrating heaven—all the work of this sacred child and divine descendants.

The *Wuzhen Pian* states:
*"The golden lord is originally the son of the eastern house,
Raised in the western neighbor’s home, born of a borrowed body.
Recognize and summon him to return and be nurtured,
Pair him with the radiant maiden to forge marital bonds."*

It also says:
*"The radiant maiden wanders in all directions,
Her forward steps must be short, her backward steps long.
Returning, she enters the Yellow Woman’s abode,
Wed to the golden lord as his aged husband."*

This, too, conveys the same meaning. Patriarch Zhang used the natural course to illustrate the reverse cultivation, employed the way of humanity to clarify the Dao of immortality, making it easier for learners to comprehend—truly a case of "a Buddha’s mouth with a grandmother’s heart." Scholars should ponder deeply and reflect upon this repeatedly.

The *Four Hundred Characters* comprises twenty sections, unified throughout by the theme of "the essence of Kan and Li." This essence of Kan and Li arises within the mysterious aperture, which is none other than the medicinal substances of lead and mercury. It is born from emptiness and stillness, and only when body and mind are utterly serene and unmoving does the mysterious aperture first emerge. From beginning to end, all hinges upon these two lines—readers must not overlook them.

**Tenth Lecture: Yang Arises in Emptiness, Stillness Reaches Its Extremity and Reverses**
*Without Gathering, Yet Gathering—Knowing When to Stop Is Enough*
