chunks.original_text: 肝藏魂，魂即中阴也，入我中宫神室，为我主人。 夜藏于肝，目虽闭而不漏，而神仍动，故昼有所思，夜必有所梦，盖静为魂，而动为神，肝属木，为东方生生之气，木性主动，惟动方能生化。 夜之梦也，其人胆怯，则梦遇惊险； 肝木上炎，则梦多烦扰而夜卧不宁：此皆神魂不安之所致也。 欲有以安之，莫若不藏之于肝，而藏之于肾。 肾，水也，为坎，坎中本有元神，识神并入其中，使居至深之地，故称“秉心塞渊”。 夜藏于肾，即等藏于耳。 耳与肾通，肾为耳之内府，耳为肾之外府。 孙悟空藏金箍棒，不用则变针而藏之于耳，与藏之于肾一也。 倘能调息，而心息相依，则藏神于耳，在内入耳，在外为真土。 古谓“耳听无弦琴”，又曰“耳听钧天大乐”，又曰“妙音观世音”、“梵音海潮音”，皆心息调和后，耳内所听得之妙音也。 下手做工夫，此为最要。 孙悟空，元神也； 金箍棒，元气也，神气相合，而藏于耳。 盖耳目可以动静分，目是动，耳是静。 医家以耳后为“命门”，因耳通“命门”之故； 目前为“风门”，风门即浩气之门也。 气由耳出入，即为仙，相法曾有此说。 耳门为“风门”，脑后为“风府”，修道者有“脑后生风”之事。 “风府”为助气之府，呼吸气以到此为“风府”。 《西游记》观世音菩萨，赐孙悟空“叫天天应，叫地地灵”，以三片杨柳叶变作三根“救命毫毛”,放在行者脑后。 所谓“叫天天应,叫地地灵”,即呼接天根，吸接地根也。 杨为柔木，即巽木也； 三为《乾卦》，三根毫毛，即元气也； 放在脑后，即取坎填离，变《离卦》为《乾卦》。 此事在收复龙马以后，龙马即真息真意也。 唐僧得龙马，方可往西天。 “终日乾乾”，即真息开阖。 三根救命毫毛为乾，亦为真息，龙马亦是真息。 初做工时，应由喝音入耳入手。 观世音菩萨得道，非由观心，实以观音而得道。 不特观世音，即诸佛亦多以此而得。 故文殊菩萨曰：“匪为观世音，我亦从兹证。 ” 观音何以为女相？ 《黄庭经》曰“耳为妖女”，因耳主静也。 夫离为中女，坎为中男。 耳亦为坎，何以为女？ 不知坎属水主静，亦有女性，所以耳为娇女，观音现女相。 《清净经》曰：“天动地静，男动女静”。 男象天，女象地。 亦取其静也。 神魂归耳，则心自静矣。 另有一附属之事应讲者，魂藏于肝，肝连于胆，胆藏识，有识者胆大，无识者胆小。 肝胆皆属木，魂藏于肝，而会胆之识，为识神，肝胆一也，所以曰“五脏”。 胆为脏，亦为腑，就人身而论，胆居虚危之地。 吕祖曰“虚危穴”，又曰“进火工夫牛斗危”，此穴在身内为胆下，身外为阴跷。 阴跷及胆,皆虚危也,肝胆相随。 兹以略图明之。 《参同契》曰：“旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同。
chunks.translated_text: The liver stores the *hun*-soul, and the *hun* is the intermediate state of consciousness; it enters my central palace, the chamber of spirit, to become my master. At night, it is stored in the liver, and though the eyes are closed without leakage, the spirit still stirs—thus, what one ponders by day must manifest in dreams by night. For stillness belongs to the *hun*, while movement belongs to the spirit. The liver pertains to Wood, the generative *qi* of the East; the nature of Wood is movement, and only through movement can transformation arise. In nightly dreams, if one’s gall is timid, one dreams of encounters with peril; if Liver-Wood flames upward, one dreams of vexation and restless sleep—all caused by the disquiet of spirit and *hun*. To pacify them, nothing surpasses storing them not in the liver but in the kidneys. The kidneys pertain to Water and are Kan; within Kan originally resides the primordial spirit, and when the consciousness-spirit merges into it, dwelling in the deepest place, this is called “holding fast to the heart and filling the abyss.” Storing at night in the kidneys is equivalent to storing in the ears. The ears connect with the kidneys: the kidneys are the inner treasury of the ears, and the ears are the outer treasury of the kidneys. When Sun Wukong stores his golden-hooped staff, he transforms it into a needle and hides it in his ear—this is no different from storing it in the kidneys. If one can regulate the breath so that heart and breath interdepend, then storing the spirit in the ears means that inwardly it enters the ear, and outwardly it becomes true Earth. The ancients spoke of “listening to the stringless zither,” or “hearing the grand music of the heavens,” or “the wondrous sound of Avalokiteśvara,” or “the ocean-tide sound of Brahmā’s voice”—all are the wondrous sounds heard within the ear after harmonizing heart and breath. In beginning the work, this is most essential. Sun Wukong is the primordial spirit; the golden-hooped staff is primordial *qi*. When spirit and *qi* unite, they are stored in the ear. For the ears and eyes can be divided by movement and stillness: the eyes are movement, the ears are stillness. Physicians regard the area behind the ears as the “Gate of Destiny,” because the ears connect with the “Gate of Destiny”; the area before the eyes is the “Gate of Wind,” the gate of vast *qi*. When *qi* issues and enters through the ears, this is immortality—physiognomists have long held this view. The ear-gate is the “Gate of Wind,” and the nape of the neck is the “Mansion of Wind.” In Daoist practice, there is the matter of “wind arising behind the brain.” The “Mansion of Wind” is the treasury that assists *qi*; when the breath of exhalation and inhalation reaches this point, it is called the “Mansion of Wind.” In *Journey to the West*, Avalokiteśvara bestows upon Sun Wukong the power of “when he calls to Heaven, Heaven responds; when he calls to Earth, Earth answers,” and with three willow leaves transforms them into three “life-saving hairs,” placing them behind the traveler’s head. This “when he calls to Heaven, Heaven responds; when he calls to Earth, Earth answers” means exhaling to connect with the root of Heaven and inhaling to connect with the root of Earth. Willow is a yielding Wood, which is Xun-Wood; three is the *Qian* hexagram. The three hairs are primordial *qi*; placing them behind the head is taking from Kan to fill Li, transforming the *Li* hexagram into the *Qian* hexagram. This occurs after subduing the dragon-horse, for the dragon-horse is true breath and true intent. Only when the Tang Monk obtains the dragon-horse can he journey to the Western Heaven. “All day long, *Qian* acts with ceaseless vigilance”—this is the opening and closing of true breath. The three life-saving hairs are *Qian*, and also true breath; the dragon-horse is likewise true breath. When first undertaking the work, one should begin by directing the sound of the shout into the ear. Avalokiteśvara attained the Dao not through contemplating the mind but through contemplating sound. Not only Avalokiteśvara, but many buddhas have attained the Dao by this means. Thus Mañjuśrī said: “Were it not for Avalokiteśvara, I too would have realized it thus.” Why is Avalokiteśvara depicted in female form? The *Huangting Jing* says, “The ears are the enchanting maiden,” for the ears govern stillness. Now, *Li* is the middle daughter, and *Kan* is the middle son. The ears also pertain to *Kan*—why then are they female? It is not known that *Kan* pertains to Water and governs stillness, and stillness also has a feminine aspect; thus the ears are the delicate maiden, and Avalokiteśvara appears in female form. The *Qingjing Jing* says: “Heaven moves, Earth is still; the male moves, the female is still.” The male symbolizes Heaven, the female symbolizes Earth—both take stillness as their nature. When spirit and *hun* return to the ears, the heart naturally becomes still. There is another related matter that should be discussed: the *hun* is stored in the liver, and the liver connects with the gallbladder, which stores consciousness. Those with consciousness are bold; those without are timid. Both liver and gallbladder pertain to Wood. The *hun* is stored in the liver and meets the gallbladder’s consciousness, becoming the consciousness-spirit—liver and gallbladder are one, which is why they are called the “five viscera.” The gallbladder is both a *zang*-organ and a *fu*-organ. In the human body, the gallbladder resides in the precarious region of *Xu* and *Wei*. Lü Dongbin called it the “Xu-Wei cavity” and also said, “Advancing the fire in the work of Ox and Dipper.” This cavity is within the body below the gallbladder, and outside the body in the Yin Heel vessel. Both the Yin Heel and the gallbladder are *Xu-Wei*, and liver and gallbladder follow one another. Here, a brief diagram would clarify this. The *Cantong Qi* says: “Turning and bending to see and hear, opening and closing are all in harmony.”

chunks.original_text: ”现在讲修道者，有“合一会同善社”，即用“合同”两字。 后天教言，合同义亦在此也。 “其次致曲”（见《礼记·中庸》）之“曲”字，即“旋曲以视听”之“曲”字也。 视听归一，自开阖合同，合同由旋曲而来，即收视返听于玄牝之门。 曰旋曰曲,即视听于斯,而主之以神也，开合即在此矣。 “离气纳荣卫”，即收视也。 不见外物，而归于“荣卫”，因之“坎乃不用聪”矣。 曲者车一也，“旋曲以视听”，即观音之意，如此方能得真息“开阖”之“合同”。 道藏中有《洞玄灵宝定观经》，“灵宝”者，在天为灵，在地为宝。 灵宝在人曰“神”，神即天之灵，地之宝也。 曰“定观”者，惟定方能观，即观妙、观窍之谓。 起句曰：“夫欲修道，必先舍事。 ”舍事者，“外事都绝”之意，“外事”即七情六欲也。 至忠孝节义，则诚中形外，根于天性，不是外事。 “外事都绝，无与忤心。 然后安坐。 内观心气。 ”“安坐”不是色身打坐。 元神不出于窍为坐，摄澄烦恼为安坐者，本心不起是也。 本心是天心，道心，元神本心不动为安坐。 坐字二人傍土，古字两口夹土，皆是一阴一阳。 阴阳生于真土之中，以真土和阴阳即为坐。 本心不起，烦恼屏绝，方可静观，务令安静。 观者唯灭动心，不灭照心； 动心即识神，照心是慧光，元神即是真空。 慧照长明，乃不起念，谓以慧剑斩魔，魔即邪念妄意也。 但凝空心，不凝住心，凝住心即着相矣。 《金刚经》曰：“应如是降伏其心。 ”又曰：“应无所住而生其心。 ”心不着即无所住矣，亦即道心。 《金刚经》语与《定观经》语同意，即是去“四相”。 四相灭即“无住”，无住之心，即是道心，是真意。 《定观经》下文，皆解此意，可参观之。 心应以无事为真宅，有事为应迹，所以常静常应。 静即“寂然不动”，应即“感而遂通”也。 先做寂工，方能应矣。 佛家常语曰：“眼观鼻，鼻观心； 心会意，意会心。 ”观鼻即是止窍。 又《楞严经》佛告询陀罗尊者曰：“鼻端有白，汝其观之。 ”“鼻端有白”，即直下承当之意； “白”者，“虚室生白”之白也。 至静极时，方见鼻端白气； 鼻端见白即观之，经三七日，可以得道。 如鼻端无白，应先求白； 眼观鼻者，“汝其观之”之意。 “鼻观心”之观字，应读去声，观者空也。 “鼻观”即鼻下虚空，即鼻下虚空之心也。 “心会意”者，心会真意也，真意即是天心。 还虚由垂帘凝耳，缄舌调息下手，即《参同契》“经营养鄞鄂”之意。 “经营”实为凝神成躯也，由一点而积久光大，遂能凝神以成躯。 心为“灵山”、“灵台”，灵台下有“灵沼”。 灵台即“绛宫”“应谷”是也，灵沼即两肾中间之“命门”。 “灵台”“灵沼”，与民同乐，“民”即《大学》“在亲民”之意。 《诗经》此章（见《大雅·灵台》），含有修真之意。 又“定之方中，作于楚宫”，亦为守窍，“楚宫”为南方、离方，其中虚空。 “揆之以日，作于楚室”（见《诗·墉·定之方中》），观此“日”字，更可明了矣。 五经多修道寓言，后人不觉故耳。 还虚之工，即经营“灵台”后，筑“灵沼”之事，取坎填离也。 前为九还，后为七返；
chunks.translated_text:
Now, for those who cultivate the Dao, there is the "Union of One Society," which employs the term "uniting as one." The teachings of later heavens also hold this meaning of "uniting as one." The phrase "next, bend with subtlety" (from the *Record of Rites·Doctrine of the Mean*)—the character *qu* ("bend") here is the same *qu* as in "turning and bending to see and hear." When seeing and hearing are returned to unity, opening and closing naturally harmonize. This harmony arises from turning and bending, which is to withdraw vision and return hearing to the Gate of the Mysterious Female. To "turn" and to "bend" is to direct seeing and hearing here, governed by spirit—opening and closing occur precisely in this way.

"Separating qi to receive *ying* and *wei*" is the act of withdrawing vision. Not perceiving external things, one returns to *ying* and *wei*, and thus "the *kan* no longer employs hearing." *Qu* is the unity of the chariot; "turning and bending to see and hear" embodies the meaning of Avalokiteśvara. Only thus can one attain the true "harmony" of "opening and closing."

In the Daoist Canon, there is the *Scripture of Stabilized Contemplation of the Numinous Treasure of the Cavern Mystery*. "Numinous Treasure" is numinous in heaven and precious on earth. In humans, the numinous treasure is called "spirit," which is the numinous of heaven and the treasure of earth. "Stabilized contemplation" means that only through stabilization can one contemplate—this refers to contemplating the wondrous and observing the aperture.

Its opening lines state: "Those who wish to cultivate the Dao must first relinquish affairs." To "relinquish affairs" means "to sever all external matters"—"external matters" being the seven emotions and six desires. As for loyalty, filial piety, integrity, and righteousness, these manifest sincerity outwardly, rooted in heavenly nature, and are not external matters. "Sever all external matters, and nothing will oppose the mind. Then, sit in tranquility and inwardly observe the heart’s qi."

"Sitting in tranquility" does not mean the physical body assuming a seated posture. When the original spirit does not depart from the aperture, this is "sitting." To gather and settle vexations is "sitting in tranquility"—this is when the original heart does not stir. The original heart is the heavenly heart, the Dao-heart. When the original spirit and original heart remain unmoved, this is "sitting in tranquility." The character *zuo* ("to sit") is composed of "person" beside "earth"; in the ancient form, two mouths flank the earth—both signify one yin and one yang. Yin and yang arise within true earth, and harmonizing yin and yang with true earth is "sitting." Only when the original heart does not stir and vexations are dispelled can one engage in tranquil contemplation, striving for stillness.

In contemplation, one extinguishes only the moving mind, not the illuminating mind. The moving mind is the spirit of consciousness; the illuminating mind is the light of wisdom, and the original spirit is true emptiness. When the light of wisdom shines perpetually without arising thoughts, this is wielding the sword of wisdom to slay demons—demons being deviant thoughts and deluded intentions. One should congeal the empty mind, not fixate the mind; fixating the mind is attachment to form.

The *Diamond Sutra* states: "Thus should one subdue the mind." It also says: "One should give rise to the mind without abiding anywhere." When the mind does not attach, it abides nowhere—this is the Dao-heart. The words of the *Diamond Sutra* and the *Scripture of Stabilized Contemplation* share the same meaning, which is to eliminate the "four marks." When the four marks are extinguished, there is "no abiding"; the non-abiding mind is the Dao-heart, the true intention. The subsequent passages of the *Scripture of Stabilized Contemplation* all explicate this meaning, and one may refer to them.

The heart should take non-action as its true dwelling and action as its responsive trace—thus, it is constantly still and constantly responsive. Stillness is "quiescent and unmoving"; responsiveness is "moved and thus penetrating." Only after mastering the work of quiescence can one respond.

A common Buddhist saying goes: "The eye observes the nose; the nose observes the heart. The heart meets the intention; the intention meets the heart." Observing the nose is to halt at the aperture. Furthermore, in the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*, the Buddha told the Venerable Sundarananda: "At the tip of your nose, there is whiteness—you should observe it." "Whiteness at the tip of the nose" signifies direct acceptance; "whiteness" is the whiteness born of the empty chamber. Only at the extreme of stillness does one see the white qi at the tip of the nose. Observing this whiteness for twenty-one days, one may attain the Dao. If no whiteness appears at the tip of the nose, one should first seek it. "The eye observes the nose" embodies the meaning of "you should observe it." The *guan* in "the nose observes the heart" should be read in the departing tone—*guan* means emptiness. "Nose observes" refers to the emptiness below the nose, which is the heart of the emptiness below the nose.

"Heart meets intention" means the heart meets the true intention—the true intention is the heavenly heart. Returning to emptiness begins with lowering the eyelids, congealing the ears, sealing the tongue, and regulating the breath—this is the meaning of the *Cantong Qi*'s "managing and nourishing the *yin* and *e*". "Managing" is truly congealing spirit into a body, which, from a single point accumulated over time, expands and thus enables the congealing of spirit to form a body.

The heart is the "Spiritual Mountain" and the "Spiritual Terrace." Below the Spiritual Terrace lies the "Spiritual Pond." The Spiritual Terrace is the "Crimson Palace" and the "Responsive Valley"; the Spiritual Pond is the "Gate of Life" between the two kidneys. The "Spiritual Terrace" and "Spiritual Pond" rejoice with the people—"people" here follows the meaning of "cherishing the people" in the *Great Learning*.

This chapter of the *Book of Songs* (from the *Greater Elegantiae·Spiritual Terrace*) contains the meaning of cultivating the true. The lines "When the Dipper is aligned, build the Chu Palace" also refer to guarding the aperture—"Chu Palace" is the south, the *li* direction, which is empty within. "Measuring it by the sun, build the Chu Chamber" (from the *Odes·Yong·When the Dipper is Aligned*)—observing this character *ri* ("sun") further clarifies the meaning. The Five Classics contain many allegories of Dao cultivation, which later generations failed to recognize.

The work of returning to emptiness is the matter of managing the "Spiritual Terrace" and constructing the "Spiritual Pond"—this is drawing from *kan* to fill *li*. The former is the nine returns; the latter is the seven reversions.

chunks.original_text: 不过还虚时之九还，与真正大还，稍有不同耳。 大还为乾坤相交，九还为金木并； 阳气到身充足，内则水火自交，即七返也。 水火金木，皆不离土，所以从土下手，须先得真意。 土为水之堤防，火亦由土而制止，亦以土为堤防也。 水无土则滥，火无土则猛，必用土以调和之，而水火交。 金本土生而成，木则生于水而长于土。 金木本不交，由土勾引，乃可相交。 故必二土成圭，始得内而水火自交，外而金木相并，内九还而外七返。 火为神，水为气，水火交亦即神气交也。 必得土为堤防，内之神气始固，以土有制止水火之功也。 金木外生，金为虚空中阳气，因土之真空而生，由我后天中返出之先天炁也。 木为本性元神，静极而复。 金木由外土成立，水火由内土成立。 外而金木并，内而水火交，实由内外两土，内外两空也。 外忘其身为坤土，为外玄牝； 内忘其心，而一念不起为净土，为内玄牝。 古云“念头动处为玄牝”，即不起一念而纯净之内玄牝也。 其象如空○，即内玄关也； 外忘其身而纯坤，其象亦如空○，即外玄关也。 得此两玄关成立，而七返九还之功可成矣。 学者不能到身心两忘，内外交修之地，可先从外纯坤做起，后到内纯净地步。 外纯坤做工之效验，为虚中还阳，其初一点微阳到身，四肢酥麻，渐渐全身酥麻，阳气充足，外阳勃举； 做到内纯净，为返我元神，阳动而能觉、能采、能封、能炼，自然火候，不假人为也。 净土即《西游记》之沙悟净也。 先外身纯坤，得一土为戊土； 后内心纯净，得一土为己土：二土合而成圭，为沙悟净与宝杖。 《西游记》先得悟空，后得悟能，最后得悟净，即此意也。 还虚工夫，中有九还，阳气到身，微觉有动，即其机也。 欲得真正九还，须待真阳感到身上，阳气充足。 吕祖曰：“七返还丹，在人先须炼己待时。 ”时即“活子”、“活午”也。 七返还丹，即七返九还之意； 炼己即炼己还虚也。 炼己者炼己土，以取先天戊土，由虚空中取得真阳。 惟阳一瞬即变，须有法使之留住。 既由还虚招摄阳气前来，须有法采取此阳。 此为先天大道，要必先入混沌之境，而后得之。 先天，为天地未生人物以前之境象，必由混沌以返太极也。 至末后粉碎虚空还虚，则尚在混沌之先，为天地未开辟以前之境象。 所谓“象帝之先”（见《老子》）即先天之先天也。 最初还虚之先天，是由两仪返太极，末后还虚，先天之先天，是由太极返无极，是之谓“先天大道”。 先天者，一也。 神气合一，亦即阴阳合一，混混沌沌。 若由一而二，则由先天入后天矣。 先天之道，在会三归一，其初即三家相见：神一也，气二也。 玄牝之门三也。 以心中之神，与身中之气，合在一中宫玄牝之门，是即三家相见，会三家为一家，而混沌成矣。 先天之道，始终在会三归一，神气相合，乾坤坎离相交。 于是发生造化，是即真土真意发生之时也，方能招得外来先天之一炁，是即“一画开天”之象也。 然则真意真土，究如何而成立？ 其道在一念不起，一意不散，方可得真意真土，此即《金刚经》所谓“应无所住而生其心”是也。 初学未易到此，要在先求诚意。 诚意亦未易做到，则有“其次致曲”工夫。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet the nine returns during the work of returning to emptiness differ slightly from the true Great Return. The Great Return is the intercourse of Qian and Kun, while the nine returns are the union of Metal and Wood. When yang qi fills the body, water and fire naturally merge within—this is the seven reversions. Water, fire, metal, and wood all depend on Earth; thus, one must begin with Earth and first attain true intent. Earth serves as the dike for water, and fire is also restrained by Earth, which likewise acts as its dike. Without Earth, water overflows; without Earth, fire rages—only with Earth can they be harmonized, allowing water and fire to merge. Metal is born of Earth and completed by it, while Wood arises from water and grows through Earth. Metal and Wood do not naturally unite; only through Earth’s mediation can they interact. Therefore, only when the two Earths form a *gui* does water and fire merge within, and Metal and Wood unite without—nine returns within and seven reversions without. Fire is spirit, water is qi; their union is thus the intercourse of spirit and qi. Only with Earth as the dike can the inner spirit and qi be stabilized, for Earth possesses the power to restrain water and fire.

Metal and Wood arise externally: Metal is the yang qi within emptiness, born from Earth’s true emptiness, the primordial qi returned from the postnatal to the prenatal. Wood is the original spirit of one’s nature, still at its utmost and then revived. Metal and Wood are established by external Earth, while water and fire are established by internal Earth. The union of Metal and Wood without and the intercourse of water and fire within are truly the work of internal and external Earths—internal and external emptiness. Externally, one forgets the body as Kun Earth, the outer Mysterious Female; internally, one forgets the heart, allowing not a single thought to arise, as Pure Earth, the inner Mysterious Female. As the ancients said, “Where the thought moves is the Mysterious Female”—this is the inner Mysterious Female, pure and thoughtless. Its image is like emptiness ○, the inner Mysterious Pass. Externally, forgetting the body to become pure Kun, its image is also like emptiness ○, the outer Mysterious Pass. With these two Mysterious Passes established, the work of seven reversions and nine returns may be accomplished.

Scholars who cannot yet attain the state of forgetting both body and heart, of cultivating both internally and externally, may first practice becoming pure Kun externally, then progress to the stage of internal purity. The verification of external pure Kun practice is the return of yang within emptiness: initially, a faint yang arrives in the body, causing the limbs to tingle and numb, gradually spreading until the whole body tingles and yang qi is abundant, and external yang stirs. Attaining internal purity is the return of one’s original spirit—yang stirs, and one can sense, gather, seal, and refine it, following the natural fire phases without artificial effort. Pure Earth is Sha Wujing in *Journey to the West*.

First, externally, the body becomes pure Kun, obtaining one Earth as Wu Earth; later, internally, the heart becomes pure, obtaining one Earth as Ji Earth. The two Earths combine to form a *gui*, like Sha Wujing and his treasure staff. *Journey to the West* first attains Wukong, then Wuneng, and finally Wujing—this is the meaning. In the work of returning to emptiness, within the nine returns, when yang qi arrives in the body and a subtle stirring is felt, this is the mechanism. To achieve the true nine returns, one must await the true yang’s response in the body, when yang qi is abundant.

Lü Zu said: “To refine the seven-reversion elixir, one must first refine the self and await the time.” The “time” refers to the “living zi” and “living wu.” The seven-reversion elixir is the meaning of seven reversions and nine returns; refining the self is refining the self to return to emptiness. Refining the self means refining the self’s Earth to obtain prenatal Wu Earth, drawing true yang from emptiness. Yet yang transforms in an instant, so one must have a method to retain it. Having summoned yang qi through returning to emptiness, one must have a method to gather this yang. This is the primordial Great Dao, which must first enter the state of chaos before it can be attained.

The primordial is the state before heaven and earth gave birth to beings; one must return from chaos to the Supreme Ultimate. At the final stage of pulverizing emptiness to return to emptiness, one goes even beyond chaos, to the state before heaven and earth were opened. The “before the image of the Emperor” (*Laozi*) is the primordial before the primordial. The initial primordial of returning to emptiness is the return from the Two Modes to the Supreme Ultimate; the final return to emptiness, the primordial before the primordial, is the return from the Supreme Ultimate to the Non-Ultimate—this is the “primordial Great Dao.” The primordial is the One. The union of spirit and qi is also the union of yin and yang, in utter chaos. If the One divides into two, one enters the postnatal from the prenatal.

The primordial Dao lies in uniting the three into one. Initially, this is the meeting of the three families: spirit is one, qi is two, and the gate of the Mysterious Female is three. Uniting the spirit in the heart with the qi in the body at the central palace of the Mysterious Female’s gate is the meeting of the three families, merging them into one, and chaos is achieved. The primordial Dao, from beginning to end, lies in uniting the three into one, the union of spirit and qi, the intercourse of Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li. Then transformation arises—this is when true Earth and true intent emerge, enabling the summoning of the primordial qi from without, the image of “a single stroke opening heaven.” Yet how are true intent and true Earth established? The Dao lies in not a single thought arising, not a single intent scattering—only then can true intent and true Earth be attained. This is what the *Diamond Sutra* means by “giving rise to the mind without abiding anywhere.”

Beginners may find this difficult to attain; one must first seek sincerity of intent. Even sincerity is not easily achieved, so there is the work of “proceeding from the indirect.”

The work of returning to emptiness is the matter of managing the "Spiritual Terrace" and constructing the "Spiritual Pond"—this is drawing from *kan* to fill *li*. The former is the nine returns; the latter is the seven reversions.

chunks.original_text: 下手在专一，自能一意不散。 一意不散在外也，与在内之一念不起有别。 专一者，即视于斯，听于斯，调息于斯，专住于一而不分之谓。 调息即观息，有止观之义，此中又有刻漏武火。 刻漏者，有点滴之数也，亦并不是以数记息，即“喝音入耳”之意，以耳听息，即点数也，如刻漏之一点一滴，须以耳听之也。 仍为观音之法。 不过略取其意，也非以数目暗记其息也。 《悟真篇》曰：“眼见不如耳见，口说争如鼻说！ ”眼、耳、口、鼻，同归一意，方归于一。 “旋曲以视听”，首尾武，中间文，始用武火，即以耳听息，有一点微意之谓。 所谓“专一”、“致曲”，皆一事也。 不是守一窍，不是用口，亦不由心意，以神发纵，由耳听息之谓也。 自然心息相依，神气相合，而一意不散矣。 语曰“知而不守是工夫”，盖谓“抱一”而非守一。 抱者，以两耳回合相抱之意。 若以意相守，即落存想； 想即生念，而不能空矣。 “喝音入耳”之说最妙，试细参之。 《参同契》曰：“旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同。 ”“合同”即调也，即一开一阖、匀调之意。 “为己之枢辖”，枢者，门枢也； 车有车辖，辖中有一木，木中有钉，使转动不落枢辖，即不散之意。 以耳听息，方能开阖合同，匀调不散，有如枢辖。 五官皆入气中，识神不至外驰，“动静”皆如此，而“不竭穷”矣。 至此方能“离气入荣卫”，荣卫即气血也。 气聚而通耳，亦可不听外来之声，“兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙”，而神自不散。 “寝寐神相抱”者，静中之神气合一，神宰气而行也； 动静皆虚，而归混沌也。 “觉悟候存亡”者，时至神知，而能觉悟，知“活子”之临，而以不采采之也。 坎中“真人”“浮游”“而守规中”，时时或上或下，或出或入，元神上下于三谷，黄庭一路皆玄关。 从玄牝之门，到阴跷一窍，皆为“规中”，上下有两“中”字。 上下两中，连贯以一，即“吾道一以贯之”（见《论语·里仁》）之意也。 如此之一意不散，方能一念不起。 若有意守玄牝之门，念仍续起不止也。 此非用“听”字不为功，唯听则可一念不起也。 “命”字从一、人、口、耳四字而成。 口耳合一，方能得命。 口耳相并，即以耳听息之象。 通都大邑，都邑皆从耳字，观世音由耳入道，最为正道，耳之重要可知矣。 耳为坎，口为兑，兑为少女，亦为金。 曰“求之于兑”，曰“陷入坎中，而求之于坎”，皆以求金也。 《坎》、《兑》两卦，三阴三阳，坎兑要变为乾坤，成《地天泰卦》。 以《兑》之上爻，为《坎》之中爻，即为《泰》矣。 泰者，“宇泰定”也。 从还虚如此做去，方有把握。 初时阳生甚微，到身时能觉悟否未可知； 到身时能悟知，即为觉矣。 《坤》之上六，“龙战于野”，为静极、阴极之时，阴甚而阳将生，其机极微。 及阳生为《复卦》，阳在地中，不能采取，故《乾卦》为初九，即《复》之意。 今就《乾卦》解之：初九，阳藏于下，正“潜龙勿用”时也。 阳虽已动，其机甚微，故藏而不见。 谓之“勿用”。 药尚嫩也。 阳由地下而复，雷动地中，时为冬至，故“潜龙勿用”，阳在下也； 九二，“见龙”，为《地泽临》，潜藏之阳气，出而在田，田即“丹田”也。
chunks.translated_text:
To begin, focus lies in singular concentration, which naturally ensures that intent does not scatter. Yet this "intent not scattering" in the external differs from the "single thought not arising" within. Singular concentration means gazing here, listening here, regulating breath here—dwelling wholly upon one without division. Regulating breath is observing breath, embodying the meaning of *zhi* and *guan*. Within this, there is the "water clock" and "martial fire." The "water clock" refers to a count of drops, though not literally numbering the breath. It echoes the idea of "the shout entering the ear"—listening to the breath with the ear becomes the counting of drops, like the measured drip of a water clock, which must be heard with the ear. This is the method of Guanyin. Yet it merely borrows the concept, not the actual counting of breaths.

*The Wuzhen Pian* states: "The eye’s sight falls short of the ear’s; the mouth’s speech cannot match the nose’s!" Eyes, ears, mouth, and nose converge into one intent, then return to unity. "Turning and bending to see and hear"—the beginning and end are martial, the middle is civil. Initially, martial fire is employed, which means listening to the breath with the ear, implying a subtle intent. The so-called "singular concentration" and "proceeding from the indirect" are one and the same. It is not about guarding a single aperture, nor using the mouth, nor relying on the heart-mind. The spirit issues forth, and the ear listens to the breath. Naturally, heart and breath depend on each other, spirit and *qi* unite, and intent does not scatter.

As the saying goes, "Knowing without guarding is the work"—this refers to "embracing the One" rather than guarding it. "Embracing" means the two ears turning inward to hold each other. If intent is used to guard, it falls into visualization; visualization generates thoughts, and emptiness is lost. The idea of "the shout entering the ear" is most subtle—ponder it carefully.

*The Cantong Qi* says: "Turning and bending to see and hear, opening and closing all harmonize." "Harmonizing" means regulating, the meaning of one opening and one closing in even rhythm. "It is the pivot of self-cultivation." The *shu* is the door’s hinge; a cart has its linchpin, within which lies a pin, allowing it to turn without falling from the pivot—this is the meaning of not scattering. Only by listening to the breath with the ear can opening and closing harmonize, rhythm remain even, and scattering be prevented, like a well-oiled pivot. The five senses all enter the *qi*, and the discriminating spirit does not stray outward. In movement and stillness alike, this is so, and thus "exhaustion is avoided." Only then can one "leave *qi* and enter *ying* and *wei*," where *ying* and *wei* are blood and *qi*. When *qi* gathers and flows to the ear, external sounds may no longer be heard. "Closing the mouth without speech, few words follow the primordial chaos," and the spirit naturally does not scatter.

"In sleep, spirit and *qi* embrace"—in stillness, spirit and *qi* unite, with spirit governing *qi* as it moves. In movement and stillness alike, there is emptiness, returning to the primordial chaos. "Awakening to await life and death"—when the time comes, the spirit knows and awakens, recognizing the arrival of the "living midnight" yet refraining from gathering it. The "true person" within Kan "floats and drifts while guarding the center." At times rising, at times descending, at times exiting, at times entering, the original spirit moves up and down through the three valleys, with the Yellow Court’s path all being the mysterious pass. From the Gate of Mystery, to the aperture of Yin Qiao, all lie within the "center." Above and below, there are two "centers." Connecting the two centers into one embodies the meaning of "My Way is threaded by one" (*Analects*, "Li Ren"). Only with this undivided intent can a single thought not arise. If one intentionally guards the Gate of Mystery, thoughts will continue unceasingly. This cannot be achieved without the word "listen"—only by listening can a single thought not arise.

The character for "life" (*ming*) is composed of one, person, mouth, and ear. When mouth and ear unite, life is attained. Mouth and ear side by side form the image of listening to the breath with the ear. The great capital city, *dudu dayi*, is derived from the ear—Guanyin enters the Dao through the ear, which is the correct path. The importance of the ear is thus evident. The ear is Kan, the mouth is Dui. Dui is the youngest daughter, also metal. It is said, "Seek it in Dui," and "Having fallen into Kan, seek it in Kan"—both refer to seeking metal. The two trigrams Kan and Dui, with three yin and three yang lines, must transform into Qian and Kun to form the *Earth-Heaven Peace* hexagram. Taking the upper line of Dui as the middle line of Kan forms *Peace*. Peace means "the universe is settled and stable." Only by returning to emptiness in this way can one gain control.

At first, the arising yang is extremely subtle; whether one can awaken to it upon its arrival is uncertain. If one can perceive it upon arrival, that is awakening. The sixth line of Kun, "Dragons battle in the wild," marks the extreme of stillness and yin, where yin is at its peak and yang is about to arise—its mechanism is exceedingly subtle. When yang arises, it forms the *Return* hexagram, with yang in the earth, yet it cannot be gathered. Thus, the first line of Qian embodies the meaning of *Return*. Here, interpreting from the *Qian* hexagram: the first line, yang hidden below, is the time of "the hidden dragon does not act." Though yang has stirred, its mechanism is subtle, so it remains concealed and unseen—hence "does not act." The medicine is still tender. Yang returns from beneath the earth, thunder moving within the earth, at the time of the winter solstice. Thus, "the hidden dragon does not act," for yang lies below. The second line, "the dragon appears," is the *Earth-Marsh Approach* hexagram. The hidden yang *qi* emerges into the field—the field is the "cinnabar field."
chunks.overlap_context:
mage of “a single stroke opening heaven.” Yet how are true intent and true Earth established? The Dao lies in not a single thought arising, not a single intent scattering—only then can true intent and true Earth be attained. This is what the *Diamond Sutra* means by “giving rise to the mind without abiding anywhere.”

Beginners may find this difficult to attain; one must first seek sincerity of intent. Even sincerity is not easily achieved, so there is the work of “proceeding from the indirect.”

chunks.original_text: 既到玄牝门，是将感到身矣。 德施普也，谓有明德之气，如云行雨施。 到此即须招摄而留之于身，用火逼金行之功，使之满足，即《乾》之九三是也； 九三，“君子终日乾乾”，乾乾，阳也。 “终日乾乾，夕惕若厉，无咎”，到此须加工采取矣。 采以不采之采，故有朝乾夕惕之义。 乾之对面为坤，应周流六虚，以纯坤为体，须定、忘二字工夫。 定者，定于一也； 忘者，即忘身也。 觉有一点阳气，到于四肢之时，应定于一，即九二“在田”之时。 定于玄牝之门，定应稍着力，而万不可着身。 定于外方可生足阳气，定静之功，为学者常行之事。 “终日乾乾”，以光大之耳，阳足，即九四之爻矣。 “潜于渊”者，命门之阳也； 外来之阳与命门之阳相接，合同类而感通也。 所以用“武”字者，在命门中原有先天阳气，合而一之，斯有大作用出矣。 即阳气上升于鼎，而填满离宫之事也； 能填离即得明德之气，而采到真阳矣。 不定在外，则九三不能生阳； 不能忘身，则九四不能感合命门之阳。 倘忘身而或略生他念，或喜或惧，则所生阳气，仍可走失。 须大忘全忘，方能到得九五。 既到九五，则因外来阳气至足，冲动命门两肾，而外阳勃举矣。 且又上冲心府，而觉知矣。 此时采药归壶，天人合发，故有“飞龙在天”之象。 天、乾，顶也，阳气上升，填离成乾之谓也，仍宜以坤为体，以乾为用，虚心采之，否则到上九，而“亢龙有悔”矣。 九五之阳，正不老不嫩，应即采取。 所谓“采取”者，乃不采之采，不取之取，念头不动，身心两忘，方能“美在其中，而畅于四体”矣。 如稍有一念一意，则阳气未到即去，已到即化，化者，化后天也。 阳气到身，温然生春，温而不热； 至化则发汗而热，变为后天矣。 盖采时恐去，取时恐化。 阳之到也，初而四肢酥麻绵软，继而全身酥透。 初到身为活子时，既到而吾心觉知，为活午时。 活子属气，活午属神。 所谓“时至神知”，活子一到，心神觉知，已为活午时矣。 学者还虚混沌，为知白守黑； 觉知活子活午，即药产神知； 既知时至，务须定忘在外，万不可着于心身，此为最要最要者也。 阳到时虽身体舒适，犹似绵软，而四体端正，仍如山岳，巍巍不动，及于酥麻透体，欲忘而不能忘，直接发生作用，使我要忘忘不了，此时节须止火矣。 其初刻漏，武火也； 到定时仍有为武火之意； 至忘身时，则文火也； 止工时，止火也。 至此时，已工行一度，可云采到取到，应即起而散步，或微微吟诗，或轻轻读书，万不可接续再做，此为最要而不可忽者也。 止火，即封固也，不然则阳气发热而走矣； 发热发汗为走药，此最忌之事也。 阳亢则又化阴，所以“有悔”也。 于此可别为三种工夫：第一武火为“采取”，第二文火为“温养”，第三止火为“封固”。 此三种从古上真，最为秘密，而不肯轻谈，余今泄之，幸勿忽也。 最初下工采取封固，而得微阳，日积月累，金气满足，真阳旺盛，外肾方举。 即应聚火载金，驾动河车，过关上昆仑，而“利见大人”焉。 此即小周天也，与大周天之作用不同，后当详细述之。 凡做九还工夫，其水源必须至清。 亦有人以梦中阳举，至醒时因其举而做九还工夫者，此实不可。
chunks.translated_text: Having arrived at the Gate of the Mysterious Female, one is about to feel the body. The virtue is universally bestowed—this refers to the *qi* of luminous virtue, like clouds moving and rain descending. At this point, one must summon and retain it within the body, employing the work of "fire forcing metal to move," allowing it to reach fullness. This corresponds to the third line of *Qian*. The third line states, "The noble one is ceaselessly active throughout the day"—*qianqian* is yang. "Ceaselessly active throughout the day, vigilant in the evening as if facing peril, without blame." Here, one must apply effort to gather and refine. The gathering is a gathering that does not gather, hence the meaning of "vigilant in the morning and evening." The opposite of *Qian* is *Kun*; one must circulate through the six voids, taking pure *Kun* as the body. The work lies in the two words: *stabilizing* and *forgetting*. *Stabilizing* means stabilizing in the One; *forgetting* means forgetting the self. When a speck of yang *qi* reaches the four limbs, one should stabilize in the One—this is the time of the second line, "in the field." Stabilizing at the Gate of the Mysterious Female requires a slight exertion of effort, yet one must never cling to the body. Only by stabilizing externally can one generate sufficient yang *qi*. The work of stabilizing and stillness is a constant practice for the cultivator. "Ceaselessly active throughout the day" is to magnify and expand—when yang is full, it becomes the fourth line. "Concealed in the abyss" refers to the yang of the Life Gate. The external yang joins with the yang of the Life Gate, uniting like with like to resonate. The use of the word "martial" here signifies that within the Life Gate, there originally exists primordial yang *qi*. When these unite as one, great function emerges—this is the matter of yang *qi* ascending to the cauldron and filling the *Li* palace. To fill *Li* is to obtain the *qi* of luminous virtue and gather true yang. Without stabilizing externally, the third line cannot generate yang; without forgetting the self, the fourth line cannot resonate with the yang of the Life Gate. If, while forgetting the self, even a slight thought arises—whether joy or fear—the yang *qi* generated may still dissipate. Only through complete forgetting can one reach the fifth line. Having reached the fifth line, the external yang *qi* is so abundant that it stimulates the two kidneys at the Life Gate, causing the external yang to rise. It further surges upward to the Heart Palace, bringing awareness. At this time, one gathers the medicine and returns it to the crucible; heaven and human unite in activation, hence the image of "the flying dragon in the sky." Heaven and *Qian* represent the crown—yang *qi* ascends, filling *Li* to complete *Qian*. One should still take *Kun* as the body and *Qian* as the function, gathering with an empty mind. Otherwise, upon reaching the ninth line, "the exalted dragon has regret." The yang of the fifth line is neither too old nor too tender—it should be gathered immediately. The so-called "gathering" is a gathering that does not gather, a taking that does not take. Only with an unmoving mind and the forgetting of both body and self can one achieve "beauty within and harmony throughout the four limbs." If even a single thought or intention arises, the yang *qi* will depart before arriving or transform upon arrival—transformation here means reverting to the postnatal. When yang *qi* reaches the body, it brings a gentle warmth like spring, warm yet not hot. When it transforms, it induces sweating and heat, becoming postnatal. Thus, in gathering, one fears its departure; in taking, one fears its transformation. When yang arrives, first the four limbs feel supple, numb, and soft; then the entire body becomes thoroughly supple. The initial arrival at the body is the *living zi* hour; once it arrives and the heart becomes aware, it is the *living wu* hour. *Living zi* pertains to *qi*; *living wu* pertains to spirit. The saying "when the time comes, the spirit knows" means that when *living zi* arrives, the heart-spirit becomes aware—this is already the *living wu* hour. The cultivator returns to emptiness and chaos, knowing the white yet guarding the black. Awareness of *living zi* and *living wu* is the birth of medicine and the knowing of spirit. Once the time is known, one must stabilize and forget externally, never clinging to body or mind—this is of utmost importance. Though the body feels comfortable when yang arrives, as if soft and supple, the four limbs remain upright like a mountain, steadfast and unmoving. When the body becomes thoroughly supple and numb, one wishes to forget yet cannot—directly generating function, making one unable to forget even if one wishes. At this moment, one must cease the fire. The initial period is the martial fire; upon stabilizing, there remains an intention of martial fire. When forgetting the self, it becomes the civil fire; when stopping the work, it is the cessation of fire. At this point, one round of work is complete—one may say the gathering and taking are done. One should then rise and take a walk, or softly recite poetry, or gently read a book. One must not continue the practice immediately—this is of utmost importance and must not be neglected. Ceasing the fire is sealing and securing; otherwise, the yang *qi* will become hot and dissipate. Heat and sweating indicate the medicine’s departure—this is most forbidden. If yang becomes excessive, it transforms into yin, hence "regret." Here, one may distinguish three kinds of work: the first, martial fire, is "gathering and taking"; the second, civil fire, is "warming and nourishing"; the third, cessation of fire, is "sealing and securing." These three methods have been most secret among the ancient perfected ones, never lightly discussed. I now reveal them—do not treat them lightly. Initially, one practices gathering, taking, and sealing to obtain subtle yang. Through daily accumulation and monthly refinement, the metal *qi* becomes full, true yang flourishes, and the external kidney rises. Then one should gather fire to carry metal, driving the river chariot, passing through the barriers to ascend Kunlun, and "benefiting from meeting the great person." This is the Small Celestial Cycle, differing in function from the Great Celestial Cycle, which shall be detailed later. In practicing the nine-return work, the water source must be utterly pure. Some attempt to practice the nine-return work upon waking from a dream in which yang has risen—this is truly inadvisable.

chunks.original_text: 何则？ 以梦中至醒时之间，有他念否未可知。 故必有法，使睡梦中能身心两静，方可用之。 盖一有他念，则水源不清，而不可用矣。 辩水源清浊，为修道者最要之事。 如有水浊之虑，不若弃而不用之为愈矣。 此中详细，后当细述之。 先天大道，始终在还虚。 以虚感虚，全为虚里工夫。 丹法共分三品： 上品：无卦爻，无斤两，无火候。 有采取，无法度。 中品：无卦爻，有斤两，有火候，有采取，无法度。 下品：有卦爻，有斤两，有火候，有采取，有法度。 上品以定、忘，为全始全终工夫，并无火候； 守中抱一，即其火候也。 虚里还虚，身内身外，自然感应，其工夫全不落于形相也； 中品则有、无参半，比上品已着相矣； 至下品则全有形相，须按定法行持。 故上品，上士可行之，一年可成； 中品，中士行之，三年有成； 下品，下士行之，成不成未能定焉。 即幸而有成，亦甚费岁月，多为终身无成者。 盖其法为“安乐法”，只能却病，而并不能延年。 中品尚可进道，其工夫先、后天兼用，不易求效。 至下品则完全在后天形身上做工夫，比中品更下矣。 今日讲丹法者者，大半为中、下二品工夫，修道者亦不可不知也。 先天大道,却不在此三品丹法之中,惟与上品多有同者。 其工夫要甚简易，得之只在片刻。 盖火候工夫，妙在能攒簇。 攒簇一年于一月，一月于一日，一日于一时，转瞬即一周天。 只要能守住定、忘、止三字无误，必能得之。 至中品则夹杂有后天在内，兼用意觉，即已着相，而半在身上。 则末后还虚，不易超脱，难于炼心。 工夫做得甚合法度，充其量不过一地仙而已，以其工夫多在色身之上故也。 至下品，则最高能成人仙，多为却病保身之法，去仙更远。 唯上品乃为神仙也。 今吾所讲者，为道家最上一乘、无上至真之道，即先天大道也。 以太虚为鼎，太极为炉，清净为丹基，无为为丹母，性命为铅汞，定慧为水火。 定即是水，定中生慧，即为慧中发火，窒欲惩忿为水火交，以定然后能慧故也。 如《易·艮卦》之词“君子以惩忿窒欲”。 性情合一，为金木并； 以洗心涤虑为沐浴，即大忘也。 存诚定意为固济，戒、定、慧为三要，如佛家无异，修者修此三者而已。 中为玄关，明心为应验，见性为凝结，天、地、人三元混一为圣胎，性命打成一片为丹成，身外有身为脱胎，打破虚空为了当。 此最上一乘之妙，至士可以行之，谓之“圆顿兼修”、“功满德隆”、“直超圆顿”、“形神俱妙”、“与道合真”。 吾人所做之工夫为渐法，而所修者为“圆顿双修”，殆由渐以顿悟圆通也。 至所说上、中、下三品，皆为渐法，渐法即权法也。 因人而施，异其授受，其中年龄大有关系。 因人到六十四岁之年，卦气尽矣。 卦气既完，阳已无余存者，最上之道，不能即修。 必须先习渐法，去其色身之病，而能延年，渐复真阳，方可授以最上一乘之道。 渐法三品中，尚有上品，可以成道，中品却病延年，下品仅足去病，今日普通外间所讲之道，皆为此渐法三品。 最上一乘，知者鲜矣。 渐法三品中，上品以天地为鼎炉，阴阳为化机，铅汞银砂土为五行，日月为水火，性情为龙虎，念为真种子。 既以念为真种子，所以有心，非无上妙道，以无为主也。

Why is this so? For between the moment of dreaming and waking, it cannot be known whether stray thoughts arise. Thus, there must be a method to ensure that both body and mind remain utterly still during sleep and dreams before it can be employed. If even a single stray thought intrudes, the water source becomes impure and cannot be used. Discerning the clarity or turbidity of the water source is the most critical matter for those who cultivate the Dao.

If there is any concern that the water may be turbid, it is better to abandon it and not use it at all. The details of this shall be explained later.

The Great Dao of Primordial Heaven ultimately resides in returning to emptiness. With emptiness responding to emptiness, the work is entirely within the realm of emptiness.

The methods of elixir refinement are divided into three grades:

**Upper Grade:**
No trigrams or hexagrams, no weights or measures, no fire phases.
There is gathering, but no fixed method.

**Middle Grade:**
No trigrams or hexagrams, but there are weights, measures, and fire phases.
There is gathering, but no fixed method.

**Lower Grade:**
There are trigrams and hexagrams, weights, measures, and fire phases.
There is gathering, and there are fixed methods.

In the Upper Grade, stability and forgetting constitute the entire beginning and end of the work, with no fire phases. Guarding the center and embracing the One—this is its fire phase. Returning to emptiness within emptiness, the resonance occurs naturally within and beyond the body, and the work does not fall into form or appearance.

The Middle Grade is half in form and half beyond it, already clinging to appearances compared to the Upper Grade. The Lower Grade is entirely bound to form and appearance, requiring adherence to fixed methods.

Thus, the Upper Grade may be practiced by superior cultivators, who can achieve success in a year. The Middle Grade may be practiced by average cultivators, who may succeed in three years. The Lower Grade may be practiced by inferior cultivators, but success is uncertain. Even if fortunate enough to succeed, it consumes vast time, and many spend their entire lives without achievement. This method is an "easeful practice," capable only of dispelling illness but not prolonging life.

The Middle Grade may still lead to the Dao, as its work combines pre- and post-heavenly practices, though results are not easily attained. The Lower Grade operates entirely on the post-heavenly physical body, even more limited than the Middle Grade.

Today, most discussions of elixir methods pertain to the Middle and Lower Grades, which cultivators must also understand. Yet the Great Dao of Primordial Heaven does not reside within these three grades of elixir methods, though it shares much with the Upper Grade.

Its work is exceedingly simple, attainable in a single moment. The subtlety of the fire phase lies in its ability to condense: condensing a year into a month, a month into a day, a day into an hour, so that a Celestial Cycle is completed in an instant. As long as one can maintain stability, forgetting, and cessation without error, success is assured.

The Middle Grade, however, is intermixed with the post-heavenly, employing intention and awareness—already clinging to form and partially bound to the body. Thus, returning to emptiness at the end is difficult, and refining the mind is arduous. Even if the work is performed flawlessly, the utmost achievement is merely an earthly immortal, for its work is largely upon the physical form.

The Lower Grade, at best, may produce a human immortal, mostly serving as a method to dispel illness and preserve the body, far removed from true immortality. Only the Upper Grade yields divine immortals.

What I now expound is the highest vehicle of Daoism, the supreme and most authentic Dao—the Great Dao of Primordial Heaven. It takes the Great Void as the crucible, the Supreme Ultimate as the furnace, purity as the foundation of the elixir, non-action as the mother of the elixir, nature and life as lead and mercury, and stability and wisdom as water and fire.

Stability is water; wisdom arises within stability, and fire emerges within wisdom. Restraining desires and curbing anger is the union of water and fire, for only through stability can wisdom arise. As the *Book of Changes* in the *Gen* hexagram states: *"The noble person curbs anger and restrains desires."*

The union of nature and emotions is the parallel of metal and wood. Washing the mind and cleansing thoughts is bathing—this is the great forgetting. Preserving sincerity and stabilizing intention is the seal. The Three Essentials—precepts, stability, and wisdom—are no different from Buddhism; the cultivator need only refine these three.

The center is the Mysterious Pass; illuminating the mind is the sign; perceiving nature is coagulation. The unity of the Three Origins—Heaven, Earth, and Human—is the sacred embryo. The fusion of nature and life is the completion of the elixir. A body beyond the body is the shedding of the embryo. Shattering the void is attainment.

This is the subtlety of the highest vehicle, which superior cultivators may practice. It is called *"simultaneous cultivation of sudden and gradual,"* *"fulfillment of merit and virtue,"* *"direct transcendence and sudden realization,"* *"perfection of form and spirit,"* and *"union with the true Dao."*

Our practice is gradual, yet what we cultivate is *"simultaneous sudden and gradual refinement,"* ultimately achieving sudden enlightenment and perfect penetration through gradual means.

The aforementioned Upper, Middle, and Lower Grades are all gradual methods—gradual methods are expedient teachings, adapted to individuals with varying transmissions. Age is a significant factor, for when one reaches sixty-four, the hexagram *qi* is exhausted. Once the hexagram *qi* is complete, no yang remains, and the highest Dao cannot be immediately practiced. One must first train in gradual methods to dispel illnesses of the physical body, prolong life, and gradually restore true yang before the highest vehicle of the Dao can be transmitted.

Among the three grades of gradual methods, only the Upper Grade can lead to the Dao. The Middle Grade dispels illness and prolongs life, while the Lower Grade merely removes illness. The Dao commonly taught today belongs to these three grades of gradual methods. Few know of the highest vehicle.

In the Upper Grade of gradual methods, Heaven and Earth serve as the crucible and furnace, yin and yang as the mechanism of transformation, lead, mercury, silver, cinnabar, and earth as the Five Phases, the sun and moon as water and fire, nature and emotions as dragon and tiger, and thought as the true seed. Since thought is taken as the true seed, there is intention—this is not the supreme and wondrous Dao, which is rooted in non-action.

chunks.original_text: 有心，所以有存想之法，先须存想“山根”（据《性命圭旨》），以心炼念为火候，息念为养火，含光为固济，降伏内魔为野战，身心意为三要，取其体也； 天心为玄关，取其用也,情来归性为丹成，和气熏蒸为沐浴，乃上乘延生之道。 其中与中乘相似，上士行之，始终如一，亦可成道，不过非金仙之道而已。 中品与此不同，更着相矣：以乾坤为鼎器，以乾为首，坤为腹故也； 坎离为水火，即心肾是也； 乌兔为药物，心气肾气相交是也； 精、神、魂、魄意为五行； 身心为龙虎，气为真种子，一年寒暑为火候，法水灌溉为沐浴，内境不出，外景不入为固济，太渊、绛宫、精房为三要，以泥丸为玄关（大小相交之中如点之外是也），即内虚空是也，在人身上有形之处也； 精神混合为丹成。 此中乘养命之法，与下乘大同小异，功成可以作人仙，而长生久视。 此种丹法，现在讲者最多。 除旁门之外，集会传道者，多系此种。 铁岭孙君所传，则上品也，观其书而知之，因采取时有作为形相也。 尚有下品，更难成矣。 以身心（自己的）为鼎炉，精气为药物，完全是后天之物； 心肾为水火，五脏为五行，肝肺为龙虎，精为真种子，以年、月、日、时行火候，咽津灌溉为沐浴，口鼻为三要，肾前脐后为玄关，五行混合为丹成。 此乃安乐之法，与上三品稍稍同，而作用处有别。 弊在以“还精补脑”一语，象言而实做之，且有用夫妇双修者，，以自己夫妇为限，尚与造孽者不同。 以肾前脐后为玄关者，做工夫之法，由呼吸入手，用意吸气，至脐后肾前之处，使气在其处回旋凝结，此其则也。 下品丹法，最要者在忘情，如能忘情，亦可养命。 只恐不能忘情，则非特不能养命，恐反促命矣。 中品采取有法，以气为真种子。 当气动阳生，即阳举之时而采取，因用乌兔为药物，故左手捉着金乌，右手执住玉兔，又“左捏青龙头，右捉白虎尾”，亦为养命之道，能做好亦可长生久视。 惟上品与最上一乘相似，可以成仙合道。 以天地为鼎炉，仍守空字，以念为真种子，炼念成意为药。 先用止念工夫，念去得真意为真种子。 炼念为火候，息念为温养，与最上乘“虚心”二字不背。 不过炼念息念，即存想之法，凡讲存想者，皆如此也。 定在一处，坚一念而修，可以成地仙； 因恐水源不清，成金仙则不易耳。 兹更就上、中、下三品之玄关，分别列之如下： 上品：玄关在上（泥丸山根）之虚窍及天心为玄关者，阳动时为天心。 中品：玄关在中，脐下一寸三分脐后肾前为玄关。 下品：灵关在上修性，山根为灵关。 玄关在下修命，命门为玄关。 就佛家论，可以修成阿罗汉、声闻、缘觉之果，以其指念为真种子，未能灭尽定也。 至先得阿罗汉，由罗汉修成菩萨，由菩萨修成佛，及“立地成佛”者，皆非修最上一乘，不为功也。 其经两重阶级，乃成佛者，仍因本源不能归空，所以如此迟迟者。 今日讲火候，特将道佛之阶级等等，略为说明。 诸君将来见讲道者，听其言，观其书，即可知其为何品何乘，而不致误入歧途，于修道者有裨也。 最上一乘，先天大道，为三教同一之法，所谓“只此一乘，余二非真”是也。 历来成圣、成佛、成天仙者，皆由此入，皇天无二道也。

With intention comes the method of visualization. First, one must visualize the "Mountain Root" (according to *Xingming Guizhi*), using the refinement of thought as the firing process, the cessation of thought as the nurturing of fire, the containment of light as the sealing of the crucible, and the subjugation of inner demons as field combat. Body, mind, and intention serve as the Three Essentials—here, one grasps their essence. The Heavenly Heart is the Mysterious Pass—here, one grasps its function. When emotions return to nature, the elixir is formed; when harmonious qi steams and permeates, it is the bath. This is the Upper Grade’s Way of prolonging life. Though similar to the Middle Grade, if a superior practitioner cultivates it with unwavering consistency, they may still attain the Dao—though it is not the Way of the Golden Immortal.

The Middle Grade differs from this, becoming even more attached to form: Heaven and Earth serve as the crucible and vessel, with Qian (Heaven) as the head and Kun (Earth) as the abdomen. Kan (Water) and Li (Fire) are the water and fire—namely, the heart and kidneys. The Black Crow and Jade Hare are the medicinal substances, where the qi of the heart and kidneys interact. Essence, spirit, ethereal soul, and corporeal soul are the Five Phases; body and mind are the dragon and tiger; qi is the true seed. A year’s cycle of cold and heat serves as the firing process, and the irrigation of Dharma-water is the bath. When inner visions do not leak outward and outer phenomena do not intrude, this is the sealing of the crucible. The Great Abyss, Crimson Palace, and Essence Chamber are the Three Essentials. The Mud Pill Palace is the Mysterious Pass (the point where the great and small intersect, like the outer edge of a dot)—this is the inner void within the human body, a tangible location. When spirit and essence merge, the elixir is formed. This is the Middle Grade’s method of nourishing life, differing only slightly from the Lower Grade. When the work is complete, one may become a Human Immortal, achieving longevity and enduring vision. This type of elixir method is the most commonly taught today. Aside from heterodox schools, those who gather to transmit the Dao mostly teach this method. The teachings of Master Sun of Tieling belong to the Upper Grade, as can be seen from his writings—his method of gathering the medicine involves intentional form and appearance.

There is also the Lower Grade, which is even harder to master. Here, one’s own body and mind serve as the crucible and furnace, and essence and qi as the medicinal substances—all entirely postnatal. The heart and kidneys are water and fire; the five viscera are the Five Phases; the liver and lungs are the dragon and tiger; essence is the true seed. The firing process follows the cycles of years, months, days, and hours. Swallowing saliva serves as the bath; the mouth and nose are the Three Essentials; the space between the kidneys and the navel is the Mysterious Pass. When the Five Phases merge, the elixir is formed. This is a method of ease and comfort, somewhat similar to the three higher grades but differing in application. Its flaw lies in taking the phrase "returning essence to replenish the brain" literally and putting it into practice. Some even employ dual cultivation with husband and wife, limiting themselves to their own spouse—though this is not as harmful as those who commit transgressions. In this method, the Mysterious Pass between the kidneys and the navel is where the work begins: one uses intention to draw breath, guiding qi to the space between the navel and the kidneys, causing it to circulate and condense there. This is its principle.

The most crucial aspect of the Lower Grade’s elixir method is forgetting emotion. If one can truly forget emotion, they may still nourish life. But if they cannot, not only will they fail to nourish life—they may even hasten its end. The Middle Grade has a method for gathering the medicine, taking qi as the true seed. When qi stirs and yang arises—at the moment of arousal—one gathers it. Since the Black Crow and Jade Hare are the medicinal substances, the left hand grasps the Golden Crow while the right hand seizes the Jade Hare. Alternatively, "the left hand seizes the Green Dragon’s head, the right hand grasps the White Tiger’s tail"—this, too, is a method of nourishing life. If practiced well, one may still achieve longevity and enduring vision.

Only the Upper Grade resembles the Supreme Vehicle, allowing one to become an immortal and merge with the Dao. Using Heaven and Earth as the crucible and furnace, one still abides in emptiness. Thought is the true seed, and refining thought into intention yields the medicine. First, one employs the practice of stopping thought, and when thought is truly gone, intention becomes the true seed. Refining thought is the firing process; ceasing thought is the nurturing. This does not contradict the Supreme Vehicle’s principle of "emptying the mind." However, refining and ceasing thought are methods of visualization—all who teach visualization proceed in this manner. By fixing the mind in one place and cultivating with unwavering focus, one may become an Earth Immortal. Yet if the source of water is not pure, becoming a Golden Immortal is difficult.

Now, let us distinguish the Mysterious Pass in the Upper, Middle, and Lower Grades as follows:

**Upper Grade:** The Mysterious Pass lies above (in the void aperture of the Mud Pill Palace or the Mountain Root) and in the Heavenly Heart—when yang stirs, it is the Heavenly Heart.

**Middle Grade:** The Mysterious Pass lies in the middle, one *cun* and three *fen* below the navel, between the navel and the kidneys.

**Lower Grade:** The Spiritual Pass lies above for cultivating nature, with the Mountain Root as the Spiritual Pass. The Mysterious Pass lies below for cultivating life, with the Gate of Life as the Mysterious Pass.

From the Buddhist perspective, this can lead to the fruition of Arhat, Śrāvaka, or Pratyekabuddha, for it takes thought as the true seed and has not yet extinguished all fixations. Even if one first attains Arhatship, then progresses to Bodhisattvahood, and finally to Buddhahood—or achieves "instant Buddhahood"—this is not the cultivation of the Supreme Vehicle and does not count as merit. Those who ascend through two stages to become Buddhas do so slowly because their original source has not returned to emptiness.

Today, in discussing the firing process, I have briefly explained the gradations of Daoist and Buddhist cultivation. In the future, when you encounter those who teach the Dao, listen to their words and examine their writings—you will then know to which grade and vehicle they belong, avoiding misguided paths. This will benefit those who seek to cultivate the Dao.

The Supreme Vehicle is the primordial Great Dao, the singular method shared by the Three Teachings, as the saying goes: "There is only this one vehicle; the other two are not true." All who have become sages, Buddhas, or Heavenly Immortals throughout history have entered through this path. Heaven has no second Way.

chunks.original_text: 丹书所讲火候，包罗三品而言。 故说先天，而又引证后天之象，更申述曰“象言”。 一面说“虚中采取”，一面云“有所作为”，分别甚着，在读者善读善用之耳。 此所以修丹者，不论何品，皆讲《参同》《悟真》也。 吾讲之“酥麻”二字，邱祖谓之“酥绵”。 邵子曰“三十六宫都是春”，白紫清曰“骨肉融和都不知”，亦酥绵景象也。 还虚时，虚空中所生阳炁，能到我身，其间有感应之理焉。 盖我已虚极静笃，成纯坤之体，则内外两静，杳杳冥冥，不特空其身，又已空其心。 亦非略空，实已空极。 阳气无空不入，恍恍惚惚，内感外应而来到我身，殆全属恍惚杳冥发生之作用也。 《无上玉皇心印妙经》讲之甚详，后当详细述之。 一贯天机直讲卷三

The firing process described in alchemical texts encompasses three grades. Thus, while expounding the primordial, they also cite postcelestial images, further elaborating with "image and word." On one hand, they speak of "gathering in emptiness"; on the other, they speak of "acting with purpose"—the distinction is stark, and it rests with the reader to read and apply wisely. This is why, regardless of grade, all who refine the elixir study the *Triple Concordance* and *Awakening to Reality*.

What I describe as "numbing softness" is termed "silken melting" by Patriarch Qiu. Master Shao said, "The thirty-six palaces are all spring," while Bai Ziqing said, "Bone and flesh harmonize, all unawares"—these, too, are scenes of silken melting. When returning to emptiness, the yang qi born in the void can reach one’s body, for there is a principle of resonance at work. Having attained utmost emptiness and profound stillness, one embodies the pure Kun state, so that inner and outer are both tranquil, boundlessly obscure. Not only is the body emptied, but the heart is emptied as well—not superficially, but to the utmost extreme. Yang qi enters wherever there is no emptiness; in a state of vague indistinctness, inner resonance and outer response bring it to the body—all is the function of arising from the obscure and indistinct.

The *Supreme Jade Emperor’s Heart Seal Wondrous Classic* explains this in great detail, and it shall be expounded fully later.

*Straightforward Explication of the Heavenly Mechanism in One Thread, Scroll Three*

chunks.original_text: 第十一讲 心印妙经丹书之祖 不设象言词明旨远 丹经中，以《阴符》、《道德》、《玉皇心印》、《清净》、《定观》诸经，为上古之书，最为简明，象言绝少。 后世着书设象，比喻层出不穷，于是有象中之象，喻中之喻，学者目眩心迷，无从着想。 且仙真圣贤，各因时代不同，而立言救一时之弊，故其说多有偏泥。 读书者须高具眼孔，识其门户，乃能得其正义。 旁门外道，皆自误解丹经而出，可知丹书难读矣。 兹将《无上玉皇心印妙经》逐一讲解如下： 上药三品，神与气精 夫神者一也，一而神也； 气者二也，两而化也； 精者三也，神与气合生精，而为三也。 既名之曰“上药”，则非后天之物，而为先天之元神、元气、元精无疑矣。 分别言之，后天之神、气、精三者为识神，思虑之神，呼吸之气，交感之精，与先天之三者不同。 元神为乾元祖性，其体本空； 元气者，父母交时，两精两气相合而生之气，即后天之先天炁也； 元精者，混元至精也。 三者合一，即可成道，此上药三品也。 至后天，则元神生思虑神，思虑神为识神之一部分，识神本由元神、元精而出。 中阴入胎，其时混混沌沌，虽夹带情识，而元神尚在，足以制其欲望。 至后天变成坎离，而情变为性，上占元神之地位； 性陷为情，下混于元情之所。 情识夺元神之混沌而为开明，故谓识神为元情元神化合之变体也。 思虑之神，即识神之动于内者，故谓为“一部”，而实为后天人心之主，故言后天即以“思虑之神”代之。 后天识神，由先天元神陷失而生，故丹书谓元神为母，识神（思虑神）为子，有子、母之关系也。 人之最先，只有元神，识神后来者也。 识神挟有情根、智蒂而来，入我中宫，为我主人，涂附习染而加劣。 后天劣性，皆由其智识牵引而来。 倘智识不加污浊，识神仍空洞如元神也。 由此观之，则识神实生于空，由空体感七情六欲，而成识神。 空即元神也，故以元神为母，识神为子，丹经、佛典名之为贼，曰：“不可认贼为子。 ”因劣性而名之为“贼”，贼实子也。 丹经于识神元神，谓之“子藏母胞”。 若识神归元神，则识神自不动矣。 呼吸气与先天炁，亦有母子之关系也。 唯先、后相反，呼吸气为母气，而先天炁为子气。 先天炁，无形者也，呼吸气，有形者也。 以有返无，即在后天呼吸气中，提取先天无形之炁。 道在阴阳相交，熏蒸四体，即可提出先天炁。 譬之蒸气水然，经火锻炼蒸发，而极清之蒸气水出焉，故呼吸气为母气，而先天炁为子气。 丹经曰“母陷子胎”，言先天炁在后天气之胎中也。 唯神与气两者，皆有子母之关系，作丹方有凭藉。 《西游记》有“子母河”，猪八戒过“子母河”吃水而有孕，问之土人方知。 既有孕，即无法打胎。 唯直南去千余里，有“解阳山”，有泉水名“落胎泉”，饮此泉可愈。 此即先天炁也，盖误认有形之气为先天炁而作丹，陷于有形，成为幻丹，故有此譬喻。 子母河，为女儿国所管，女儿为纯阴有形之气也。 神气皆有子母关系，而元精与交感精则有所不同。 元精之为物，名虽为精，其实气也，亦即为情。 元神元气相合，而感生元精，先天也； 以后天之精神，与呼吸之气感情而动，化成有形之精，为交感情，后天也。

**Lecture Eleven: The *Heart Seal Wondrous Classic* as the Ancestor of Alchemical Scriptures—Unadorned with Imagery, Its Words Reveal Profound Meaning**

Among alchemical texts, the *Yin Talisman*, *Dao and Virtue*, *Supreme Jade Emperor’s Heart Seal*, *Purity*, and *Contemplation* are regarded as the most ancient, distinguished by their brevity and clarity, with scarcely any symbolic language. Later works, however, abound in layered metaphors, giving rise to symbols within symbols and analogies within analogies, leaving scholars dazzled and bewildered, with no foothold for understanding. Moreover, the immortals, sages, and worthies of each era addressed the prevailing ills of their time, and thus their teachings often lean toward partiality. Readers must possess keen discernment to recognize their schools of thought and thereby grasp their true principles. Heterodox teachings and external paths all stem from misinterpretations of alchemical classics—such is the difficulty of reading these texts.

Here, the *Supreme Jade Emperor’s Heart Seal Wondrous Classic* shall be explicated in detail as follows:

**The Three Supreme Medicines: Spirit, Qi, and Essence**

Spirit is the One—one, yet spirit. Qi is the Two—two, yet transformative. Essence is the Three—spirit and qi unite to generate essence, forming the triad. Since these are called the "supreme medicines," they are not postnatal substances but undoubtedly the prenatal *yuan* spirit, *yuan* qi, and *yuan* essence.

Distinguishing them: the postnatal spirit, qi, and essence—namely, the spirit of consciousness, the spirit of thought, the qi of breath, and the essence of intercourse—differ from the prenatal triad. The *yuan* spirit is the primordial nature of Qian, its substance inherently empty. The *yuan* qi is the qi generated at the moment of parental union, when the two essences and two qi merge—this is the prenatal within the postnatal. The *yuan* essence is the primordial, most refined essence. When these three unite as one, Dao may be attained—such are the three supreme medicines.

In the postnatal realm, the *yuan* spirit generates the spirit of thought, which is a part of the spirit of consciousness. The spirit of consciousness arises from the *yuan* spirit and *yuan* essence. During the intermediate state before rebirth, in that state of undifferentiated chaos, though tainted by karmic consciousness, the *yuan* spirit remains, sufficient to restrain desire. Postnatally, it transforms into Kan and Li, where emotion supplants nature, usurping the place of the *yuan* spirit; nature sinks into emotion, merging with the realm of primordial emotion. Consciousness seizes the undifferentiated chaos of the *yuan* spirit, rendering it luminous—thus, the spirit of consciousness is the transformed body of the union of primordial emotion and *yuan* spirit. The spirit of thought is the internal movement of the spirit of consciousness, hence called "one part," yet it truly governs the postnatal human heart. Thus, in postnatal terms, it is referred to as the "spirit of thought."

The postnatal spirit of consciousness arises from the loss of the prenatal *yuan* spirit, so alchemical texts call the *yuan* spirit the mother and the spirit of consciousness (the spirit of thought) the child, establishing a mother-child relationship. Initially, humans possess only the *yuan* spirit; the spirit of consciousness comes later. It arrives bearing the roots of emotion and the stems of intellect, entering the central palace to become the master, coating and contaminating it with habitual defilements. All postnatal base qualities arise from the pull of this intellect. If the intellect remains unstained, the spirit of consciousness remains as empty as the *yuan* spirit. From this, it is evident that the spirit of consciousness is born from emptiness, taking emptiness as its substance and responding to the seven emotions and six desires to become the spirit of consciousness. Emptiness is the *yuan* spirit—hence, the *yuan* spirit is the mother, and the spirit of consciousness the child. Alchemical texts and Buddhist scriptures call it a thief, saying, "Do not mistake the thief for your child." It is named a "thief" due to its base qualities, though in truth, it is the child.

Alchemical texts refer to the *yuan* spirit and the spirit of consciousness as "the child concealed within the mother’s womb." If the spirit of consciousness returns to the *yuan* spirit, it ceases to move.

The qi of breath and the prenatal qi also share a mother-child relationship, though in reverse: the qi of breath is the mother qi, while the prenatal qi is the child qi. The prenatal qi is formless; the qi of breath is formed. Returning from form to formlessness entails extracting the prenatal, formless qi from the postnatal qi of breath. The Dao lies in the union of yin and yang, steaming and permeating the four limbs, thereby drawing forth the prenatal qi. It is like distilled water: subjected to fire and refinement, the purest vapor emerges. Thus, the qi of breath is the mother qi, and the prenatal qi the child qi. Alchemical texts say, "The mother is trapped in the child’s womb," meaning the prenatal qi resides within the womb of postnatal qi.

Only when spirit and qi share this mother-child relationship can the elixir be formed with a foundation. *Journey to the West* speaks of the "Mother-Child River," where Zhu Bajie, after drinking its water, becomes pregnant, only learning the cause from the locals. Once pregnant, no abortion is possible—except by traveling over a thousand *li* south to "Sun-Unbinding Mountain," where the "Miscarriage Spring" flows. Drinking its water cures the condition. This is the prenatal qi: mistaking the formed qi for the prenatal qi in elixir-making traps one in form, producing a phantom elixir—hence the analogy. The Mother-Child River is governed by the Women’s Country, representing the purely yin, formed qi.

While spirit and qi share a mother-child relationship, *yuan* essence and the essence of intercourse differ. Though called "essence," *yuan* essence is in truth qi—more precisely, emotion. The union of *yuan* spirit and *yuan* qi generates *yuan* essence—this is the prenatal. Postnatally, the essence of spirit and the qi of breath, stirred by emotion, transform into formed essence, the essence of intercourse—this is the postnatal.

chunks.original_text: 识神一也，呼吸气二也，元精三也，合一二三而成四，为交感情。 不能自生自化，必须三合而成。 所以修道者，须先将交感精化成元精，所谓“炼精化气”是也，此第一步工夫也。 第二步为“炼气化神”，第三步为“炼神还虚”。 交感精因动而生，别有淫根，为出入门户。 不去淫根，不能断淫。 修道者将有形者，化为无形，不空者化而为空，情化为性。 欲断淫根，须先将交感精化为元精。 《楞严经》缘起于淫，阿难陷于魔女淫室,淫根未断，不得"漏尽通,"未能免难,所漏者虽仅淫精,然此精由神气交感而生，则神气亦随漏矣。 惟得“漏尽通”，则不漏，而可断淫根。 观音得道，何以在耳？ 因耳肾同为坎，精由肾漏，即由耳亦漏。 故须调息，喝音入耳，以藏神于耳。 欲水源清，在先洗耳，肾水自清。 耳可遍听八方，有千二百功德； 眼只能视前，而不能及后，仅有八百功德； 口鼻同眼，八百功德； 意能周知远近，亦同于耳，有千二百功德。 佛宗先净耳、意两根，求得真意归耳，方可观音得道。 千二百功德，能统八百功德故也，观音得道，方能断得淫根淫意。 经说人身三淫：意、身、根是也。 单断一根，如身如意，皆不能断淫无漏； 必断淫根，方能断淫，为漏尽通，见“马阴藏相”。 道家说“阴缩如龟”，小周天完成，七返九还工夫已毕，方现此相而断“三淫”，还成童体，可进修“上德无为”之道，如童体修真无异。 此最上一层，无为大道也。 上、中、下三品渐法，则不然。 虽修功深，至淫根仍难断尽，仅为缩而不动，尚未能灭尽成童体也。 中、下两品，淫根更难于断。 因进修时，夹杂后天精气，只能却病延年，去仙远矣。 仙须先断淫根，语曰“天上无漏精的神仙”，即此是也。 安乐法多有采炼后天者，以识神与呼吸气为身心鼎炉，为药物乌兔，而采取交感之淫精，不知此有形质之物，何所用之！ 不过得一时身体光润，面目红紫而已。 凡有形质之物，终有坏时，更有男女交媾，不泄精而返之者，则为外道邪说也。 其间主夫妇双修者，尚无损于私德，若用女鼎，则作孽而非修道矣。 夫上药三品，自是先天无形之物，后天岂可谓“上”！ 《易》曰：“形而上者谓之道。 ”（见《系辞上》）形上，即先天也，先天之神与气、精，为作丹之大药，而水、火亦在其中。 元神为心之主，元气为身之主，元精为意之主。 神动气随，精亦因之而动，故先言神，后言气、精。 白玉蟾曰：“此神不是思虑神，乃是混沌之元神； 此炁不是呼吸气，乃知却是太素烟； 此精不是交感精，乃是玉皇口中涎。 ”（按白玉蟾《心意恁地歌》原作：“其精不是交感精，乃是玉皇口中涎； 其气即非呼吸气，乃知却是太素烟； 其神即非思虑神，可与无始相比肩。 ”）先天元神，便是空性之动体，真空而妙有者也； 先天元炁，便是太极中之理气，妙有而真空者也。 “两者同出异名，同谓之玄，玄之又玄，众妙之门”（见《老子》）也。 元气者，“玄”也； 元神者，“玄之又玄”也。 神气合而生元精，谓之“至阳之精”。 佛曰：“我有一宝，秘在形山。 ”道曰：“先天一点阳精，不在心肾，而在元关一窍。 ”元关者，神气合为药物，药物而生之玄窍也。

The *shí* spirit is one, the breath of respiration two, and *yuan* essence three—combining these three to form four yields the essence of intercourse. It cannot generate or transform itself; it must arise from the union of the three. Thus, those who cultivate the Dao must first transmute the essence of intercourse into *yuan* essence—this is what is called "refining essence into qi," the first step in the work. The second step is "refining qi into spirit," and the third is "refining spirit to return to emptiness."

The essence of intercourse arises from movement and possesses a distinct root of lust, serving as the gateway of ingress and egress. Without severing this root, one cannot cut off lust. The cultivator transforms the formed into the formless, the non-empty into emptiness, and emotion into nature. To sever the root of lust, one must first transmute the essence of intercourse into *yuan* essence.

The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* originates from lust: Ānanda fell into the chamber of demonic women, his root of lust unsevered, and thus failed to attain the "perfection of ending outflows." Unable to escape calamity, what leaked was merely the essence of lust, yet this essence arises from the intercourse of spirit and qi—thus, spirit and qi also leak with it. Only by attaining the "perfection of ending outflows" can one cease leakage and sever the root of lust.

Why did Avalokiteśvara attain the Dao through the ear? Because the ear and kidney both belong to *kǎn*, and when essence leaks from the kidney, it also leaks from the ear. Thus, one must regulate the breath, directing sound into the ear to conceal the spirit within it. To purify the source of water, one must first cleanse the ear, and the kidney’s water will naturally clear. The ear can hear in all eight directions, possessing one thousand two hundred merits; the eye can only see what lies ahead and not behind, possessing but eight hundred merits. The mouth and nose share the same eight hundred merits as the eye, while the mind, capable of knowing both near and far, also possesses one thousand two hundred merits, like the ear.

The Buddhist school first purifies the ear and mind, seeking the true mind to return to the ear—only then can one attain the Dao as Avalokiteśvara did. The one thousand two hundred merits can govern the eight hundred merits, and only after attaining the Dao as Avalokiteśvara can one sever the roots of lustful thoughts and desires.

The scriptures speak of three lusts in the human body: mind, body, and root. Severing only one, whether body or mind, cannot cut off lust or end outflows. Only by severing the root of lust can one achieve the "perfection of ending outflows" and witness the "concealment of the horse’s yin," the "yin retracting like a tortoise." When the minor celestial cycle is complete and the work of seven returns and nine refinements is finished, this sign appears, the "three lusts" are severed, and the body returns to the state of a virgin—only then can one advance to cultivate the "effortless Dao of supreme virtue," no different from a virgin cultivating the truth. This is the highest realm, the great Dao of non-action.

The gradual methods of the upper, middle, and lower grades differ. Even with deep cultivation, the root of lust remains difficult to sever entirely—it may merely retract and cease movement, yet it is not extinguished to restore the virgin body. In the middle and lower grades, the root of lust is even harder to sever. During cultivation, postnatal essence and qi are intermingled, allowing only the alleviation of illness and extension of life—immortality remains distant. To become an immortal, one must first sever the root of lust, as the saying goes: "There are no immortals in heaven who leak essence."

The methods of bliss often involve refining the postnatal, taking the *shí* spirit and breath as the cauldron and furnace of body and mind, and the hare and crow as medicinal substances, harvesting the essence of intercourse. Yet what use is this formed, substantial thing? It merely yields a temporary glow to the body and a flush to the face. All formed, substantial things will eventually decay.

There are those who, in sexual intercourse between men and women, do not emit essence but return it—this is heterodox and heretical. Among them, those who practice dual cultivation with husband and wife do no harm to personal virtue, but to use a female cauldron is to commit sin, not to cultivate the Dao.

The three grades of supreme medicine are inherently formless and prenatal; how can the postnatal be called "supreme"? As the *Book of Changes* states: "That which is above form is called the Dao" (*Xì Cí*, Part I). "Above form" is the prenatal. The prenatal spirit, qi, and essence are the great medicines for elixir-making, and water and fire are also within them.

The *yuan* spirit governs the heart, *yuan* qi governs the body, and *yuan* essence governs the mind. When the spirit moves, qi follows, and essence moves accordingly—thus, spirit is mentioned first, followed by qi and essence.

Bái Yùchán said:
*"This spirit is not the spirit of thought,
But the primordial *yuan* spirit of chaos;
This qi is not the breath of respiration,
But the mist of pristine simplicity;
This essence is not the essence of intercourse,
But the saliva in the Jade Emperor’s mouth."*
(Note: The original *Xīn Yì Rèn Dì Gē* by Bái Yùchán reads:
*"Its essence is not the essence of intercourse,
But the saliva in the Jade Emperor’s mouth;
Its qi is not the breath of respiration,
But the mist of pristine simplicity;
Its spirit is not the spirit of thought,
But one that can stand shoulder to shoulder with the beginningless."*)

The prenatal *yuan* spirit is the dynamic aspect of empty nature, the true emptiness that is wondrous existence. The prenatal *yuan* qi is the principle and qi within the Supreme Ultimate, the wondrous existence that is true emptiness. "These two emerge from the same source but differ in name; together they are called the mysterious, the mystery of mysteries, the gateway to all wonders" (*Laozi*). *Yuan* qi is the "mysterious," and *yuan* spirit is the "mystery of mysteries."

When spirit and qi unite to generate *yuan* essence, it is called "the essence of utmost yang." The Buddha said: "I possess a treasure, hidden within the mountain of form." The Dao says: "The single point of prenatal yang essence resides not in the heart or kidney, but in the single aperture of the *yuan* pass." The *yuan* pass is the mysterious aperture where spirit and qi unite as medicine, and from which medicine is born.

The union of *yuan* spirit and *yuan* qi generates *yuan* essence—this is the prenatal.
